title: What global challenge do you think innovation leaders should work to solve right now?

cross_cultural_collaboration_innovation_.description: How can we use design, skills and resources across countries and cultures to design better products (& lifestyles), while creating a better life for those in developing countries by helping them preserve their culture and traditions in craftsmanship, yet pushing it in new ways?
cross_cultural_collaboration_innovation_.creator: 6c0a47abfa928ba77d47a123185f455d

comments.text: thanks for that, Sydney! Here's the link for others wanting to learn more: http://www.worldofgoodinc.com/ there is even an eBay component http://worldofgood.ebay.com/

There is a company called World of Good that goes to many developing countries and connects with local artisans to create a relationship with them so that they can then sell their products in the international marketplace. I know it's not related to bamboo, but it demonstrates the concept of humanizing the producer by creating a direct relationship with them. I believe ideas can be extrapolated by all companies and organizations like this to find common "seeds" of innovation that can then be applied to any and all industrial and commercial sectors.

I was discussing a different angle about bamboo for Open Planet Ideas http://www.openplanetideas.com/how-can-sony-technology-be-used-to-address-environmental-challenges/concepting/share-new-ways-of-creating-products-using-more-renewable-resources/ that renewable resources like bamboo could be used as alternate to platics. I think it is a versatile product so I do hope someone or some company would create an alternate to plastic packaging.

This is great Anne.Here's a couple more bamboo businesses you might like:Bamboo coffins:  http://www.oasisbamboocoffins.com/Bamboo bicycles:  http://www.bamboosero.com/Fair trade, sustainable, renewable resource, employment creation in the developing world for consumers in the West.   It's all about valuing what we buy so much more and ditching the mass produced throw away culture that's become the norm.

Great summary Anne! We like that it acknowledges the expertise that exists with the *artisans* as well as Ekobo. This way innovation can flow from top-down and bottom-up with mutual benefits at both ends. And we're loving that it's centered on a renewable resource!

cross_cultural_collaboration_innovation_.title: CROSS-CULTURAL COLLABORATION / INNOVATION THROUGH DESIGN

how_do_you_teach_people_to_lead_themselv.description: “How can we really help and improve other countries?"  In my opinion, aide needs to go beyond providing much required goods and resources. We also need to discover how to teach citizens to lead and to build communities.
how_do_you_teach_people_to_lead_themselv.creator: ee15faeef1f7f4986be4088581e20544

http://www.sarvodaya.org/ is the link for the largest social change movement in Sri Lanka . They work to empower local communities (villages) to meet their own needs for sustainable development. In the last 40 years they have reached over 1/3 of villages in Sri Lanka, and have huge amounts of experience with creating and implementing programs which provide solutions in the realm of the  the formula above.

how_do_we_foster_education_and_empower_y.description: Prosperity and quality of life in developing countries is tied closely to the level of education of its people. People in more remote areas are sometimes unaware of the importance of education. However, improving education is correlated to improved health, democracy, and economic development. As a new generation in over-populated parts of the world inherits greater societal and economic problems, education can be their savior.
how_do_we_foster_education_and_empower_y.creator: a2e8cea3392da09d1d31be3fca68efed

comments.text: Thanks everyone! I look forward to seeing the innovative ways in which we can find an answer to this question. Onward!
Congratulations on making it to the final 9 on the agenda! Well done!http://reasonedprogression.wordpress.com

Excellent question Nadia! And one we were interested in exploring during our earlier challenge on increasing the availability of affordable learning tools and services in the developing world: http://bit.ly/az46Xk

Very interesting project, and a good point you're making. Education is important, and it would be great to see how the i20 can take on the question you pose of fostering education and empowering youth that now sometimes are without a chance of bettering themselves and their communities.
An interesting model to look at is Khan academy: http://www.khanacademy.org/

tourism_as_empowerment.description: How can we use tourism to empower local communities and improve visitor experience?
tourism_as_empowerment.creator: 6c0a47abfa928ba77d47a123185f455d

comments.text: Another interesting example I just heard of: visiting the townships of South Africa via bicycle http://blog.africabespoke.com/experience-real-township-life-with-vamos-cycling-tours-in-langa/

I like the idea of both parties mutually benefitting. I work with an organization that tries to bridge both local and international community and enrich the lives of all participants in what they call "social sculptures" based in Italy. It is recent in the past three years, but I think they are on the right track. It is an interesting model. www.artmonastery.org

Hi Anne, I agree that it's definitely a worrisome development, especially the begging for money. But it is often a matter of opportunity. If you are in a place where locals ask for money for directions, you sort of know that there have been tourists who give that too easy. I think tour operators have a responsibility here. It's often not the travelers like you and me who create these opportunities :).

Hi Ashley! Thanks for that! I think it's really interesting that the Pachamama Alliance is a U.S. based non-profit, and that it was the indigin elders and shamans themselves who initiated the relationship. It's definitely a key factor to have both parties involved.

Anne, I really like this idea (although it's too bad it's inspired by a negative experience!). I think looking at tourism as a way to empower local communities and economies is a really terrific idea - and not just because it leads to improved cultural understanding and increased education and sensitivity. Tourism can also be an incredible tool for expanding awareness of ecological/environmental issues while also helping local economies flourish. One organization that's doing this is The Pachamama Alliance (www.pachamama.org). They have worked directly with the Achuar Tribe in Ecuador to develop sustainable/eco tourism experiences for travelers who want to both learn about new parts of the world and help protect this tribe's cultural ways for future generations. Definitely one group to check out!

Arjan - Yes, I agree. It's definitely part of many cultures to negotiate prices, and part of the fun of travel. However, I felt like in the instance [post] I linked to this game of negotiation had been taken to a new, more negative level. It was the paying for directions that worried both me (and alarmed my prof) the most. I still wonder what more we can do beyond just doing our "research" before we go a new place. Language barrier can also complicate things too.

It's always a bit difficult. On one hand, the culture of negotiating a price is different than people are used to in Western Europe. But, it's an integral part of doing business in shops in North Africa. So over-pricing is part of the game. They normally don't expect you to pay it all, they expect you to come with a counter offer. Knowing this, and using this, helps a lot to have a great tourist experience. About the asking for money for directions, that's indeed a sign of things going wrong. Years ago, in Cuba, I experienced the same thing in Havana. Everybody was holding out their hand for some money. In other places, however, where tourism was less, people just wanted to talk to you to learn, share and practice their English. To me, this indicated also that the problem is on both sides. It's not only the locals that ask for money, but it is some tourists that like to play Santa Claus and show off their wealth by giving money to the 'poor locals', only to feel like a wealthy good person. Education is needed for tourists as well.
Love this. You're not alone in having these thoughts!

tourism_as_empowerment.title: Rethinking Tourism - tourism as empowerment

how_can_we_encourage_innovation_design_e.description: There is a severe lack of design and innovation education throughout many schooling systems throughout the world. How can we encourage education systems to provide more opportunities for students to learn about the power of innovation and design?
how_can_we_encourage_innovation_design_e.creator: 711c99771f3ceed49f77ac8c7c89ac2d

comments.text: Education needs a lot of work, and this is a great idea. What I love about design thinking is that it enables constructive dialogue around what is and what we can improve. If only people everywhere were exposed to this kind of thinking early on in life.

This is a great idea. I personally wished design had been taught in school. I am just getting involved in it professionally and never realized what importance it could play on a global scale. Going through high school, etc. we were forced to think of math/science/english as the "real courses" and other subjects like "art, design, etc." and just interests. Had I realized both are equally important disciplines, I could have realized my true passion for design earlier.

I know I'm very behind in commenting on this (I just signed onto openIDEO today) but I really want to applaud the focus on innovation in education.  I'm a former science teacher in the U.S. public school system and have been keen on creating well-scaffolded "design challenges" for my students -- whether building bridges in physics or prototyping self-sustaining biodomes in biology. I think the question for the i20 leaders is how to build enough flexibility into the curricular standards and accountability systems that there is freedom to invest in design challenges in the classroom.

There have been talks and arguments recently about the limits on the free mind that today's education imposes. Formal education which includes ample ready-to-apply concepts and definitions confines creativity and creates individuals who can best work on ready models and well-known concepts. Crayons and blank pieces of paper should be brought back to high school, universities and other educational institutions. I myself got a new pack of crayons a few days ago. Therefore, I will try to rejuvenate my kindergarten creativity which I missed for years.
Congratulations to the final nine concepts.  There were so many good ideas and challenges to think about.
Congratulations on making it to the final 9 on the agenda! Well done!http://reasonedprogression.wordpress.com

Adam, the K-12 Lab at Stanford's d.school has already tested and shared a great, hands-on design curriculum:https://dschool.stanford.edu/groups/k12/wiki/332ff/Curriculum_Home_Page.html
Copy and apply locally as needed:)

Very good point Pablo. I'm definitely in agreement with the thought that design and innovation can come from any profession and area. So it's not only providing more opportunities to design and innovate but to provide them in various different subject areas.
Johan that sounds like a wonderful event that they have going on there. Really interesting and definitely the type of thing I think we need to see more of.

Hey man, very good point there and we definitely need everyone to apply creative thinking in every field, the only thing i'd like to add is that i personally believe that even though i agree with you saying that children should be exposed to creative thinking at an early stage, i also believe that Design itself is a profession that people chooses based on their understanding of their skills and preferences, current education programs introduce a variety of subjects in order to give students a broader vision of the world and its complexities and finally giving them the choice to develop an expertise in a particular subject or profession; creative thinking can be applied from any profession and therefore it should be actively encouraged in every subject being taught , but how can we do that in a more effective way that hasn't been tried out by the educational systems already?

Feel free to add information about a project that I wrote about, Innovation plant It is written as comments in an inspiration made by user : Nicole(scroll down to the bottom)
http://openideo.com/open/what-is-the-global-challenge-that-most-concerns-you-right-now-and-that-global-innovation-leaders-could-begin-to-solve/inspiration/interdisciplinary-incubators/

Great question Adam! 
If you want more DQ points : ) you can look through the Inspiration phase and add posts like Project H design, confidence in creative abilities, etc. (Use the update button on the left)

how_can_disaster_relief_be_coordinated_t.description: When natural disaster strikes there is always an immediate and immense global outpouring of medical aid, food, supplies and support.  Most times, this influx of aid is not accompanied by operational management and coordination through a centralized organization.  Too often this results in aid transportation bottle necks, disproportionate supply surpluses, misallocation of resources, distribution delays, etc.  All of this can put the most vulnerable disaster victims at greater risk and potentially cost more lives.  Is there a better way to coordinate the good will, resources and energy of the global community to more efficiently and effectively bring relief to the victims of disaster?
how_can_disaster_relief_be_coordinated_t.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: hey, could we get rid of all the plastic bottle waste in desaster relieve? just look at the picture above: even there helpers import tons of plastic waste to rural areas with each plane load.

Sabra, great point!  Displacement and refugee camps are a very serious problem.  Not only do neighboring countries such as Pakistan in relation to Afghanistan and Kenya and Ethiopia in relation to Somalia feel the burden of thousands of refugees flooding across their borders but also the sad fact that refugee camps are quick to succumb to the spread of disease, crime, rape, etc.  Right now Haiti is suffering from the outbreak of cholera  And this is almost a year after the earthquake that devastated that country.  Which brings up another grim fact in that on top of all the suffering that the victims of whatever disaster have already gone through, refugee camps tend to also suffer from inertia.  Once they are in place it is very hard to get families back to their original homes. So, yes, the more efficient and effective a disaster relief effort is, using Ushahidi, something like it, or a combination of methods, the less victims may have to be relocated to refugee camps and face an even more uncertain future.Thanks again Sabra!
What do you think of our new solution for reusable, rapid response emergency relief housing: http://www.reactionhousingsystem.com/
What do you think of our new solution for reusable, rapid response emergency relief housing: http://www.reactionhousingsystem.com/
Each days news gives more reasons why we desperately need solutions in this area. 800,000 in Haiti still in " tents".
We're trying to change that with http://www.reactionhousingsystem.com/
Congratulations on making it all the way to the final 9 on the agenda!!

Meena!  Thanks for the heads up and the link!  How funny!  It seems the city got caught on it's heels by the snow storm and left lots of neighborhoods unplowed.  So people started shoveling each other out.  Almost all of the 20 inches of snow has melted already but it caused an uproar while it lasted.  The mayor had to publicly apologize for not getting all of New York's streets plowed right away.  Definitely not as life threatening as something like the Haiti earthquake but it shows how adaptable Ushahidi is.Thanks again! And Happy New Year!
Demian  thought you might be interested that Ushahidi has even been used in your own NYC this winter!  to deal with snow via social collaboration: http://bit.ly/eAW0YL

I applauded and evaluated your concept.  While it's a compelling issue, I feel that a humane global system of technology and resources would quickly solve it.
If I could have built on this, I would have.

Thao, thanks for your comment!  Yes, I need to spend some more time with Ushahidi to truly understand it but from what I can tell at this point it looks really great.  Definitely very usable for situations I am thinking about.  My main question that I would like to explore further is it's usefulness on a coordination level from the standpoint of the multitude of incoming independent relief organizations.  Can each of them fully utilize Ushahidi to orchestrate their movements with those of all the other aid groups to maximize efficiency and effectiveness, responding to the information they are receiving from on the ground?  But from what I can tell so far, this capability is either available already or easily developed within the Ushahidi framework.  Very cool.Thanks again Thao!

What's also great about Ushahidi are the many applications that people have come up with. From violence in Kenya to harassment in Egypt, and Sabra's idea about using it to stabilize the economy of nations  these are just a few of the creative applications and the possibilities are endless. Ushahidi is a mashup of all things great: mobile phones and SMS, web and social media, crowdsourcing and peer-to-peer, etc. Yes, I'm a big fan!

Another area that this concept will help with is reducing refugee stress in surrounding populations. Coordination of aid means less people have to be displaced long distances from their home place, and the demand for food and other resources doesn't destabilize the economy of host populations as much.

Sabra, thanks for the comment!  Yes, the increasing global population does bring with it more more dangers and challenges.  The world's urban centers are much more populated, and densely populated at that, than ever before.  And with large portions of those urban populations living in substandard housing, many people are left more vulnerable than they should be.  I agree with you that a more efficient system of disaster response will have direct impact on the lives of the victims.  As we saw in Haiti, the survival of people trapped in the rubble of collapsed buildings was utterly dependent on how quickly relief workers could be mobilized and get to them.  One thing I like very much about the Ushahidi system that Meena brought to my attention, is the ability of trapped people to text their location and condition to the system.  Rescue workers monitoring the map generated by the texted data can then more efficiently target areas with the most trapped people which would enable them to hopefully save more lives more quickly.Thanks again for your comment!

Indeed Demian: Ushahidi is used in both those ways. One of the things I like about Ushahidi is that it facilitates P2P, collaborative networks which often work more efficiently than single organisations. Frontline SMS and Samasource have also been doing good work along these lines at sites of disaster. I feel that innovation for disaster relief needs to include acknowledgment of the power and opportunity in P2P networks  both digital and otherwise.
Good stuff as always Meena. Thank you!

Meena!  Thanks for the tip!  How did I not see Ushahidi?! It is amazing!  The story you linked to is here: http://www.newsweek.com/blogs/techtonic-shifts/2010/03/03/ushahidi-technology-saves-lives-in-haiti-and-chile.html# in case anyone missed it.  Ushahidi's use and adaptation to the earthquake situation in Haiti was really great.  I am sure I do not understand completely how it was utilized but I think it would be great if it could be used in both directions. From one perspective, victims could use it to report their medical need, location, an emergency, etc. so that a working map of situational need could be established and monitored.  But also from the other side Ushahidi could be utilized by incoming aid organizations and rescue workers to notify other aid organizations of their contributions and capabilities.  Aid organizations could post the supplies, food, equipment, etc. that they have brought in.  They could also give information on their location, the personnel they have on their team, their mobility, established nodes of distribution, any immediate need in their current location, etc., etc.  All of this information from every aid group could be aggregated to form a continually updating map of relief work being done, current clear lines of transportation, points of distribution, areas of specific need, etc.  This could greatly help inform other aid organizations on what is needed at the moment and how best their available resources could be put to use.I could go on and on... but I love it.  Thanks again for alerting me to Ushahidi.  I actually think that it could be beautifully developed to address my concept on utilizing cell phones to gather real-time health data in the developing world http://tinyurl.com/2vspwd8  I will go there now to tie it in...

This is a most needed concept Demian. In our current human degraded environment with such a quickly growing human population, we are bound to have even more disasters in the future. Coordinating and systematizing disaster relief will enable us to greatly reduce wastage of resources and human lives.

Nice one Demian. You can add Ushahidi from the Inspiration Phase as a Build Upon post for this. I'll let you search for it ;^) but here's an article that talks about how it's assisted disaster management efforts: http://bit.ly/i7Bzxs

how_can_disaster_relief_be_coordinated_t.title: How Can Disaster Relief be Coordinated to Make it Most Efficient And Effective?

comments.text: Brilliant
The inspiration for me is that beauty in design shouldn't be overlooked. It can  be a powerful means to instill pride and ownership over protecting one's community.

Definitely, this issue is much deeper than that. But if more initiatives from individuals and the private sector can bring light to the problems while improving their lives a little bit (maybe a lot depending on what they do), we might be on the way to something...

I would like to have more colours in the city, but I not not sure that just having colourful facades sufficient to improve the lives of the people there, their poverty and health environment? We may have to seriously consider this issue much further.
Love this project!
@Nicole: you should add that TED movie as an inspiration as well. Absolutely wonderful.

I agree with Emily, the picture is amazing. And the initiative as well. It plays in to the Broken Windows theory - http://3bl.me/3qxgfs - it would be great if this can be promoted as a model in other places.
this is my favourite picture in this challenge
stunning and beautiful
I love this. It reminds me of TED prize winner JR: http://www.tedprize.org/congratulations-to-the-2011-ted-prize-winner-jr/

women_and_girls_aren_2019_t_the_problem_.description: There’s a growing recognition in the world that focusing on women and girls is the most effective way to fight global poverty and extremism. The world is awakening to a powerful truth: Women and girls aren’t the problem; they’re the solution.
women_and_girls_aren_2019_t_the_problem_.creator: 94f8ef29957040e42b74843c902d2eea

comments.text: David, thanks for this concept.  It is a vital issue to be dealt with.  Unfortunately made all the more complex by the many and varied contexts within which women and girls are repressed and relegated.  If it were simply a matter of education that would be one thing, but too often it is the environments and societies within which these women live that resist any change to the status quo.  No amount of new educational resources will help if the culture in which they are delivered does not see women's education as valuable and vital also.  Positive change for women needs to happen as a change on the larger cultural, societal and religious scale if it is going to have a lasting effect on each woman and girl in that community on an individual level.  Therein lies the trick, I think.Great stuff to think about and lots of opportunities.  Thanks for putting the concept in there!

Important concept. The position of women is fortunately more and more being seen as important all around the world. The rise of Grameen bank and micro financing is a great example of this. Although I really feel this is an important issue, my question is if there is not already so much being done around this issue, that it might be better to take more specific action. For example how to ensure that young girls get equal access to education.

how_can_fuel_efficiency_innovation_be_pu.description: From 1975 through 1985 U.S. auto fuel efficiency was steadily increasing, with passenger vehicle mileage doubling from roughly 13.5 to 27.5mpg.  Unfortunately, under pressure from automaker lobbyists, the Reagan Administration had the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration lower the efficiency standard from 27.5 to 26mpg.  The momentum of innovation has never fully recovered.
how_can_fuel_efficiency_innovation_be_pu.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: Sabra, thanks for the comment and the Volvo story!  You are right that it has never been an issue of technology or the potential of technology.  The main problem has been one of incentive.  As illustrated by the above graph and the Pew Campaign for Fuel Efficiency article in the link, oil companies put pressure on the U.S. president and lawmakers to keep gas mileage standards low.  The politicians caved and the oil companies succeeded, and continue to succeed, at stifling innovation and the development of fuel efficient autos sold to the mass market.  The fact that this has done so much to pollute our environment is criminal.  And we are suckers for allowing it to go on for so long.Thanks again for your comment!

In 1950 a European couple brought their Volvo (small car) to the U.S. for their honeymoon. It was written about in Reader's Digest (a popular magazine). That car got 40 miles to the U.S. gallon (smaller than British Imperial gallon). In the same magazine issue was an article about why it would be impossible to make a car that could get 50 miles per gallon. Most U.S. cars of the day got 10-20 miles per gallon. The problem has never been one of technology. 
Henry Ford originally made his Model T(the first mass production automobile) to run on alcohol, since most farmers made alcohol for cleaning and burning in lamps anyway. Fueling cars on petroleum was a decision based on maximizing profits for oil companies. Petroleum was the dirty stuff left over from making kerosene. When it became difficult to get away with just dumping it, they had to come up with a way to sell it to us.

Simon, Thanks for the comment!  Agreed.  Just because an energy source is not oil-based gas does not mean that it is clean.  Electricity may sound cleaner than gas but the sad truth is that some electricity is produced from burning coal.  You are correct in that we need to look at alternative energy sources from beginning of their life cycle to the end.  But the point is that major amounts of time and research have to happen so that great leaps in efficiency and fuel alternatives can be made as quickly as possible.  Thanks again!

Andrea, Thanks for the comment!  The Brazil model you mention sounds very interesting and a case worth studying.  Unfortunately it seems that automakers in the United States have been focused not on fuel efficiency innovation but on maintaining the status quo and selling a driving experience based on artificially cheap gasoline.  Since gas has been so cheap for the last 30 years, car buyers can indulge in vehicles with more power and size.  In Europe, however, where gas prices have historically been less subsidized than the U.S., vehicles are generally smaller and more efficient.  It could be argued that a more realistic understanding of the actual cost of driving has created a culture of buyers that is more concerned with fuel economy.Maybe the real challenge is to change the culture to not only accept but to also want vehicles with greater fuel efficiency.  But I think that legislators have to understand that they have a responsibility not to lobbyists but to the entire global population as they can be key influencers of culture and change for the better.Thanks again for your comment!

This sounds good. I guess we need to be sure that making all these huge batteries for electric cars is itself "more" sustainable. A battery rental or buy-back scheme might be a solution... Trials going on now; see http://www.ted.com/talks/shai_agassi_on_electric_cars.html

Its a really interesting thought. Today much focus is placed on electric cars and bio ethanol, which both are good candidates for the future. But let's face it, its far in the future. I think Brazil is a good country to look for inspiration. They have, through legislations and innovative technologies by automakers, managed to change the fuel industry. They now have almost 30% of fuel as ethanol, and most of the new cars flex cars where you can use both petrol and ethanol. Why cannot a similar collaboration be made with fuel efficiency?

how_can_fuel_efficiency_innovation_be_pu.title: How Can Fuel Efficiency Innovation be Put Back on Track?

re_format_existing_intellectual_property.description:
Not enough is being done to speed innovation.

Intellectual property laws need to be reformulated in order to speed innovation and protect innovators and businesses by reducing counterfeiting and encouraging investment in new technologies. Existing patent laws are arcane, complex, time consuming and expensive to undertake. The economy is driven by innovation and change; all major economic surges are tied to new technologies and new paradigms.
re_format_existing_intellectual_property.creator: a93d3a7f5eb97794f7a11aa2fb745587

comments.text: Agree. But we also need to think about crediting innovative ideas moving forward. Creative Commons licenses are cool, but wonder how they actually hold up in court. There have been some innovative licensing schemes that could be a possible solution (I am thinking of the Starbuck's sponsored Betacup challenge for example: http://thebetacup.com/.) Definitely a very important question - and implicates some of the most basic principles of our legal system and even culture.

Along the same lines as this is an interesting Ted talk on the fashion industry http://www.ted.com/talks/lang/eng/johanna_blakley_lessons_from_fashion_s_free_culture.htmlShe touches on how without the copyright laws in the fashion industry innovatin is aided. Rather than within other art forms, sculptors, artists, filmmakers etc. This demonstrates how innovation can work without laws and regulations.

re_format_existing_intellectual_property.title: RE-format existing intellectual property laws.

micro_retail_start_ups_uk.description: Fostering start-ups and showcasing local talent.
micro_retail_start_ups_uk.creator: 0ebfe65ca16ea82675e4294e27747639

comments.text: What a great model for creating venues for local artist markets in a global city.

micro_retail_start_ups_uk.title: Micro-Retail Start-ups (UK)

helping_kids_and_young_adults_gain_confi.description: Kids and young adults who are allowed to hack, break, tear apart, and generally probe the world around them develop an innate sense of courage when it comes time for them to make an impact in the world.
helping_kids_and_young_adults_gain_confi.creator: 078c007bd92ddec308ae2f5115c1775d

comments.text: Cool!  I like the way the conversation thread below is shaping up.

Hi Diego - Your one post on "helping kids and adults gain confidence in their creative abilities" has inspired me to write multiple responses on the issue of creativity.  We learn by doing.  We learn by taking things apart.  Creativity is a process.  
If a group of innovation leaders cannot solve all the world's problems at once - then maybe they can equip the rest of the world to do so - especially all the adults and children in schools - with the creative resources.  
Also, we like to think of learning in categories like school majors or disciplines.  But really, the human mind does not work that way.  This is because we are all creative people.  Creativity is both multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary.  Likewise, empathy can be that way too.  
My recent article is: http://openideo.com/open/what-is-the-global-challenge-that-most-concerns-you-right-now-and-that-global-innovation-leaders-could-begin-to-solve/inspiration/awaken-creativity-in-schools-with-empathy/
I'd be curious to hear what you have to say since you first originated most of my inspirations on Open IDEO on creativity.
By the way, thank you.  :)

This is where education really exists.  Not in theory but in practical application by getting your hands dirty.  You can think about and talk about doing something all day long but until you actually do it, you do not know anything but theory and theory doesn't accomplish anything

People may let students on experiment, failing, etc, since they're kids. The more the person try the more s/he improve his creative ability. Great discussion. It can change the regular teaching on our schools.
Every act of creation is first an act of destruction. - Picasso

Completely agree that it's all about having opportunities to create, experiment, and learn by doing. It's these experiences, not simply learning theory, that expand people's horizons of what's possible. Great visceral video!

helping_kids_and_young_adults_gain_confi.title: Helping kids and young adults gain confidence in their creative abilities

how_can_we_create_a_global_approach_to_p.description:
The oceans are critical to our survival as a species and to life on Earth as we know it. From a human perspective, the developing world gets 40% of its protein from the Sea, we use it for commerce: shipping, for travel, the seas are a potential international security problem and a massive part of the smuggling issue.

There are many policies and ways in which the seas are regulated, but frequently they are ignored and ill-policed. We need a holistic agreement and method for bringing together the different bodies and initiatives to ensure global awareness and protection of the seas.
how_can_we_create_a_global_approach_to_p.creator: d7d03fc4ed767b64ad78b2fdbcd6324c

comments.text: Great concept question Nathan!  So true that the world's oceans are utterly important in so many regards.  And very ill-treated and ill-considered.  And, yes, the laws and treaties you mentioned meant to broadly govern the oceans seem ineffectual at best.  I wonder if one of the main issues to consider in thinking about your question is the method of monitoring.  The ocean areas tend to be so big and the resources available to police them so limited that a lot, evidently, goes on unnoticed.  Or some things at least.  For example we can track the migratory patterns of humpback whales, measure the rate of melting at the polar ice caps and watch from above as hurricanes form.  But we have no idea where the Somali pirates are at any given time or when they will strike valuable freight vessels next.  Or from what land the largest amounts of polluted water and waste material are being dumped into the ocean.Would it be possible to construct an internationally run network of satellites that monitors every single boat on the world's oceans and waterways just as air traffic control systems monitor all flights at all times?  The other big question that I care very much about, as noted in my 'Plastic Bag Problem' concept, is what do we do about the immense amount of trash and pollution already in the water?  The middle of the Pacific ocean is reported to be a swirling galaxy of plastic debris.  And it is only getting worse.  Should a massive clean-up effort be undertaken?  Or can we just leave it and try to do better by polluting less in the future?  Questions, I think, that need to be asked.Anyway, I could go on and on but I am glad you added this concept question to the list.  It is a very important one.  Thanks!
I really like this direction, Nathan.  It is foundational in every sense of the word.

how_can_we_create_a_global_approach_to_p.title: How can we create a global approach to protecting the oceans?

solidarity_2013_in_every_dimension.description:
I think most of the debate and development gets overclouded with fuzzy facts and arguments that to most people can seem irrelevant and timeconsuming. It is too easy for many to disagree with climate change reports and results from actual scientific investigations ( individual conspiracy theorists and large lobby organisations ) to cause confusion and counter info attacks.

We need to put larger emphasis onto solidarity towards all living persons and animals on the globe in this moment, aswell as with all of the future inhabitants on this globe.
If we reduce the focus on the labels: changing climate, greenhouse effect, global warming and so on. We could perhaps get more people onboard the logical reasons and actions that everyone can agree on : dont throw out anything toxic into the nature, dont make nature more dirty and so on...
solidarity_2013_in_every_dimension.creator: 656863f55543ea22d1dbce290f237277
solidarity_2013_in_every_dimension.title: Solidarity – in every dimension

tetra_society_assisstive_devices.description: Tetra is an organization which puts volunteer engineers, creative thinkers, designers, and technicians together with a specific task. The team is given a specific problem from somebody with a disability, whether they used to play a lot of pool and now are unable to, or are having difficulty moving about their home. The team then comes up with a unique solution to their problem usually in the form of a device.
tetra_society_assisstive_devices.creator: 711c99771f3ceed49f77ac8c7c89ac2d

comments.text: It would be fantastic to have those sorts of ideas and solutions accessible to others around the globe.

tetra_society_assisstive_devices.title: Tetra Society - Assisstive Devices

how_can_we_spread_sustainable_practices_.description: We have countries like India and China that are developing so rapidly along conventional Western lines that they also aspire to the same old things, some of which are not so desirable. These are elements such as noisy and polluting cars, heavy air-conditioning, plastics, incorrect dumping of waste, water mismanagement etc. How do we steer emerging societies away from the mistakes of the past and help them leap to more enlightened and sustainable practices, rather than have them waste time, effort, and health in following the same paths seen in the past?
how_can_we_spread_sustainable_practices_.creator: bdb17a3044a511d1a2a6f540615c48c7

comments.text: Good concept. My question with it, however, is if this is not already happening in some places? Really, I think it does, but I am not really sure.
By sharing information and knowledge with our fellow man, all walks of life can flourish.  I evaluated your concept, and I really enjoy it.
http://www.greenbeltmovement.org/ movement in Kenya to solve environmental and social problems. Very effective! Good model to inspire.

Emerging countries of economic wealth look up to developed nations and are highly influenced by them. Developed nations need to set a greater example. Sustainable energy and electric vehicles are not just a concept, they are an economically viable reality. Perhaps we should practice what we preach?
Electric assisted pedal bicycles and electric scooters are hugely popular in China, there are millions of them, why dont they exist to the same extent in developed countries? Perhaps developed countries should try looking up to emerging countries for a change?

Sharing knowledge for assisting Technology Jumps is important. We in Industrialized nations can and must help with that, both as free support, keeping communication open, but also with building commercial joint-ventures so the economy improves mutually and sustainably.

I agree! Because it has to be a win-win situation...the emerging markets will never accept that their economic growth has to suffer just because we in the west decided that it is "time to start saving the planet."
Braskem is an inspiring example. They are a Brazilian chemical company that have started to produce bio plastics. It is not economically competitive with petroleum based plastic yet, however, they argue that a lot of companies with a "green profile" are willing to pay higher prices for bio plastics. Or rather, they are being forced to do so as the option now exists...and eventually the prices should get competitive enough to get more clients interested.
This is a key challenge today...nicely put.

how_can_we_spread_sustainable_practices_.title: How can we spread sustainable practices in emerging societies?

how_can_we_close_the_gap_between_rich_an.description: Last year marked a record high ratio of the gap between the richest and the poorest folk in America. 14.5-to-1 was the ratio for 2009. The US in particular has the highest disparity on the international Gini index, a similar metric, which found U.S. income inequality at its highest level since the Census Bureau began tracking household income in 1967.
how_can_we_close_the_gap_between_rich_an.creator: d7d03fc4ed767b64ad78b2fdbcd6324c

comments.text:
Hi again,
I saw this article in the NYT today and thought of your concept: "Equality: A True Soul Food"http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/02/opinion/02kristof.html?_r=1&bl.
A very relevant read given your ideas above.
Thanks,Ashley

Hi Nathan,
An incredibly important question! What I think is interesting is that often, when presented with a question or challenge like this, my first inclination is to think about how to raise the standard of living for those at the bottom of the economic pyramid (ie: providing the education, tools and training people need to help themselves).
However, if we all can agree that the presence of such drastic income disparity is troubling and needs fixing, then I think it's equally important to think through how those at the very top of the pyramid can distribute and invest their own wealth and resources to help "balance things out". One idea that comes to mind is Warren Buffet and Bill Gates' Giving Pledge (givingpledge.org), where the world's wealthiest have pledged to donate the majority of their fortunes to charity. 
While the Giving Pledge is an example of how philanthropy can be a huge part of the solution, I think we also need to consider other, non-financial resources the wealthy have access to  things like education, professional networks, business savvy, etc. How can the people with these types of resources share what they know and what they have with those who dont? Id love to see the i20 address this.
Thanks,Ashley

Put a financial curriculum in schools centred around creating businesses, knowing a balance sheet and how to read numbers. As well as education in Stocks, Bonds, Investing, Real Estate Investment and how to create a corporation and how to franchise, we give kids the education needed to be employers besides employees. Then we give light to the poor instead of taking from the rich.

Unfortunately, that gap will always exist as long as we live in a monetary economy.  Purchasing power is what it is, power.  
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ksw6TJSrWdo&feature=related
I'm afraid this gap will always exist, you can figure out how to solve the problem if you educate yourself on why it exists to begin with.  I implore you to do so.
The first step towards closing the gap between rich and poor would be for us to really want to close the gap between rich and poor.

comments.text:
Your inspiration immediately reminded me of an article on NPR about a peanut sheller http://n.pr/9cU16V I read a couple of days ago. It's a story about Jock Brandis and his universal nut sheller that started in a country in Africa; it's a very inspirational making-something-out-of-nothing story. I'm looking forward to the documentary, Peanuts.
I wonder if and how the Illac Diaz's peanut sheller is connected to the Brandis' nut sheller... perhaps the peanut-shell-breaking devices are one and the same? The article did mention that Brandis' small-scale peanut shellers are revolutionizing agriculture in 17 different countries so maybe the Philippines is one of those countries, and you mention Diaz had a hand in help design the devices. From a comparison of the machine from the photographs, they look the same. It would be neat to see how the devices are used in different countries. Again, I'm looking forward to the documentary.
Hi Eric. Good call  and maybe some of the solutions are at the grassroots themselves? You inspired me to post about the Honey Bee Network: http://bit.ly/aHRepZ
Sometimes just a bit of appropriate technology can really make a difference!

is_it_possible_to_collectively_forget_te.description: Nuclear weapon technology, even in it's early stages, killed thousands and thousands of people. As well as profoundly polluting the environment.  The technology has since been developed to be even more massively deadly, has been proliferated, stolen and sold to any nation interested in tipping the balance of international power in their favor.  Today nuclear weapons technology is in the hands of many nations, continually threatening to destabilize international relations and tip us into a devastatingly destructive war.  Could it be possible for mankind to put an end to the development and use of this gravely dangerous technology once and for all?
is_it_possible_to_collectively_forget_te.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: Luke, thanks for your comment!  I totally agree, we must not 'forget' in the literal sense of the word.  Too often humanity forgets, or doesn't learn from, the lessons of history. And we end up making the same self-destructive mistakes over and over again.  I think your idea to remember Hiroshima and Nagasaki is an interesting one.  What if an internationally organized day of memorial were established so that all nations paused to remember the victims?  Would such a meditation help us all to think twice before we built more missiles?  Or voted to fund more 'defense' spending?  Would keeping the terrible destruction of those atomic bombs fresh in our collective consciousness give world leaders pause enough to think twice before they sought to build more weapons or made strategic political moves to purposefully escalate tensions?  Yes, you are right, 'forgetting' nuclear weapons must be a willful and continual 'forgetting'.  We have got to make the choice to move beyond grasping the capability of such destruction.  But can we make that choice together?Thanks again Luke!

No. To forget is to surrender the ability to learn. We should dispose of the disgusting things, but never forget. What we need to do is remember Hiroshima and Nagasaki. We need to understand how naive we are to believe that any good can come of having enough nuclear weapons to destroy the entire planet. We need to learn from our mistakes; never ever forget them. Most importantly so future generations don't make these mistakes again.

is_it_possible_to_collectively_forget_te.title: Is it Possible to Collectively 'Forget' Technology For The Good of Mankind?

how_can_we_design_a_clean_system.description: How can we use design to reduce an age-old problem of corruption across different countries and cultures? Corruption breeds in both developed and developing countries although their forms may differ. In developing countries, it may be in the form of a physical bribe; in developed countries, it may be in the form of undue influence by large corporations on political leaders.
how_can_we_design_a_clean_system.creator: af12d67c887430203dd3edf958d321aa

comments.text:
I'd rather see robust systems that overlap traditional political systems.  Medicine Sans Frontieres could not do what they do as a governmental entity.  
That said, I'm sure any human organization includes qualitative influences, that's just the nature of humans.  Reducing influence / corruption to zero should not be a requirement for a system to operate soundly, if it is, you've built a brittle system.
at one level corruption indicates lack of effective leadership. In a well lead society people and organizations identify with their role and take pride in it.

how_can_we_design_a_clean_system.title: How can we design a clean system?

how_do_we_give_hope_to_the_world_s_43.3_.description:
Conflicts and natural disasters have displaced many, many people. In their yearly report, the UNHCR now uses the number of 43.3 million people that have been forced to leave their home. An estimated 30 % of them lives in refugee camps, some of them for decades already. Imagine that you have to live in a refugee camp for most of your life. That the playground in the picture is the only playground your kids know, and will maybe ever see.

Apart from bringing solutions to conflict regions, how can the world bring a bit of hope to the refugees living in camps. Hope for returning home, or for making a real home in a safe place, instead of living in a makeshift temporary place, dependent on aid from others.
how_do_we_give_hope_to_the_world_s_43.3_.creator: 6fed0e6f1ba44f0520bc14fceee3663d

comments.text: There are three durable solutions proposed by UNHCR: firm resettlement (moving to a "third," usually affluent, country; returning home; and living in the country of first asylum. Less than 1% of the world's refugees are resettled, which could be raised. However, even if it were raised, it still couldn't be a solution for most refugees. Further, the culture of the refugees often suffers during resettlement. Countries of first asylum are, by their nature, close to conflict zones, and often can't really absorb the hundreds of thousands of refugees going there (witness Dadaab in Kenya, right near the border of Somalia, which has similar drought issues, and increasing violence). What could be done to then create more favorable conditions post-conflict in countries once a peace has been settled, to attract more people to go home? This often seems to be the solution with the most dignity for the refugees themselves. Could this include microfinance projects with an additional piece, like civic education? Or with mentoring built into the model? Or whatever is most a challenge in that particular area, like in an area like South Sudan, a condition for microcredit loans is to participation in a regular forum on ways to increase education rates?
Great discussion. Thanks for posting this, Arjan!

My (offline) friend urges me to emphasize that when refugees gain skills of such value to the greater community, they are much more likely to be able to make a permanent home in a new place, and be missed by their home communities, raising their chance of return.

When I see numbers like 43.3 million displaced persons, I think about the huge potential for positive change worldwide of that many people. I realize that problems facing refugees and other displaced persons are many and intense, yet displaced persons have made immense contributions to society and cultures where they have settled in previous generations. What if some of today's refugees could enter the global marketplace as sought after technical workers, skilled labor and consultants in crisis management and disaster relief?

Hi Kara and Sabra,Thanks for the link and the support for the topic. My sister works with asylum seekers and we recently had a discussion about it. She reminded me that there are so many people living in camps without the hope of returning any time soon. All the efforts to make their lives a bit more normal are good, I think. But the best thing is to give them hope.

Great topic to address, Arjan. This project is one I appreciate as something that temporarily responds to the desire for home but it is by no means a complete answer: http://www.core77.com/blog/materials/design_for_the_displaced_using_textiles_to_create_a_home_16037.asp(which is why I think your suggestion of this topic is appropriate and relevant).
Nice, Sabra, I like that idea.

If we could somehow provide education and resources for at least some of the refugees in appropriate tech and related sustainable livelihood and public health skills, then they could become the seed for transforming refugee camps worldwide into Research and Development centers for solving problems of displaced people.Teach people in one camp to begin with, each camp gets help to teach 3 other camps. http://www.sarvodaya.org/ for a well proven model of how to do this with villages in Sri Lanka

how_do_we_give_hope_to_the_world_s_43.3_.title: How do we give hope to the world's 43.3 million people that are forcibly displaced

how_do_we_speed_up_renewable_energy_inno.description: Most governments and industry refuse to see the long-term environmental benefit of leaving fossil fuels and turning to clean renewable energy sources.  The decision still remains an economic one.  It continues to generally be cheaper to burn coal and oil for power than to rely on clean energy sources such as solar and wind.  How can we improve the speed of innovation in research and development in clean energy technology so that it's cost can be reduced enough to compete directly with traditional fossil fuels?
how_do_we_speed_up_renewable_energy_inno.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: Hey everyone.  Thanks for joining in on the conversation!  Here is a beautiful infographic on U.S. energy subsidies that is great for what I want to address with this topic. http://tinyurl.com/3x3hcqu  Thanks to @sallymadsen for directing me to it!

Pablo, thanks for the comment!  Very well stated!  I think the thing that no one talks about is how massive the sea-change will necessarily have to be as the world shifts it's economic and political momentum based on fossil fuels to that of one geared more and more toward clean renewable energy.  Probably because no one wants to talk about how painful or what a upheaval it will be.  But it has to be done.  And the sooner it happens the better.  We just need a coalition of strong leaders that have the guts to do the right thing to move the world's economy away from oil and coal and toward renewable energy.  Otherwise the massive upheaval will find us when the climate, affected by global warming, changes countries environments and landscapes for the worse.  Or when the world's oil supply is depleted and prices skyrocket, tipping the market scales and crippling economies.  You are correct in that there will be challenges.  But they have to be faced.  And soon.Thanks again for the comment and thanks for the link to the book.  I will definitely check it out!

Rene, thanks for your comment!  I think the key to what both you and Johan are talking about is incentives.  Startup companies need to have incentive to innovate in the green technology space. As you mention, competitions are one way to do this.  Another way would be for governments to make the business climate favorable for the incorporation of new energy solutions with research funding and subsidies.  Unfortunately it seems that the current political and economic climate, in the U.S. at least, favors big oil companies and traditional fossil fuels.Johan's comment about getting people to band together and demand cleaner energy from their leaders and energy suppliers is a good idea too.  But it is also about incentive.  My guess is that most consumers tend to take the path of least resistance.  Using the energy that is already being supplied to their homes is much easier than joining a campaign to demand for cleaner energy sources.  But maybe if they were given enough incentive that might change.  This is one of the keys to the issue I think.  Whether is it pricing of fossil fuels that hurts their wallets more than renewable alternatives, seeing evidence of environmental damage that directly affects their lives, or whatever, there will need to be a trigger that catches consumer's attention, ignites their imagination and fuels their passion to bring about change for the better.  Otherwise they will continue to simply watch TV. :)Thanks again for your comments!

All of these are good questions. The energy problem is a complex and 'wicked' one. Change will require a well designed transition towards a global socioeconomic system that incentivizes cleantech research and development, while more efficiently using existing ones, reducing our dependence on fossil fuels and clearly communicating the public the main challenges. Dont miss this one Demian: http://amzn.to/ez27Ch

Rene: we do not really need to change innovation systems. The old market concepts of supply and demand will work just fine (if it is not unlawfully tampered with). If company that build renewable generated power plants gets customers, if more customers will find this company: it will pay for the investments. If more customers can find out they want specifically renewable = the price will go down, and more income for the company to enlarge capacity.
This is not very difficult, and not at all a political or systematic change. It is up to the consumers to phone 10 friends to make them all collectively phone and beg for renewables from their utility company and their elected representatives and make them raise emission tax on fossil fuels and carbon emissions.
Organize a large chain of consumers linked together until you reach number of "critical mass" will make difference! Just spread the word! And act together!
There is also possibility in some places for customers to buy shares of start-up-wind-power-plants!

Hi! This a very interesting debate, so I would like to add something, as Demian and and Johan says, theres a lot of fancy innovation, the problem is in changing the behavior to make the green innovations be adopted by many people. Then we really need to do two things remake the innovation systems of a country so they send back the bad innovations to drawing board and the other is to give priority to combination of innovations that can be adopted by users faster, one tool to do it can be a competition for best green startups for example, most of the innovations are often technology based, the technology can solve the problems elegantly, but if there is no channel commercialize or spread it in a good manner then its no use! Social innovation equally important as the technology for adoption behavior.

Thanks for the comment Johan!  I agree with you, and others, that lots of application is needed in the energy industry.  But I think that there is a motivation problem hindering this process.  The use of oil and other fossil fuels for power continues to be just too 'cheap' for anyone to be motivated to make any application initiatives.  The economics get in the way of real change.  Of course we all know that this is an artificial economic situation made possible by massive government subsidies and tax breaks.So maybe the major innovation that needs to take place is not in the clean energy technology itself but in the legislative process and the influential relationships maintained between politicians and the big oil companies.  The big question to me is how can politicians be convinced, or pushed, to reduce the ridiculously huge amount of  subsidies they give to oil and fossil fuel companies that keep the price of fuel artificially low?  Sure it may keep voters happy in the short term, but this system hinders, as you mention, advances in application of clean energy technology as well as continue us further down the path of polluting our environment.A huge paradigm shift needs to take place in not only how the world thinks about energy and how we use it, but also in how we fund it.  It might be painful to go through but this change has to happen and it has to happen soon.Thanks again Johan!

Existing versions of technology is extremely innovative and evolved already!As someone said in another place on OpenIDEO:"Enough innovation, get into application!!!"Apply all the fancy tech to use the stuff in practice! Change bad practice into cleaner practice, in daily use, for many people at the same time!!!
Solar panels would only need to use 0,1% of all the sun rays falling on us and we would have much more electricity than we could spend, and distribute it for all 7 billions!!! the wind is constantly blowing on the oceans... (actually the wind is caused by the sun heating us)
Consider the oil prices has risen and is almost at 100$ again! Clean energy is cheaper in the long-term!
U.S.A's subsidies on petrol for automobils are higher and more costly than any subsidies on solar or wind power industry!
The attitudes and behaviours that say that it costs too much to save electricity or fuel is sick! (they must be a product of massive advertising from big corporate america?)Remember that ol' president saying : a penny saved is a penny earned??? :D
We need to make technology jumps, and quicker than before! so we need to put all the existing tech into clever use on a large scale now!Applied to human beings real life will make us use and see what will work and what will not. We can seed out poorly constructed machines and methods by using them. And in that way develop the good innovations more, and to send back bad innovations to the drawing board to be reworked or redesigned.
as always: thanks for your inspiration and writing!!!

comments.text: Congratulations Nicole on being on the agenda!!!Well done

For anyone interested in why I think we need to build government capacity through private partnership models instead of circumventing it, see my recent blog post: http://nicoleskibolaesq.wordpress.com/2010/12/01/market-trust-why-governments-still-matter/
Another example for successful educational public-private partnerships is an NGO called NCCEP: http://bit.ly/bZzDRu.
Nice on Aturo. Another successful example of a university collaborating in a public-private partnership  in the area of urban transport solutions  is with Janmarg in India: http://bit.ly/eNll7Q
Thanks Arturo. I'll try with google translate. And otherwise, a Mexican friend is visiting us soon, so he might be able to help :)

Of course Arjan, I have a link where you can find more information, but unfortunately it is all in Spanish. I'd be happy to help you find more information on this and to translate it to English.
http://www.itesm.mx/incubadorasocial/isdesc.htm

Arturo, I think that is a great example, the incubators ITESM. Maybe you should add it as a concept or an inspiration, if you haven't already. Do you have a link to more info?I agree with some online space, but don't forget the value of real life spaces. Like the incubator you mentioned. That's very valuable.

I think that initiatives like these are not only self sustainable, but also promote community engagement. It induces a good clean image of the company that cares about the community, and improves people's perception of the government, in communities that really need support. In my humble point of view, I think that involving Universities would be a great plus to these kinds of projects. In Mexico's Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education (ITESM), Social Incubators have been estabilshed. In these social incubators, not only monetary support is given, but also entrepreneurial coaching for small businesses, and different activities that promote community engagement that aim to make these communities a better place. I think that with the help of the government, the private sector, and Universities, the help can be significantly increased. To keep this on the loop, I think that we are looking into the information era, and there should be a space (web 2.0 perhaps) where interaction and collaboration takes place for these entities, and deliver positive results combined with commitment by all parties to keep the relationship in the long term. My grain of salt, I hope I'm not too off.
Ya, that's the real challenge. Throw corruption in there and it's a real doozy.

Nicole, great. That is the thing I would be looking for. That would be a great question indeed, to find that continuous information/feedback loop for evolving governments and society. Thanks for your patience and insight!

I totally agree with you Arjan. Totally. However, for a sustainable long term functioning societies, governments have to work. I see it as a big feedback loop. Social entrepreneur does his thing, there is an exchange of information with the government, government then adapts to make the regulatory and policy environment friendlier for future social entrepreneurs, then with the better environment, there is more innovation, and so on. The problem with many developing societies is that there is no regulation in place for new industries and ideas (hey, it happens in the US even, all the time with constant advances in technology) or the government does not have the resources to enforce regulations. So, for me, as a policy person, the greater question becomes, how can we make this a continuous information loop so that governments can evolve as societies evolve?
Good discussion guys! Arjan  perhaps you can pose a fresh question in Agenda Concepts which includes the scope of partnerships you envisage?

@Nicole: I just think that sometimes social entrepreneurs, maybe supported by regular businesses, are more efficient in getting things done than governments can ever be. In my humble opinion, governments are most effective if they are facilitating that by making sure proper regulation is in place, and enforced.

A significant suggestion, Nicole.  We've definitely seen this on the rise with organizations like WRI.  USAID too is invested in such an approach in certain countries.  Solely for the purposes of tickling your brain, I would like to encourage you to look at Adam Smith's first book "Theory of Moral Sentiments" that correlates with your suggestion.

I think that the government plays a very important role and I don't mean to sound like I am suggesting the government be completely bypassed. Involving governments is crucial for democratic institution development, but often times governments don't have the capacity to provide many basic services - like water or sanitation for example. I see the government as more of a third partner than a guide (unfortunately). I think a key part of these projects should be to work with governments to make sure they build capacity to function without the private partner over time.

You're absolutely right that moving away from charity to more sustainable solutions is important. However, if I understand the term public-private partnerships correctly, it might be too limited. There are already many examples of how companies, individuals and social enterprises are acting together, without governments as direct partners. In some cases, the role of the government could be just to enable and to create a fair and level playing field. Wouldn't that be private-private partnerships?Anyway, applauded this concept just as well. I think this is the best way to create more equal opportunities around the globe.
Great call, Nicole!
Particularly like your encouragement to move from charity to co-creation and partnerships here. More empowering not to mention economically sustainable.

how_can_we_create_effective_and_meaningf.title: How can we create effective public-private partnerships?

how_do_we_quickly_transform_our_thinking.description:
"The significant problems we face cannot be solved at the same level of thinking we were at when we created them."  Albert Einstein

The end of poverty, global warming and conflicts cannot come soon enough for the thousands who suffer daily from these events.  We don’t need to wait for a global crisis to get so bad that we are forced into finding solutions. We can address the source issue now.  I assert the source issue is the individual mindsets held by a large number of people, often innocently unaware (I was one).  People’s mindsets form a collective perspective that keep alive man-made issues that cause suffering, take lives, and threaten the planet.

comments.text:
Hello Mike, today I saw this video-research twitted by Gary Huswitt and it reminded me your concept. "People tend to sit where there are places to sit."
The Social Life of Small Urban Spaces: http://vimeo.com/5298850

Governments building and investing in public space is becoming rarer.  Democracies need public spaces that are free, where loitering is not only allowed but encouraged, where large and small meetings can be held spontaneously. This is a question of the trust worthiness of local law enforcement, and the commitment of governments to invest financially in projects whose benefits are "softer" and more difficult to quantify than schools and hospitals... Yet, when you look for meaningful spaces, we use qualitative measures rather than quantitative.  The issue beneath this is perhaps how to define appropriate qualitative values so that they can, at times, succeed over the more precise quantitative (financial) values .

Indeed Mike! I'm also exploring this idea with my Agenda Concept: Innovating *With, Not For* Communities http://bit.ly/ggQpo4 And it was great to see a number of Inspiration posts which pointed to global examples of initiatives which pursue such notions.
