comments.text:
Hi Andrenna,
(This a long post, I hope you can bear with me...I wanted to see what you think of my grant idea, so I explained it.)
You have made my Monday special.  Thanks so much for your warm comments about my post, on your post.  Like you, I believe and see, how inter-related "we" are with nature, "I" is not "we" and "we" are part of the much bigger picture of nature.  
We blink, everything blinks, each action has a corresponding reaction, good or bad. The false fragmentation has allowed "us" to do things we would never do if "we" really understood the relationship and how harm to nature is directly related to harm to ourselves.  If floors me how obvious this is, but, at the same time, does not serve the larger perspective of un-linking, in order to remove ourselves, from responsibility and the relationship' we need to live and survive.
The grant idea:
I have been independently and very consciously, taken Obama's Open Government (OGD) Directive, as a concrete vehicle, for thinking through something which can be done now, to actually make a sustainable difference.  (I have tons of experience with grants).
The basic premise is taking an already existing, powerful system, federal grants, which operates in an outmoded, counter-productive system.  I want to re-design this system, to be totally congruent. A majority of Congressional allocations, for programs, goes through the grant system (outside of federal contracts).
The OGD requires each federal agency to consciously plan for collaboration, citizen participation, transparency and accountability.  Consciously the principle of transparency and data, has been inextricably linked to the use of technology, which make obvious sense.
There is an equal push to include citizen participation, collaboration and other sub-sets of the directive, to be addressed through the use of technology.  I do not agree. Technology is not the answer for everything.  The human factor is essential and basic to our human nature.  Not very different from what you are talking about with community, connection and relationships.
As a starting point, I do not assume anything.  Success, in my model, is directly linked to capacity building, seemless integration of the primary principles (in the background of the grant design), and an open system for continuous improvement, failure analysis and evaluation. 
We can take any federal grant program, the focus doesn't matter.  I made one up called "Read for America", to illustrate the idea easily.  Starting with the conception of the RFP (request for proposal) development, I would teach grant managers about the directive and make sure the primary principles of collaboration, etc. were written and built into the grant application process.  
If the grant focus is: "all student's in America will read proficiently by age 10" (there are a lot of reasons why, which I will not go into now), we want applicants to write up what they will do to make that goal come to life. At the same time, they have to clearly explain how they will be transparent, collaborative, encourage citizen participation and accountable throughout.
Moving through grant conception to the application phase, I would set up temporary sites, in all 50 states, for grant applicants to receive training and technical assistance in federal grants. Our goal is increasing their chances of being successful applicants.  
Naturally, this training would include all aspects of the OGD.  Currently non-profits and community groups are at a tremendous disadvantage in federal grant applications, almost set up to fail, unless they have the resources to hire specialists, including evaluator's.  Some of this is equally true for philanthropy.
We would remedy this by balancing the playing field, offer capacity building workshops, at these sites and online, everyone would have a chance at doing their best, not guessing what the feds want.  
As we move through the grant-making process, we would make sure everyone  is educated and informed, while building understanding, capacity, connection, participation and communication.  The OGD in action. Any issues will emerge faster and reliance on each part of the whole becomes ever more apparent.
Everyone who comes into this system, at any point, is always left off better than before, always.
Applications are sent in and evaluated against clearly understood expectations.  While not everyone "wins" the grant dollars, everyone involved is getting smarter about change, innovation and what the OGD concepts really mean. Already this is a huge step in the entire system.
Our grant "winners" will be connected to a social/grant closed network.  Currently this does not happen, each grantee is on their own, by themselves, with a grant manager who has many grants to monitor.  
Currently, South Dakota has no idea what is happening in Washington, or California or Alaska and on and on, unless they attend very expensive meetings once in awhile in DC. 
We would use technology to connect grantees from the beginning. They would share ideas, problems, solutions, etc.  All grantee's would get to know each other, just as they do on Facebook now.  
The OGD in action again, using multiple systems, including state and local systems, for success, saving a ton of money and increasing the likelihood of great results across the country.  This would also build up our best practices catalog, be much more accountable and go beyond current limitations. The potential is limitless, something we can implement within a year, and can begin using a demonstration type of grant process.
This is a very basic outline of my idea.  Love any feedback.  Thanks for being so encouraging.
Happy New Year to You Too!Andrea

Andrea, thank you for your post. You have a very bright and positive personality that comes through your writing. It's got me all excited and inspired and hopeful. :)
I agree about taking small mindful acts of engagement with our surroundings (people/environment/etc.) as an open and adventurous every day challenge. It would be wonderful to compile a source-page of existing models (and models that could exist) that create this type of action and awareness.
Bringing this perspective into systems, like grant-making as you mentioned, would be a wonderfully productive step, and a step that would potentially ripple in all sorts of amazing ways. Healthy relationships are key. 
Thank you for taking the time to post such an incredibly knowledgable and thoughtful post to this OpenIDEO concept, Andrea. Wishing you a very happy and healthy New Year!Take care.

I have done a lot of professional work in law enforcement, particularly community policing.  A key idea in that paradigm is you don't usually shoot people you know.  Of course I realize that we've seen the ugliest examples of families and friends killing each other all over the world.  Still, I like the idea of person to person, neighbor to neighbor, community to community and so on.
Your concept reminds me of just how important it is to encourage this sense of belonging and accountability to each other every day.I do think it's possible to consciously create models which will encourage what you are talking about.  
When I evaluated all the innovative community policing grants under the Clinton Administration, I came away with incredible examples of this all over the country.  I thought I found a great American story.  I was amazed at the ideas being implemented through our grants (most of them anyway), and think we can construct our grant making system, as well as other systems, to purposefully build in what you are talking about.  Not just through technology, but in everyday people to people contact and relationships, including organizational.Thanks for posting this so thoughtfully.

I evaluated and applauded your concept, and I really like where your hearts at.. but I think you'd be really interested to see where my head's at and maybe we could really work together on making this a reality!  I think the best way to bring about awareness of our very nature-bound way of life is to apply the scientific method to society where decisions are arrived at, rather than disputed over.
To make this a reality, we have to remind humans of their ties to nature and it's absolute authority over the survival of our planet.  Although many argue that your concept has no clear opportunities from it, I feel that it could really bring people together on Earth.  If I could build on this concept of yours, I certainly would.
I am new to the site and didn`t read everything before posting my ideas. If I had I wouldn`t built on yours. Your ideas were more generic and wholesome than the ones I posted. Nice work ...

A quick story about the photo uploaded for this concept:
This monument overlooks the Unalakeet River valley in northwest Alaska. Some monuments are believed to be landmarks, used for centuries to help travelers gather their geographic bearings and orientation. My favorite interpretation, though, is that some monuments are believed to be sculptures of thanks; each stone carried and carefully placed as a gesture of gratitude -- for survival, blessings, and the gifts that our earth provides for us.

You're right, Julian, the "hippie" concept can be distracting.
I think  it's our job, as designers, to curate opportunities for new perspectives.We can choose the lenses that help us best perceive this concept of "one" and "connectedness" by focusing on our concept through trusted lenses of science, history, and world cultures. The "hippie" perspective is just one view we see through a lens of our not-so-distant history...and it's a lens many may choose to look through unless we offer them other options.
Thanks so much for your post, it poses a very important and interesting consideration on how we might begin to approach this concept with openness and universal understanding.

Hi Andreanna, this is really a case of answering the root cause of our current environmental issues  which is brilliant, and like the other comments, its v. elegantly proposed. The challenge is in penetrating the public consciousness when the idea that we all connect is perceived as a hippie concept.
Thank you for your thoughtful comment, Rich. I couldn't agree more. Looking forward to reading your posts and contributions.
Thank you, James, for your comment. Empathy is totally where it's at! I enjoyed reading through your posts...especially the one on giving.

I really like the elegant way you have stated this problem. It hits on so many areas where difference leads people to negative, damaging and event violent outcomes. Country borders, ethnicity, religion all help us focus on where we are not the same and history is filled with places where those ideas (or ideals) lead to separation and aggression. 
Innovation on your idea could really help bring about change in a fundamental way that can help address other problems listed in this Challenge - each one being really important in it's own right.
Andrenna Your concept relates to mine nicely and I thought you deserve a round of applause for it. Empathy is where it is at.
Vincent, thank you for your thoughtful comment!It's people like you who help make collaboration productive and an inspiring venture.Take care.
Beautifully put Andrenna. This infuses direction and meaning not just into innovation, but also into our lives.

how_do_we_rekindle_universal_awareness_o.title: How do we rekindle universal awareness of our interconnection with one another and our shared natural environment?

can_global_health_efforts_better_utilize.description: Many more people in the developing world have a cell phone than have access to health care or proper sanitation.  Can this widespread use and availability of cell phones be utilized by Global Health organizations to care for the world's under-served populations?
can_global_health_efforts_better_utilize.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: Thanks for the comment Sanjay!  Both of your ideas would be very useful.In addition to incoming informational texts maybe there could also be a United Nations, World Health Organization or Medecins Sans Frontiers menu built into the mobile phone's system which would let users select from a list written in their own language of direct-dial buttons or phone-based forms for such things as reporting medical supply shortages, individual illness symptoms, illness outbreak in a family or village, medication counterfeiting, etc.  Phones having cameras could also take a photo of the topic, such as the medical supply item that is running low, the skin rash symptom or the condition of the local sanitation infrastructure, etc.  The user could then send these photos free of charge to the Global health authority as not only a way of authenticating the claim but also of aiding in data collection that would be beneficial to effectively and efficiently treating the collective health of that country or area.Lots of opportunities there.Thanks again for your comment Sanjay!

Dates of next heath camps could be disseminated to cell phone users in catchment areas so that health status of populations can be better ascertained.A neighborhood watch scheme for epidemic diseases can be created if people report symptoms of the epidemic or conditions favouring it.

can_global_health_efforts_better_utilize.title: Can Global Health Efforts Better Utilize Available Technology?

get_rid_of_plastic_bags.description: Plastic bags are a huge waste and a huge polluter of our oceans.  Some cities have heavily taxed them or banned them outright.  They should be commended and followed.
get_rid_of_plastic_bags.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: Arjan, thanks for the comment!  I agree that sometimes plastic is the most practical, especially for handling raw meat, etc. But the impractical use of plastic is also rampant and widely accepted.  For example I regularly see people buy one can of soda at a corner store, the clerk puts the can in a plastic bag, the person carries the plastic bag out onto the sidewalk, pulls out the can of soda, opens it and throws the plastic bag into the trash bin.  The plastic bag spends less than one minute in actual use.  And then hundreds of years in a landfill.  So terrible.  And both the person buying the soda and the clerk don't think twice about it.Either public opinion about the use of plastic bags has to change or public policy has to change.  The person buying the soda could have refused the plastic bag knowing that it was not needed.  Alternatively, if plastic bags were banned there would be none for the clerk to offer, and therefore none to quickly throw away.  My bet would be that neither the buyer nor the clerk would miss them.  Another option would be to charge for a plastic bag, making the option available for someone with several items to carry but forcing the buyer to think twice about its use.I think that a look back at history might be useful in thinking about alternatives to plastic use.  What did people do to carry things before the invention of plastic bags?  Or plastic in general for that matter?  Surely they figured something out :)  Maybe a discussion for another post but definitely something to think about.Thanks again for your comment!

It's indeed amazing to see the amount of plastic bags used. Also here in Latvia, but don't forget places in the developing world. There's also a practical side to plastic, especially when using them as packaging for fresh food. Not only vegetables, but think of fish and meat as well. The fluids in those will leak through paper. I think that to find a good way to reduce use of plastic bags, we also need to look at an alternative in practicality. Many people have economics and practicality as main drivers.

Meena, Thanks for the comment and the link!  A very interesting idea to reuse and re-purpose newspaper for farmer's market vegetable packaging.  Making it visually fun and marketable by simply adding a bit of patternated color. I wonder if this formula could be used for other recyclables or natural fibers such as burlap sacks...Thanks again Meena!

James, thanks for the comment!  And Johan for the 'rebuttal':)!  Interesting points to think about on both sides.  Beyond the data, though, one might make the argument that just because something is cheaper isn't necessarily reason enough to allow it.  Sometimes the right thing to do is the harder, more costly, thing to do.  And really, it may be that as our oceans and landfills continue to get choked with discarded plastics, the true costs of reckless plastic usage are yet to come.Both of you end with a great point, that a reusable bag on everyone's shoulder is the way to go and a goal we can all work toward.  Thanks again James and Johan for your comments!

Anne, Thanks for the comment and link! Chris Jordan is all over the issue!  And quite the crocheter! I agree that, in general, Europe seems a little more measured about its plastic bag consumption.  But I did notice, when living in London, that some products in the UK are overly packaged - more so than in the US.  Single serve bags of chips (crisps) redundantly packaged in larger bags, vegetables that would otherwise be fine on their own packaged in plastic trays and then wrapped in plastic, etc.  Not only we as consumers need to get away from the mindless consumption and use of plastic bags but also manufacturers need to strive to minimize the amount of wasteful packaging that is used - and then promptly thrown away.  Thanks again for the comment!
Speaking of existing innovations in this area  here's a cute little one from Japan: http://bit.ly/bl0dMh What other examples of current initiatives do we know of that speak to this issue?

Good discussion here, with input from many countries. I would like to comment on James "paper-bags little extra transport" : The upside of paper bags is that raw material is trees and other growing plants. That is more abundant than oil. Paper bags can carry more weight than comparable plastic bag of same size. And paper fibres that gets into proper recycling can be reshaped up to 10-12 times without degrading quality. (And if you mix together different stages of recycled paper fibre, even more times) And the water and energy use for making new paper out of recycled fibres is smaller than making new paper from raw materials. Remaking plastic bags out of recycled plastics are almost exacly same energy-use (as making bags from raw plastic material)Plus : a Paper bag thrown into a forest or side of the road will compost itself!!!So a total profit if you calculate cradle-to-cradle.And of course an even much larger profit if you bring your own textile bags to the shop!

One important point, the amount of saving in making a paper-bags system over a plastic bags system is lost when you add up the extra transport it takes to carry paper bags verses plastic bags that are far more condensed. I can't remember where I saw it, but one article somewhere described how plastic bags were better for the environment than paper ones for the reason of transport.
What I do like is the encouragement of bags that are not throw-away. Ireland has had the plastic bag tax for some time, AND...does a good job at encouraging heavier bags that can be used multiple times.....

Nicole, thanks for the comment!  I remember being a student living in Italy in 1992 and thinking that paying for a bag at the grocery store was ridiculous.  How short-sighted I was!  What seemed arcane was actually further ahead than the US mindset at the time.  There is nothing like economics to push us to rethink our presuppositions!  Thanks again for the comment!

Lena, Thanks for the comment!  I agree!  One small trip to the grocery store can easily produce ten used plastic bags when counting the ones used to purchase vegetables.  So if we do some math... if every person goes to the grocery store once a week and ends up with ten used plastic bags... after a year they have used over 500 plastic bags.  Do these 500 bags get recycled?  Or end up in the trash?  And possibly the ocean?  Now multiply that by the billions of people on Earth right now.  That is a lot of plastic bags.  It is painfully obvious that these numbers cannot go on.  So let's figure out how to change people's minds about plastic bag use!  Thanks again for your comment!

Samantha, Thanks for the comment!  I love the idea of re-use in the utilization of discarded paper or newsprint folded to make a paper bag.  Pragmatic brilliance that is never seen in the U.S.  The trick would be in making the practice socially acceptable so that it becomes widely used.You also have a good point about promoting bags made from jute.  I bet corn stalk fibers could be a locally sourced fiber in the US to take advantage of.Maybe the main objective of this is just changing the world-wide perception that the thing that is used to place your just-purchased items in should be either a reusable bag you bring from home or a fibrous bag made from vegetal bi-products.  Not a synthetically produced plastic bag that spends five minutes in actual use and then 500 years in a land fill or floating at sea.Thanks again for the comment!

Photographer Chris Jordan is passionate about the issue and has an entire site devoted to it: http://bagsbegone.com/
I find in Europe that people tend to be better about plastic/reusable bags. However, it's at the market where vendors seem to like to bag everything, and each vegetable separately that creates even more waste, and excess baggies. (Some vendors use paper sleeves as a solution).

San Francisco passed a measure to do this a couple of years ago. There were a couple of loopholes, but it would be interesting to see how the ordinance has fared. I think its really just a matter of incentives. I have always been a fan of the European charging for bags model, where people are forced to bring their own bags (and they actually do). The Betacup challenge (http://www.thebetacup.com/) sponsored by Starbucks attempted to do this last year in re-inventing the way we use coffee cups. The project has met with mixed success, but great idea nonetheless to get people re-thinking old ways of consumption.

Not only plastic bags, reduce plastice where ever possible. And get it out of our oceans, keep it away from our new born. Give people a better chance to shop food without creating an "mountain of plastice waste".

This is a movement which already has some steam and it would be great to see it spread further.  I live and work in Bangladesh where plastic bags are banned.   They can only be used by exporters and are not freely available to buy.   Everyone takes their own bag with them when they go shopping.  If you buy some apples or something from the market then the paper bag is a very simple recycled affair - generally a piece of paper with someones school test on which has been folded and made into a bag.   Always have to remember to shred your private papers here before throwing them out!Also in Kuala Lumpur we noticed that every weekend there is 'no plastic bag' days when you have to bring your own shopping bag with you.It would be great if you could tie this initiative in with the sale of bags made from jute or other natural fibres or recycled material and sourced from workers co-operatives in the developing world.   Hand made jute bags reduce the need for plastic bags and can create valuable employment in the developing world.

get_rid_of_plastic_bags.title: Get Rid of Plastic Bags!

how_do_we_address_the_global_plastic_pro.description: Roughly 1 million plastic bags are used globally every minute.  Which adds up to between 500 billion and 1 trillion plastic bags used and thrown away worldwide every year.  The U.S. alone throws away 2.5 million plastic bottles every hour.  Plastic may be recyclable but the vast majority of it ends up in landfills and the ocean where it can take up to 1,000 years to degrade, remaining toxic even after it breaks down.
how_do_we_address_the_global_plastic_pro.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: There is a concept over in the sanitation that suggests turning plastic waste into plastic lumber. That's already happening in some places in the U.S.There is room for a lot of " wood replacements" in the world right now. We need every tree we can make room for to make oxygen and bind carbon. I don't know about the pollution potential of this, and how it compares to the existing plastic pollution.

Rob, Thanks for the comment and the link!  I do not know about Plastic to Oil but the process looks interesting.  My first question would be about how much pollution is produced by the process.  But, yes, what to do with the immense amount of plastic waste is a huge problem.  We should also not forget to think about the public's casual attitude toward plastic and plastic waste.  If we can change our culture's perception of plastic as a viable material, help people to understand the damage that is being done by producing so much plastic in the first place and change our daily habits around plastic use, we might be able to stem the tide of incoming plastic waste that is polluting our oceans and air.  And then hopefully not be in such need of technologies such as this Plastic to Oil process.  But as it stands now, it is a good thing that this technology has been developed.  Thanks again for the comment!
Processes like http://www.plastic2oil.com/ could make a difference; we'll be using oil in the near future anyway, and it could save a lot of landfill space.  Just a piece of the puzzle.

Meena, Thanks for the comment!  And thanks for the link!  Some great ideas in there.  Maybe the question is to take some of those ideas and to develop them to be implemented on a global scale.  Is it achievable?  I think it could be.  How to get every government to agree is probably the toughest part.Thanks again for your comment!
Thought you might be interested in GOOD Magazine's favourite innovations for plastic consumer waste: http://bit.ly/gz7CgI

I grew up in the United States school system - first attending private Catholic school education, then went on to college to graduate from a top UC.  Watching this video actually enrages me because it hits too close to home…
the_creativity_crisis_part_2.creator: 8757541db3a21588d7952dbb8fb5fe29

comments.text: My Brazilian friend had sent me this video last week and now I'm seeing it everywhere! Honestly growing up with an ADHD brother made me realize that he shouldn't be taking those medications to fit into the education paradigm, but rather the education paradigm needs to flex and adapt to accommodate his different learning styles. You put him in front of an English novel and ask him to do read it you won't get any results, but you animatedly recite a paragraph from that book and he will remember it for the rest of his life. This innovation needs to be applied from the curriculum to discipline to the interior environment of the school, and it needs to create room for change and flexibility as new students with new needs begin to study every year.

Thank you Open IDEO for the link to barefootcollege.org.  Very interesting to read an approach on empowering creativity as a resource for the physcially challenged in rural communities in India.  This inspires me to post yet another article on the creative crisis - stay tuned...  =D
We love this video Kristine! Can folks think of global education initiatives that are enabling creative thinkers? One that comes to mind is the Barefoot College from India: http://bit.ly/amxy0r

comments.text:
This is definitely very interesting, it's good to see how they are attempting to get the greater public more involved with the system, rather than just with a simple election. 
Rachel makes a good point about how easily this could become complicated though. But with some care I'm sure it could be done correctly.

I think this is interesting - it picks up on the idea of participatory design.  I would worry that if it's not done properly that it could be complicated for the average citizen who's not well versed in local policies - heck, the American system of politics is confusing enough for the folks who live here.   But it's an interesting idea, and I think if we matched up sister cities or similarly matched areas (by population etc.) it could be worth exploring.  It would also be an interesting way for innovations to occur since the citizens involved in the community might be able to see linkages and create new ideas from being involved since they're not the usual stakeholders in policy development.

Nice one Jeremy! 
What other novel, existing ways do we know of that address urban transportation issues from around the globe? Post an example from your city as an Inspiration.

How convenient! Why isn't there something like this in the Bay Area?  Based on my personal experience with the SF/Bay Area public transportation system, I would give the cycle hire scheme a try if these stations existed nearby BART and Caltrain stations.

Yes, I like these type of schemes. In Paris I regularly used the Velib' and here in Riga there is a similar scheme as well. Now I don't use it that much, because I have my own bike again, but still. Also interesting, a company in Lithuania (teo.lt) has their company bikes, which they promote for use in stead of cars when the weather allows for it.

how_to_end_war_poverty_disease_and_corru.description:
Prepare yourself with this question: How would I "rebuild the world" to be environmentally sound, crops to be plentiful, homes to be available, disease to be eradicated?

It should come to no surprise that the issues we faced hundreds of years ago still exist today, considering we use a very traditional approach to dealing with them.  Our efforts should be ever changing to meet the ever changing troubles we, as a species, have faced.   My question to you is why haven't the worlds leaders given resource based economics a chance?  Many forms of literature are available to anyone interested in making this a reality.  Only looking through our proposal with an objective approach will you successfully collaborate into making this either (in your eyes) more realistic or more plausible.   Be aware that over a half a million members of The Zeitgeist Movement are already up in arms to make this plan a reality.  What say you?
how_to_end_war_poverty_disease_and_corru.creator: 420d33a849897c740de99421ef8a6ce7

comments.text: As I have stumbled upon this topic and website in general only today, I understand that the topics expressed here are old, but nevertheless I will try to answer some of the questions that were presented in the comments as the issues are still valid and the Zeitgeist Movement as well as the Venus Project are still functioning.@Demian: You are absolutely right, money allowed our culture to develop and grow. However, we have reached such a state that we can eliminate the money, rearrange our social system and grow even faster, as now money has become the most corrupting medium ever. In other words, money was good in the past, but now it is an out-dated mechanism.We would not need to revert to an agrarian society, as most of the products (including food) will be produced automatically. There are hydroponics, aeroponics, automated farms and other ways to grow food without much human labor (I presume the amount of human labor would only decrease over time). The same goes for other products - we have 3D printers that can print any object you want for a very low monetary price.Do not imagine that this kind of a system would be implemented only after destroying everything that has been created in the monetary system - there are many things that can be used. As for the main computer in particular, in the transition period many home computers can be connected into one network to create a super computer. This can be found even today - offices sometimes use one supercomputer instead of PCs in each office, and there are projects like BOINC that use the computers of the participants all over the world. So creating that would not be a problem. As technology evolves, we will be able to eventually use better, faster computer as the core systems and recycle the resources of the products that are no longer in use.As for the resources and value, The Venus Project does not offer to substitute something else for money. If it's gold coins, paper bills or firewood branches, it is still money. Instead, there would not be such a mechanism. It is not very hard to imagine how it would function. If you can grow food with hydroponics for yourself and your family at home without any labor involved, the price of these products is virtually zero. You might say that one needs to pay for the materials used, but you can recycle and build it completely for free. Energy? The same, although it requires more work to get it to function completely for free. What I'm trying to say, the monetary value we put on products is not required at all as we can produce everything we need virtually for free and never require people to pay for anything. Many people like to count such things as construction costs into the price of a product, but if you regard it as a one-time investment, then the price drops drastically.My explanation is probably vague, so I'll give another example. Imagine that a city builds a giant greenhouse that is designed to generate it's own water (e.g. from the water vapor in the air or underground water), it's own energy (e.g. solar, wind, steam (which also works on the principle of solar power, not coal), geothermal), and produces everything automatically. Volunteers only come to maintain the greenhouse and adjust the systems if needed. Let's imagine that this greenhouse is a gift from the city hall to it's citizens and they do not need to cover the costs of construction. In that way, there is virtually nothing left to pay for, as everything is produced for free. As for transportation - let's say all citizens come to the greenhouse and pick the goods up themselves. But food can also be delivered to the market using an electric vehicle that powers up by the same energy produced by the greenhouse.You might notice that there is however price for the construction included, we can't get rid of that as of yet because we live in this system now.I understand that I covered only a small portion of the questions that arise, and I may have caused new questions to arise. If you wish to delve more into this matter (maybe you want to prove to me that this approach is wrong and faulty, or you wish to see how it isn't, or you just want to find out more about it, etc.), be sure to drop me a note. I will keep an open mind and together we can evaluate all the information we can find. You can find me on facebook (nickname: tadas.dht), or over email tadas.dht @ gmail.

Uh... wow. Quite a concept.  Thanks Kale for your creative energy and passion about this topic.  Unfortunately I don't think I see it in quite the same terms as you or the futurists you site do.  Such a broad range of topics to consider in this concept... but maybe the most important one to address is the issue of money.  'Money' may represent greed, economic disparity, etc. but it is also one of the key innovations that has allowed our society to specialize, develop and grow.  If society was solely based on resources, it seems that we would have to revert to some sort of agrarian / dawn-of-industrialization type of society.  But even then I am not sure how anything could get made without the use of money as a representation or place-holder of value.  The concept mentions the world's  resources being monitored by a computer.  This one aspect of the concept raises lots of questions for me in terms of money alone.  Such as: how does a computer advanced enough to monitor the Earth's resources get produced without the use of money?  There are just too many refined parts as well as research that would have to go into an object such as a computer to produce it with anything other than money.  And speaking of research, I am not sure I understand how design (of computers or anything else), innovation or intellectual property might be valued by a 'post-money' society.  Even though a designer might be contributing an abstract thing such as an idea would they still be paid for it in natural resources?  But then valuation would come into play.  As soon as one idea is deemed worth two pieces of firewood and another idea is thought to be worth three... all of the sudden that firewood, though in one respect nothing more than a natural resource, in another respect represents value.  The firewood has become money.  I am not sure there is a way to be free of money without reverting to a much more primitive society than what we are used to.I will pause there and spare you any more questions.  Interesting stuff Kale.  Even if not very plausible, your concept is very fun to think about.  There may even be some insights into how our society currently functions, as well as critiques of it, within these thought exercises that we can discover and learn valuable lessons from.  Thanks again!

Oh, I have same thoughts as Arjan. I think it is a very broad problem, and a historical one. It is very hard and dangerous to create a 'single minded solution' to it, same for the whole of the world. And a solution without any failures. What you described sounds interesting, changing world mechanisms, but I cannot see how it can be worked by the innovation leaders ;)

I tried to evaluate this concept, but the options given in the evaluation form are insufficient. Although I appreciate the energy Kale is putting into this, to me this is comparable to the utopian communism as described in the book 'Animal Farm'. It offers no viable solution for real world problems, describes a system without going into details on the crucial parts that create the problems it aims to solve. There is no clear description on how the resources are being fairly distributed, while at the heart of each conflict in the world lies the access to exactly that: resources.Quite frankly, I am surprised to find it in the set of final concepts.

The monetary system is completely decoupled from any natural processes. Can you not see that it is not working? The root cause of our problems is the system itself that created it. Not only is it the most wasteful, It is completely unsustainable. but the rich think they benefit from it. The truth is that in an RBE everyone would have a truly high standard of living.  The "in group" will do all they can to keep their power as they have been conditioned to do so. It is not that an RBE cannot happen but yes, the odds are against it and we are aware of what we are up against. In a moral sense, it is the only right thing to do and with regards to the scientific method of solving problems it is the only logical thing to do.

1. RBE is not communism. As communism requires the state to be the center for distribution of goods and services. RBE is stateless, as it relies on the effective management of the earth's resources by a central computer that requires only updates with new information. It is just taking the technology and resources that we have now and using them optimally. Culture is lagging behind technology--an RBE would catch us up and get us up to date. 2. RBE is not utopian. An RBE does not claim to solve all social problems, but it does claim to solve all problems that are common to all people. These problems being having enough food, water, and a safe place to live.  If a person still decides to kill another person from jealousy or something, they would not go to jail but society would treat the person as an outcast, most likely.

I got introduced to Zeitgeist by chance and was intrigued by the arguments and agenda. Since than however I have been more and more worried about the actual state of the world, about the empowerment of human needs with disregard to education as well as about the criteria and ethical borderlines required to fulfill this utopia. 
Problem 1. When (not if) aggression strikes against the  'venusian' idea, what would be the response be it in personal confrontation, on local community basis or globally when those in power try to keep it from escaping their grasp?Problem 2. How would motivation work if all basic needs are met and not create a gap for institutionalization, dogma or despotism?Problem 3. How would a resource ineffective solution be regarded if it meets the desires for freedom, expansion and growth?Problem 4. The project states it is not "Utopian nor Orwellian", I'd like to think so but a theme park is a show, an enterprise - still in the money world and as such may remain isolated and become a disaster without a real chance for survival. Is it not a more realistic idea to globally constitutionalize a city/state/small country/ as the ground for this political experiment, as an example for success and growth based on it's own independent laws so others may follow?
P.S. Please remember - communism already tried some of this and failed miserably causing more death than the two world wars together. Just consider its evolution even in current days where although it is no longer present in Europe, it is in China - taking on a new form...

Well, there's much debate on the Transition going on within the Zeitgeist Movement.  It's my own personally belief that the first goal would be, of course, to raise mass awareness of this project.  Once the common folk of all reaches of the planet become aware of this new way of doing things, we can then pressure the leaders of our countries to have an international monetary 'reset' day.
All countries (1.) agree that the monetary system is destructive and benefits the lives of the few rather than the whole, (2.) reset all debts of all nations to zero and (3.) create money to be equal value throughout the world.  Once this is accomplished, we could use the monetary system in a way to encourage the growth of a new economy.  Once technology has been focused on by all nations to increase the crop yields, (currently, there are farmers in the United States paid not to grow because their product is in such high abundance, their product would be worthless if it continued to grow as it is) advance technology to slim down the work force (create almost a new kind of welfare, temporarily), and push things like sustainable and updatable technology (so that things don't go to waste) while simultaneously working toward creating abundance.
And eventually the need for credits will just.. vanish.
Now, of course, that's just my take on it and does not necessarily reflect the vision of Jacque Fresco of The Venus Project or Peter Joseph of The Zeitgeist Movement.  The transition will be tough and trying at times, but it could be considered the birthing pains of a new society of neo-humanistic values.  A world that treasures the arts and nature.  A world without hunger or war.  The rabbit hole is much deeper than you can imagine, just take a look for yourself.
www.TheVenusProject.com

I wonder how this could be prototyped.  What's the smallest scale that you could do this for, say, five years, and then regroup and decide what has been leaned?
All of the 17 goals sound great, but each is so far-reaching as to really be hard to grasp in a tangible way.  Of course we would like to do each of these, but how do you prototype each?
I agree with Adam that small steps are the start of the journey.  What's the smallest meaningful step towards prototyping some combination of the 17 goals?
Keep it clean guys  there might be kids watching : ) We're sure it's possible to have this conversation without some of you getting antagonistic.

In response to your question of "why haven't the worlds leaders given resource based economics a chance? " Because of the sheer difficulty of the task and the change required for it. The only way to try a resource based society within our capitalist world would be to make a test city as the Venus Project wants to do, it would have to be able to fully function on its own. But that's where the hitch is, for this city to work properly it needs essentially the best technology available in every single way. The amount of resources required to set up this test city would be immense. This is a project of larger scale than ever has been attempted before, and it requires a whole shift in our ways of thinking like the project is suggesting but this isn't easy to implement. The governments as elected bodies are representing a people, their party which then represents the citizens. Before they can do anything large such as this they need the support behind them, and to change this many people's minds is a huge challenge. 
Now personally I agree that we need to dream big to have big changes and I admire those that are passionate about something and want to see these great changes but personally I tend to work for more realistic targets. I'm looking for the smaller changes, the steps which will help our world immediately. I don't think of our world as a bad place as a whole, I'm a very positive person. I see the good in almost everything, yet I understand that there are a lot of problems which need to be solved which is why I think developments like OpenIdeo are wonderful, they encourage people to start solving these problems and making the world a better place. And to me the easiest way to do this is one small step at a time.

I'm not going to bother to read your responses if you're not going to bother to take me seriously.  Everything you see and read on this page is based of scientific evidence.  You can go on dreaming that your world is going to be shit from birth to death, and I guarantee that it will stay that was as long as you have that kind of attitude.  I'm not dreaming, buddy, you are if you think this primitive way of thinking is ever going to hold up forever.
The Venus Project isn't TADAAAA the end to our problems, but it's a solution to many.  The Venus Project isn't neat architecture and and philosophy.. it is ever changing, constantly evolving with the knowledge we acquire.   You've made how you stand very clear, now move on to the next concept and tell them how it will just 'never happen'.

I remind you that even though it's fun to think about an utopian society such as The Venus project, neither you or me will ever see that world during our life's span; having said that, the real question for you and me and everyone who wish to lead the world in that direction needs to understand the monetary system and work against it from within it; Jacque Fresco imagined a better future, now it is up to us to make that switch without sub estimating the complexity of the world in which we live right now. So what questions do you believe Innovators should be asking today in our transition to a Venus society?; let's never forget that technology in any context is a tool for humans to extend its capabilities and even though it should be available for everyone( and that's where we are heading to), it is at this very moment helping you and me connect and create a discussion that will generate change, so Lets not take for granted the power of things we own, they identify us as individuals and connects us back to society; and that my friend is the real value of material goods. cheers

We've outgrown the monetary system, mate.  If you were guaranteed exactly the life you want to live as long as it doesn't interfere with another's, then you would have a very different idea on property and all that junk.  I mean, what good is it all after you die anyway?  
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jEfP39ZjyNk

The monetary system represents intangible value, but it would be possible to keep the monetary system as long as money value corresponds to the amount of available resources?, it is hard for me to think that the monetary system is going anywhere and if you ask me i would say it will stay for a very long time still, but how can we bring money value close to what it once was, an abstract representation of the available resources!, policy makers have the power to bring the intangible costs (meaning the REAL cost of things) of every single good that is produced , a good example of this policy would be the recycling fee that is now being charged with some electronics; all of the sudden we realize that acquiring products is a lot more expensive than what we thought, this will in exchange slow down consumers and in my opinion will generate positive change. Bringing real prize of things back through taxing will push technology forward in terms of efficiency and sustainability.

Thanks for your comment, Johan. I think indeed that fear of the not-familiar is a big issue. Great initiatives you mention about the hospital and the school schemes. Any chance you have a link to that?

Big reasons to racism and discrimination is a fear of unknown people, you spread rumours about "them", you feel nervous when a stranger walk onto your bus. You are feeling worried that "they" are living much richer and happier than yourself, and that they are envious about your life.
If lots of smallscale businesses bought and sold everyday objects to each other easily, regularly across any border, they will gain some more knowledge, familiarity and respect for one another. Just like the great examples in Israel where all staff at a big Hospital is intentionally mixed groups of people from different areas. There is also some school schemes there that attempt to pair up kids into being friends with others.
In comment to Pablos Comment below, it is only true for weapon industry. Huge costs involved for government, and not to mention all the suffering innocent and soldiers families.

Pablo, I take that into consideration, but firmly believe that there are actually only very few individuals that benefit from war. I think for many people, war is a big threat to welfare and health. And I also think that if people are in difficult circumstances, they tend to follow leaders that promise them security if they just help kill the enemy. However, when economic cooperation is stimulated, for many people war is in the way of progress, and then the pressure on politicians to end conflicts will increase. comments.text: James,Thank you for the thoughtfull comment!I am in good company.
Congratulations on making it to the final 9 on the agenda! Well done!http://reasonedprogression.wordpress.com

Andrea,My hopes are similiar for developing countries, the ability to "leapfrog" unsustainable practices. Consume and produce locally, etc. 
Developing countries are portrayed as helpless victims, give them the tools and stand back!

Somehow we have to find ways to share the "American Story" in such a way as to not communicate we are asking 3rd world countries to do things we are not doing.  There seems to be a general theme emerging, where we want others to learn from our lessons before they make our mistakes.
These other countries see us as successful and want the same for themselves, so they logically follow our methods.  Somehow we have to find a way to say, "you can not only do it better, but you will be even more successful using new methods".
It's so hard to think of doing the right things when modeling the poor behaviors of 1st world countries has so clearly has led to wealth and prosperity, at a very high price to the whole world.  When you don't have the basics like water and food, it's much easier to make bad deals with people who don't care either way.
Perhaps, using countries like Brazil and other's who have become so successful may help make the best case.

This is really important in the international aid context. In addition to installing new technologies for solar power and wells, we need to train people how to maintain them after the donors leave. I wrote an article on the idea of plumbers without borders: http://nicoleskibolaesq.wordpress.com/2010/12/17/plumbers-and-bureaucrats-without-borders/.

Larry,
Thank you for the comment!I could not agree more. Nothing fuels independance and empowerment more than the act of creation.Nice catch on the BF T, nice catch. Not sure if many people pick up on that. Not sure where the counterculture occurs today.

This is just as important, maybe even more important, in underprivledged areas of the first world.  it would be great to encourage learning about how to be more than just a consumer.
Also Tom, I like your Black Flag shirt.

comments.text: Emily...great points! I hear you on the issue that "some find it more easy to contribute their stories to societies discourse where others don't." Thought you might be interested in a couple of initiatives that speak to this from the previous Affordable Education challenge on OpenIDEO  Grassroots Comics: http://bit.ly/cisGqE and Local Content Creation: http://bit.ly/9YNTOK

I definitely think that stories are one of the best places to inspire and change people. I know from first hand experience, a couple of years ago when I was a student at a summer program I had a guest speaker who certainly changed my life and inspired me to work towards doing something for our world. 
And I agree we need stories from all different types of communities as they will break down boundaries and provide new perspectives upon our world.

Sydney I agree. Hearing stories is as important as making them. Hearing stories lets us know what might be possible. They teach us to aspire and inspire.
But this particular project recognises some find it more easy to contribute their stories to societies discourse where others don't. It's important to ensure that we are including even those most isolated in the steering of our local communities and our global agenda.
Stories are the way we're able to make sense of the world and our lives.  As the world gets crazier, we need stories more than ever to keep us grounded in what's important.  APPLAUD!

I agree that telling your story is extremely powerful, but also hearing the stories and poems and words of others is just as powerful. There have been some spoken word poets and poems that have completely changed my life. In the school I work at (in Marinilla, Colombia) there is a 10th grade native Spanish speaker who performed a poem he wrote in English, and it took everything I had not to breakdown into tears. Also there is a famous spoken word poet Anis Mojgani that inspired me to make a decision that many outsiders deemed as crazy. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rvruwi211fU
So in the end we need to establish consistent story-telling projects like Pangea Day http://www.pangeaday.org/ but this time instead of it being one day and only focused on cultural exchange it should be a forum allowing people to share and read stories based on all themes that relate to them :)

ah yes!! stories can carry our young and impressionable into other worlds.. that can inspire! and maybe it might be something they remember enough to carry to the next.... england has soo much more in that way of preservation of history... los angeles, has some but its all old hollywood.. which is cool.. but its not the history that i want my son to know of America...
Stories have a powerful healing effect. Our identities are shaped by the stories we carry. If we could set up a global story telling project we would construct a new history for future generations.

I also like the aspect of stories preserving traditions in communities (urban and rural). A sense of history if always an important source of identity and empowerment and stories have a unique way of opening a window to the past (and future).
Good stuff. Keep up the good work.

Storytelling is the first step to manifesting a better reality. We exist in a world of stories, it affects our perception and cultural constructs. If we tell positive stories, we shape what we believe we are capable of. A case in point that I find of interest is the Book Sprint http://en.flossmanuals.net/booksprints the creation of books in 5 Days originally resulted from the misunderstanding that it had already been done, which led to the belief that it could be done.

accept_autism.description: People with autism face barriers in accessing all parts of society that you or I might take for granted. It is important to stress that the concept of autism is not ‘carved in stone’. We are still very much at the dawn of understanding. We are all on a journey of exploration, and are unearthing new layers of meanings, opening new doorways and finding ourselves wandering down new pathways all the time. This is partly why it is such an exciting field to be involved with.
accept_autism.creator: 52f4ef2d88db729b255fbfd2cad9b709

comments.text: I agree Justin, there are some examples of effective assistive technology used for people with but no where near utilising potential given scope of technological advancements in other more consumer driven fields. In addition what does exist often doesn't reach those who need it most. I think enabling people with autism to more effectively contribute to society will lead to the development of a better world. The problem solving abilities, and logical and systematic approach to the world that characterises the condition can fuel, inspire and drive innovation.

WE also should be analysing what kinds of technological advancements might assist those with congenital defects like this.  There are plenty of things autistic people could do to be interactive and productive members of society if those without autism could learn to communicate with autistic people better.

I like the image of the pathway with the overhead structure you chose for your inspiration on accepting autism.  The overall supporting structure appears very worn-down, but it embraces light, and the overall pathway is colorful.
Sounds like an excellent service. Acceptance is so important to young peoples development and mental well being and the parental support network is such a valuable aspect.

Clubs like The Out Of School Club is intregal to the well being of families with autistic children/members. Without it there is little social outlet. Being understood and  accepted, worts and all, and having a special place to simply be is just wonderful.

Great how you've illustrated your far reaching point about hubs, networks and communities through a concrete example Emily. We're hoping that others will also post local examples that demonstrate current solutions in action. That way we'll have an array of ideas that can inspire Agenda Concepts in the next phase.
This sounds very positive and encouraging!
I love this idea

comments.text: Sabra, thanks for the comment!  I like your thoughts on the two routes to cleaner energy.  I think you are right in that independent companies just have to take matters into their own hands and make new clean energy technology applications available to the general consumer.  The issue, though, is your second route.  That of battling entrenched politicians and oil company lobbyists to change legislation, remove restrictions and clear the way for true competition.  Currently the dual equation of heavy tax breaks and heavier subsidies tend to give oil companies an economic advantage over new clean energy companies trying to get off of the ground.  Until the marketplace playing field is leveled it will be that much harder for companies introducing new energy technology to gain a foothold to grow from.But all this is to say that they should not give up trying.  Clean, renewable energy is our great hope in halting the polluting damage we are causing to the Earth.  We will find a way to implement it.  We must.Thanks again for your comment!

There are two basic routes I see towards a cleaner energy future in the U.S.. One is grassroots. Small companies and large are beginning to introduce clean fuel tech into the marketplace. We need thousands of self-organized groups of people to create businesses dedicated to producing and distributing waste to clean fuel technologies. Crowdsourced funding through places like http://www.indiegogo.com/ would be one way to approach. Organizations like the National Co op Bank  http://www.ncb.coop/, are another.
The other route is to to work on the barriers to a clean energy future through regulation and legislation. This is also necessary, but has tended in the past to bleed energy away from making more immediate real world solutions happen.

Yes. I guess the U.S.people are much too brainwashed to be terribly afraid of the word : "Communism".so they falsely think it ideologically is dangerous to join in unions.(U.S. need to study history and other countries much more to understand, before they reject foreign thoughts, for instance Sweden went from extreme poverty in 1850 to be one of the richest countries in the world in just 120 years, thanks to workers unions, free public school, free hospital treatments of high quality and so on)
In some ways extreme liberalism and corporate libertarianism is much more dangerous and borders to anarchism and chaos.All the big consumer companies exploit that fact by serving you shit products and shit food.
But if we cannot learn to trust and depend upon each other?how can we survive?

Johan, Wow!  What a comment!  Thanks for all of those thoughts!  I agree - what is it about U.S. culture that makes us for the most part just not that interested in getting involved?  My guess is that we have been trained to be first and fore-most a consumer culture.  It there are things to buy we will buy them.  Simple as that.  But you are right in that there is a lot of potential for powerful influence if we collectively banded together.So maybe the question is how do we get people to be inspired to get involved, organize grass-roots initiatives and act collectively in the fight for justice and happiness?  In effect a cultural shift.  But it always comes down to that doesn't it?Thanks again Johan!

about USA is that its huge crowds of people there do not use the collective consumer power as much as (and as regularly and organized) Europeans do. I mean it seems to be very silly when you all pay your electric bill, month after month, and do not understand the connection between coal miners profits and coal power plants emissions and its result on your economy and nature. And many don't even bother to register to vote! I mean didn't most of you escape from Europe because you wanted more democracy and freedom?
Connect the dots - there are plenty of info to read and learn - use technology - join together - start calling up your utility company and say "I want clean wind power and solar power and not anymore coal and oil power". And then you phone 5-10 friends and tell them to do the same, just like Multi-Level-Marketing-pyramide-scheme. This has potential to send a big message!Use mass media, emails, text messaging any type of peer-to-peer-software to form a large enough mass of people phoning and emailing the utility companies, so they understand that you guys mean it.Even 14-year old kids walk around with the tools in their pockets that could start revolutions, but noone bothers, they just send LOL and images of cute kittens!
For instance we have a swedish internet based company that collects much more than 100.000 individual home owners. They goes around to all electricity producers, and say: listen, we can give you exclusive one-year-contracts with 100.000 homes, if you give us your lowest offer, and you promise to give us cleaner way to generate electricity for us. (Sweden have historically had roughly the same percentage of water-power-plants as US coal power : 50%)
Do you understand what I am going at? look around at all industries, shops and warehouses. If you like that initiative: go and shop there and tell your friends why you support them. IF they do something bloody wrong, stop shopping there, and tell all your friends! use technology to read up on business practices and then spread the shit or salute those that do good.
Industries and business must learn to listen to what the crowd wants and prefer, and they will change, they have to change. If they want customers and money in the future, they need to change! And some scientific prestigous reports shows evidence that already it is more beneficial for a company and society to change to the little more expensive green-choices NOW. Than to have to be responsible to clean up the mess afterwards *cough,cough,BP* know what I mean???
There are many more job opportunities building and managing new renewable power plants than it is people working in coal mines or on oil rigs. (There is mostly machines excavating the ground, so big advantages to make there too with the 10% unemployment)
This can be applied to much more than just environment, it is about saving local enterprises, employment, income for families, lowering food and utility costs... about anything that you consumers care about...
You just have to join forces and go tell them, together, in unison. use your freedom of choice and of free speech. (and don't worry so much about the politicians, all they worry about is getting re-elected)

Johan, thanks for the comment!  I agree that it seems as though oil's dominating strength is protected and encouraged by politicians.  Very sad.  So maybe the question is, if we can't trust lawmakers to do the tough-but-noble thing and create legislative structure that will turn our energy consumption culture to other energy forms and move society in the right direction,  how can we do it ourselves?  Is there a smarter way to talk about energy consumption in the public space?  Is there untapped white space where the application of clean energy technology and methods will create a great shift in public perception?  I ask because, especially in the U.S., it seems like we still think it's o.k. to drive huge SUV's that get less than 20mpg.  And every oil spill and environmental disaster is downplayed and dismissed by our leaders.  What will it take to turn the tide of public opinion?  My guess is that if gas prices were actually where the market says they should be, instead of heavily subsidized as they are now, there would be a quick and decisive move toward greater fuel efficiency.Thanks again for your comment!

The simple answer is yes. Innovators have worked enourmosly for many years, and have come up with several existing techniques and methods, so we can 1. produce alternative oils, fuels and plastics that is cleaner than coal and oil. 2. do efficiency improvements on all our machines and equipment so it does not demand as much energy. 3. IT that reduces part of the need for many transports and 4. new smarter combined products with more areas of use, that replace several older inefficient products with obsolete technique.
But I agree that Oil lobby groups are getting more desperate. and by making their methods and fund raising transparent is important way for people to see what they work with and how they do it. Big reasons to why some politicians bow to lobbyists is the potential to get employed by them when the political career is over.

how_can_we_better_enable_inclusion_of_ev.description: How can we better enable the inclusion of those who are at risk of exclusion from our communities? Those most disadvantaged are frequently most likely to be locked out of the principal decision making forums involved in forming, shaping and evolving our communities.
how_can_we_better_enable_inclusion_of_ev.creator: 52f4ef2d88db729b255fbfd2cad9b709

comments.text: I very much do agree that even in 2013 this challenge is still very actual. Social inclusion is on the agenda of UN agencies and many countries in the world. Indicators have been set in order to measure the  results of social inclusion policies ranging from education to employment. However, even policy indicators do not properly measure actual improvements or lack of. We still have not reached a balance between qualitative and quantitative indicators, developmental and more traditional impact evaluations. targeting the real socially excluded remains a very strong challenge in a lot of development projects around the world. Often, the assumptions embedded in innovations and solutions proposed in development to achieve social inclusion are actually very much culture-bound/specific and characterized by stereotypes towards socially excluded specific groups we are targeting. I believe that by highthening cultural/diversity competence in planning, designing, implementing and monitoring and evaluating phases of inclusion solutions and projects would enhance the quality of results

I am totally on your page on this one Emily. I've been kicking around in the philanthropic sector for about 15 years and the (however well-intentioned) people at the top are rarely representative of the communities they're supposedly serving. I was a the Council on Foundations annual conference this weekend and spoke with Gerald Salole of the European Foundation Center about this exact topic -- he exhorted that philanthropy (and development, and social entrepreneurship) needs to shift away from a colonial "social engineering" approach and look for new (or very old and traditional) ways to listen with the "big ear" Andrea mentions and move some of the design and decision-making power to the people.
Congratulations on making it to the final 9 on the agenda! Well done!

Hi Emily,I'm happy I could make a contribution to your concept.  I've witnessed how easy it is to assume "we" know what's good and right for someone else or their community.  I've seen parents do this to kids all the time, never asking the kids themselves what would work to solve some high risk problems.  
You are so right about listening openly, "the big ear", so to speak.  I like to think after listening carefully, we can collaborate on resonant solutions/actions to take, so there are real outcomes and results, which can be seen by the community.  I've learned to marry planning and evaluation seemlessly into the listening process, so we are working together on strategic, operational and tactical goals.  I think it's helped me to be the facilitator with an intermediary role, with leadership emerging from the group. 
I often think how many lessons I've learned, and re-learned, from various and diverse communities, which has humbled me many times.  I worry those "with" can lean towards arrogance, when in fact the group has the wisdom and just needs a hand and guidance to make it so.
One other variable I think really counts.  The issue or challenge has to be compelling to the group or it won't fly.

Thank you Andrea. This is what is important to me, that we should not position people and their challenges as "problems" but instead allow them to determine their own challenges and importantly their solutions. Otherwise we are in danger of engendering more distinction between those who are powerful and those who are not... be they children, the aged, indigenous communities, people with disabilities, people with mental health problems... We need to endeavour to learn to listen to those less likely to be heard and encourage their engagement and involvement with needed change.

This is an important challenge.  We are in serious danger to leaving more and more people out of the process, especially if the primary method of communication and participation is technology based alone.
Different cultures approach the nature of community and community participation quite differently.  As we design models to address this important issue, we need to involve those in the different target groups, as part of the process.
I spent years working with the American Indian Community on the nature of the Urban American Indian Tribe.  We spent a lot of time looking at what were the best ways to communicate, to an ever increasing number of participants, from multiple tribes.  
Thinking that technology might truly make basic communication easier, it bumped up against the tradition of gathering through ritual and food.  I asked at one time about writing up this very special project and was told, "Andrea, you know Indian's don't like to write, we like pictures and stories".  Why didn't I remember that key concept, I should have known better!  I made an incorrect assumption, which was corrected by the community.  It was a classic case of my paradigm bumping up against a completely different one.
As we figure this out, we really have to remember the nature of each unique culture and honor their ways of building community, participation, and collaboration.  I'm thinking some of the "keys to the answers" lie in asking some excellent questions with a very open mind.
This concept needs to underpin the development of the global agenda. As Andy Shrader pointed out this concept is about creating lines of communication and listening.

I think this concept invites a discussion that NEEDS to be had and consideration of how to include ALL people in any global challenge seems to be a very apparent and necessary if we are going to successfully achieve much needed change.
simple but clear and clearly important

Interestingly, as we get more technologically "advanced," and, at the same time, pollute more and more of the Earth, it becomes clear that the very people so-called first-world countries want to "save" are the indigenous people who have been successfully and sustainably living in non-industrialized areas for centuries.  Opening lines of communication and listening is not only helpful, it is essential to humankind's continued existence on a planet with rapidly dwindling resources.

I agree with Andy, involving vulnerable people in coming up with potential solutions to the problems that they face is essential and will result in greater investment and increased likelihood of success.

It never ceases to amaze me how those responsible for vulnerable people seem to feel they know what's best for them. I've rarely witnessed heartfelt inclusion more often than not just box ticking. It is vitally important to make every effort to include these vulnerable people in the decisions that will affect them

To really achieve inclusion we need to think about how our societies and cultures construct notions of difference. We need to be aware of how difference is created and seek to challenge reinforced differences. The work of Foucault helped me to understand why and how difference is created. In short its about how power is exercised by one group over another. Empowering groups with little power is a step in the right direction at redressing the balance.

I think it's really important to look at things from the bottom up especially when it comes to defining which priorities need addressing. We need to move away from the sympathy model of vulnerable groups and instead accept the role the global community has played in constructing disadvantage. Any more top down problem solving just further carves out this disadvantage.

how_can_we_better_enable_inclusion_of_ev.title: How can we better enable inclusion of everyone?

Johan, it sounds that information infrastructure is one of key technologies to enhance exchanging such "low-tech" innovations. Can we except that all people will be able to enjoy information infrastructure, such as cellular phone at least?

Great!!! Innovation arises in many areas where you least expect it!!!If little-known "low-tech" innovation was put freely into public domain and open-source it could help so many people in any city in any part of the world that have got similar issues.I guess that there are loads of simpler old practical things and routine practices that are going to become forgotten when the "baby-boomers" generations of 1920's to 1950's in the western world are retiring from their careers that used to rely on handicrafts and practical skills.Any little creative or simple idea can even inspire to other, larger innovations, like a domino-effect!

how_do_we_ensure_that_companies_and_upco.creator: 711c99771f3ceed49f77ac8c7c89ac2d

comments.text: Paul indeed makes valid points. Showing examples of where sustainability has proven to be the best business practice is a good way of convincing businesses. This is also the way I am trying to promote the CSR principles in the Baltics, through a blog that shows the beneficial business cases of CSR.

I agree with Paul Hess, we need to tackle the problem at system's level and it will be a matter of a progressive transition (vs a sharp transformation) in which everyone has its own role. Sustainability is highly complex and uncertain, as it stems from the synergy  of many factors (policy, the fate of fossil fuels, consumers, tech development, economic incentives, climate change, China...). Whether you use methodology x or y to analyze trade-offs is ok, while you include socio-environmental values in the analysis.
http://www.natcapsolutions.org/ is a site devoted to helping business become sustainable. They have extensive experience and knowledge in the field.

This question is crucial and needs to be broken down or it is too overwhelming. You specified more it when you asked about incentives, and there are other dimension like availability of information. I'm working on addressing major myths about business strategy like the idea of trade-off economics, that make people assume that sustainability costs. The same frame was used to assume that quality costs but many managers eventually figured out that improving quality lowers costs--so we can learn from that historical experience of that last 3 decades. 
A question is how do we integrate sustainability with business strategy to increase revenue, productivity and lower costs? We need short, snappy talking points. People need to learn the difference between cost benefit analysis that assumes trade-offs, versus root cause analysis that removes the underlying constraints in systems that present trade-offs under a certain way of doing things. (short, but not yet snappy). Sustainable thinking generally does root cause analysis to the systems level where all the factors of business success can be addressed together to reduce economic trade-offs and create win -win social outcomes. We just need to sharpen our arguments and train people to use them to frame the policy debates, consultant sales pitches, and branding of this movement.

Very good thinking, this is definitely something we need to ensure it happens, the green movement has moved us towards a more sustainable future and a whole new set of challenges and now it is time to pinpoint everything that opposes in order to accelerate this transition; having said that, we must never forget that many many countries are not quite there yet, so how can countries that "get it" can influence the rest of the economies to don't?

Great questions. Each question needs probably a million answers; the task here seems to be to cast these ideas into many many specific questions. Demand is growing for these technologies, what are the obstacles for manufacturers?
