reduce_hunger_by_reducing_waste.description: What can we do to prevent food from catering, events, food stylists, grocery stores, etc. from going into the trash and get it to people who need it?
reduce_hunger_by_reducing_waste.creator: 6c0a47abfa928ba77d47a123185f455d

comments.text:
There are a number of great organizations in the US that do food rescue of this sort, and having worked with a few of them, especially on campuses, it's really interesting to see how food vendors often don't know how much they are wasting until they are packing it up to donate. Just by seeing the quantity of food that went into packages, to the vans and off to homeless shelters, the vendor changed their kitchen strategy and dramatically reduced food waste. Eventually, they not only changed the amount of food they were providing, but also started a program to improve up-front preparation waste.  
I think this could be applicable in a lot of different areas, not just food  seeing the waste up front, rather than gradually as it's sloughed off into black trash bags can help emphasize a need for a change. When the disparity is more obvious, people are motivated to make a change in their personal behavior.

After coming across this post in yesterday's GOOD e-newsletter http://www.good.is/post/pass-the-baton-a-more-personal-kind-of-recycling?utm_campaign=daily_good&utm_medium=email&utm_source=read_and_discuss_link&utm_content=Pass%20the%20Baton:%20A%20More%20Personal%20Kind%20of%20Recycling I started rethinking what "hunger" actually means. I'd like to start thinking about hunger beyond food, but the hunger for all basic needs. PASS THE BATON http://www.pass-the-baton.com/ is a new "personal culture marketplace" that's happening in Japan which further proves one man's trash is another man's treasure. In this model, people not only pass along objects, but they pass along stories with them.
http://www.permaculture.com/ Food waste can be used to produce fuel alcohol as part of the process of making it into good compost.

Caveat:  According to the ICAI (Chartered Accountants) Food Security will become the more NB than energy within our lifetimes.  Food Production in 2007 according to The Economist.Meat:  China 90.5million tonnes (no waste I'd say)US     41.8 million tonnes (what happening)Brazil 20 million tonnes Argentina 4.4 million tonnesIreland/Sweeden ?Total of Top Ten is 191.882 million tonnes of meatone 550 kg animal produces minimum 292,000 litres of gas per year (Reuters)Thats  101,871,898,200,000 litres of gas for the unfortunate ones that year.Cow Backpacks&Tanks plus Keanan Fodder Mulchers Are in this season He.
Total Tonnes of Coffeebeans Produced in 2007 is 5,832,000 tonnes.Thats alot Johan.
Food business will need to get cleverer.

I buy mostly unprocessed organic foods and both of us are fitness freaks, the wheelie bin appears heavy to my being and I have empitied it twice this year.  What worries me most is leachate from the landfill esp. with the rise in rainfall in November and the proximity of the catchment area to old households.  Sites like these make me feel heavy, though solving hazards fore good makes my spirit soar.Looking  at global food intake in tonnage is probably hazardous to my health however its stated in the Economist Pocket World Book in Figures 2010.  300 kg is merely a belief.  Obiesity is recognised as unacceptable by some corporations and that is a start.  Given that Corporate Social Responsibility is seen as profitable entities are adjusting this formality that we had little choice in attending.
Johan - I love that concept of the sharing refrigerator in Sweden - I think one with a glass door/front would be even more powerful so you could see what's inside.

Hey Peter in Cork! I was there exactly 10 years ago! Grand! :)
I have to ask: 300 kg of food waste per year??? per person???how?Can't you learn how to cook the exact amount that you would eat?
I think i waste only 5-10 kg food & organic compostables per year. (paper napkins, coffee filter, tea bags and so on)
and we have a municipal compost program here in Gvle, Sweden.We have a brown plastic bin next to the regular green bin for unrecyclable waste. The community garbage company makes perfect soil that we can buy back for a cheap amount if we need.And during the compost process they collect all gases and sells it as a fuel for heating.Reducing garbage collection fees and landfills.

I want to contribute with a marvelous thing i saw in a supermarket in Stockholm, Sweden. http://bit.ly/cQsNHi
The shop had bought a standard refrigerator, and it's placed visibly just inside the doors, as a reminder to people going in and going out of the shop. The front door of the fridge had a message to shoppers to try to buy one extra portion per week/or two per month and place in this fridge. A volunteer organisation went by every night and picked up the food inside it.They cook the food at local soupkitchen and shared it amongst those with needs in the area. roughly 200 homeless persons in that area. If this was placed in more shops it could create a habit of some to regularly buy some stuff to donate it instantly in the shop.---I am not sure if the shop donated themselves, but i can imagine that they are thinking twice before throwing away anything. It costs a lot for a shop to have garbage collected here.

Peter, very true about the sense of pride. This reminded me of one of my favorite dining experiences at Friends - a restaurant in Cambodia which is serviced (food and table waiting) by street children who are part of the Friends International program to improve the lives of young people. It was a delicious and memorable meal. http://www.friends-international.org/shop/restaurants.asp?mainmenu=shop&page=restaurants
Dogwood http://www.dogwoodbaltimore.com/ is a restaurant in Baltimore that uses local and organic foods. They also have a social mission, "to transform lives one plate at a time by providing training opportunity and paid employment to individuals who are transitioning from addiction, incarceration, homelessness, and/or underemployment." Perhaps transitional workers such as in this case could act as a liaison between restaurants/businesses and the communities in need.

Both my Mum and I produce about 300kg of foodwaste per year appox.  Now we have a dedicated wheelie bin with an orange CH4 (Methane) Hazchem sticker on the front of it.  Currently at the managed landfill sites try and trap CH4 with boreholes and pipes.  Seperation to a municipal digester or biomass facility could store the 63.8% CH4 for resale or send it into the grid.    With respect, I should very much like when (PEPSICO) with displaced communities offer verified W.H.O. standard water for sale at some supermarket here in Ireland and accross the "developed" world from entrenched and >20 year displacement.  Possibly to fund the arbitration of broadcast and polarised views.Common sense dictates that we should have a drive thru where we could leave with implied waiver unwanted food and household items for the homeless and people with security issues.  Having worked with homeless who all have a certain pride, I think that a personal cookery programme of nurishment would help them fend off.  It raises awareness and releases endorphins.   Alcohol and drug tests to verify their human effort and will for screening purposes is cool by me.  Here in Cork St. Vincent de Paul collect food especially during Christmas time because there are people who go to sleep hungry.  In economics the term "Giffen Good" is a historical term because people are no longer dependent on the price of bread.

Great thoughts everyone!
Arjan- I hadn't heard of it, but that makes sense, and glad to hear it's happening. I forgot to mention in my post about friend's dumpster diving during college - I can't tell you how many "expired" frozen cookies I ate ;)
Eric - Interesting thought. It's like when we move cities we invite all our friends over to claim the crap/food we don't want/need anymore. No one seems to care that it's something the person doesn't want anymore - we're just happy to have a free new thing. As people's time is so precious these days, it's nice to create alternative ways of giving back.
Elizabeth - And thank you for the great interview with Pia on your site! Fascinating to learn that there are issues of harmful gases with too much waste. Thanks too for the additional links! FareShare made me think how organizations like this could work with local companies - who are already commuting - to help act as transport vehicles. Agreed that LoveFoodHateWatse does help you think about food/waste differently.
Meena - Neat about the Super Marmite network - I could see that as a good way for students to get good, healthy & affordable meals too. And I've heard of freecycling, but never for food. Even if an apple is a little soft, or a banana is a little mushy, it still can be made into something delicious.

I have seen this issue from close by as well. One thing I heard for a solution of getting around liability, was that a company that had excess food would call a shelter or the salvation army, and let them know where the food would be 'dumped' (well packed of course) and when, so the charity could pick it up directly and distribute it to people who could really use it. Silly that it has to be that way, but still, maybe one way of dealing with it.

I absolutely agree on this. Your idea helped me think of this thought: How can the people who receive this food better their lives from it? ie. If extra food were given to others before the food became waste, how can we make it that the people receiving the food don't take advantage of the food and become lazy? I'm sure there are several great ideas that can come from this so that the people who receive the food are rewarded somehow by doing something? Community service? Volunteerism? Just a thought. Great inspiration, Anne!

Hi Anne, thanks for mentioning our Conserve Delhi 2010 project blog and leading me to this very interesting site! There are many issues with our current dominant food system around the world - eg large amounts of food waste ending up rotting in landfill can give off methane - a highly potent greenhouse gas. But there are lots of positive ideas cropping up in response as well. While I was googling Melbourne's Fareshare I also came across a similar organisation in the UK http://www.fareshare.org.uk/ and there's the http://www.lovefoodhatewaste.com/ campaign site, lots of good info and simple tips to love your food and make less waste. Particularly like the storage tips. Cheers, Liz

Hi Anne  I just noticed this on Springwise yesterday: an online network that helps home cooks sell their extra portions http://bit.ly/d0buDM  You've also reminded me of an public space/art initiative from down in New Zealand earlier this year which redistributed surplus food from local suppliers: http://bit.ly/bXavlh

comments.text: There are so many opportunities to use existing resources instead of constantly drilling / mining / growing more and more with a negative, extractive impact on the environment. We're seeing amazing companies large and small that are taking advantage of the huge amount of untapped resources. It's great to see the bottom line aligned with environmental impact. It happens when we take something that is a cost center (waste) and turn it into a revenue generator (resource).

Great stuff Nicole! I love the notion of trading waste. We also cover small-scale examples of reuse, repair, repurpose, recycle at the base of the pyramid on our REculture blog. Here's a collection of sample posts: http://bit.ly/b8iKJD They're often market-oriented approaches with a keen sense of material-efficiency.

I love that! Brooklyn has been doing cool stuff around textile recycling: http://www.grownyc.org/textiles - where collection centers take in old textiles that are then turned into car seats, cleaning rags etc. (Not exactly the same as your idea but similar). I also love "Stop n' Swaps http://www.grownyc.org/swap - where people can trade stuff they no longer use. It's all one step away from the ultra-destructive consumer-mania market we have grown so accustomed to...

comments.text: Who's going to have a go at converting this strongly discussed inspiration into an Agenda Concept question?
Sabra - I have heard of it, but will for sure check it out now that you gave me the link. Good idea, thanks! Kristine, Will also check out IDEO design toolkit.
Sabra - that's a great example!  Yes, I heard of that too.  Also, Nicole, IDEO has a human centered design tool kit you can download.

Are you aware of MIT open course ware ? http://ocw.mit.edu/index.htm Almost all of MITs courses are available online for free. People get together online and in person to follow course ware, self organizing into temporary learning communities.

Hi Nicole ~ I am going to give this some thought and post more later.  I love IDEO, but somebody told me (from their perspective) that the design consulting firm thrives on ambiguity. To be fair, design is a profession where ideas need to be protected and respected, and designers need to earn their income for their skills as an earned living. So design education and design consulting has a price.  So how can design expertise and high quality design education be accessible to us all, right? 
Well, I am going to give this some thought and hopefully, post an inspiration for you soon.  Also, I want to post something constructive for Open IDEO. It will be a post along the lines of accessible design empowerment.  
I too thought about going to grad schools like Stanford D School or California College of the Arts (CCA). I also came across many expensive workshops I wanted to take from leading innovation experts.  But really, what works for me personally is --- if I really want to move and shake the world and play a leading design role  --- I just go do it.  I see what I want to do, and I design my own way to get there.  
Although it may increase my knowledge and skills as a designer, formal design education is not my only route.  I have invented my own path by serving my community in civic engagement groups, and leading non-profit organizations with workshops.  I learn about communities from interacting.  Personally, not having to pay a cent for formal grad school education, everyday community service enables me as a leader.  Lastly, I just want to end by saying what my feng shui master says, "the world is a book."
Kristine, I think you are right re elementary education, but what about us now? There is so much talk about future leaders, what about current (or soon to be) leaders?

Great discussion guys. Johan  we'd love it if you'd post the 24-hour-instant-incubator-brainstormers as a stand-alone inspiration. Keep in mind everyone  as we post in the Inspiration Phase we're looking to lead with *existing examples* from around the world (as Nicole has done here) and follow up with discussion. We can filter into the big picture issues in the next phase of Agenda Concepts. Keep up the brilliant diversity of global initiatives!

Hi Nicole, I think the way to go is to begin creative learning early on in elementary public education before design education gets expensive in college.  We should get the department of education involved.  Begin with introducing small projects to students in elementary and high schools that enable design thinking.  Design education should be accessible in public education very early.
Also, I was fortunate to have an undergrad design education from UC Berkeley.  I also contemplated going to Stanford Design school for graduate studies afterwards.    It's an expensive path, and I didn't pursue it. Frankly, I now see that I learn more about innovation from interacting with socially cause-driven groups outside of the traditional education system, such as from my mentor at GEO Feng Shui Education Organization in SF, and my involvement with non-partisan civic engagement groups here in the Bay Area.  Those don't really cost anything compared to D School.   
Also, before I came across your article, I posted a somewhat similar inspiration on the need to address cross-disciplinary design skills in schools: http://openideo.com/open/what-is-the-global-challenge-that-most-concerns-you-right-now-and-that-global-innovation-leaders-could-begin-to-solve/inspiration/awaken-creativity-in-schools-with-empathy/

I love the idea of cross-pollination of knowledge and expertise. I work in social care and and am often frustrated at the lack of integration with other industry fields that could benefit the value of our work.

Hi Nicole, thanks!There is actually a business model that evolved from these community college events, into a profitmaking company and they took the concept nationwide with a TV-show and a live-web-broadcast.Innovationplant got some government funding and other sponsors because they involve engineers, product developers, patent specialists to try to create new patentable innovations, new green technology which should reduce emissions and lower our dependance on oil and employing more people to increase our swedish economy.And of course to try to inspire young boys and girls to choose engineering educations.
http://www.innovationplant.sehttp://youtu.be/sub9EGHHaTohttp://youtu.be/5Nv0yt0Lq1g
(my community college have no info on the web about the event)
I would love to help get you started with this model.I know all the details and logistics around the arrangement.And I am graduated in Service Design and Development.Contact me with a message on Facebook if you want.

You Scandinavians have it down. Thanks, that sounds like an awesome project! Is there a link? Could be a model for something similar here. And I love that its through community colleges! Making it income accessible everyone who wants to learn is so key.

I can tell you about a great lowcost event here at the community college in Gvle, Sweden. 3-4 times per year they organize 24Hour-instant-incubator-brainstormers, open to students of all disciplines.4-5 companies gets invited to each event, in the morning before the start they each present themselves, about their areas, expertise and ambitions, and sometimes they can formulate a specific problem/obstacle infront of all students.During 24 hours the students team up in loose voluntary groups to brainstorm, sketch and develop as many ideas as they can.They are free to change groups or share ideas all along.A moderator or two makes sure there is always a minimum of 3 students working in each group, and that ideas that is rejected during the night still gets documented, so it can be picked up and improved upon, if it is plenty of time later on.Of course the companies will organize with computers to give access to company webpages. Mentors, specialists are available on telephone for eventual specific questions throughout the night. And the companies will fix healthy food, beverages and nutrition to keep students awake all the time.There is presentations after the 24H-time-limit is up, and local media is invited and so on. Awards is handed out to special ideas : for environmentally friendly thinking and other categories.So the companies gets plenty inspiration, ideas, concepts aswell as contact with future employees.Moderators assemble all information digitally and distributes afterwards to anyone involved.And students gets great influence and motivation from socialising with other students they would not normally interact with. And this scheme also helps little with removing some stereotypes and prejudices between professions.

how_can_we_reduce_toxicity_that_makes_us.description:
Mercury from coal burning plants pollutes our air 24/7. DDT has returned to the Western US on the winds from China. 5% of the weight of furniture foam is toxic fire retardants. Many household products contain harmful chemicals.  And the list goes on.

Rising levels of toxicity are one of the main causes of epidemic levels of diseases like cancer, heart disease, autism, allergies, asthma, chemical sensitivity, chronic fatigue, arthritis, and more.
how_can_we_reduce_toxicity_that_makes_us.creator: fcb1dc6f540886cd1905b62c0a723c4e

comments.text: Emissions and toxicity must be somehow handled with global & international legislation due to the ease of spread with winds and water.I do not know what instance could take on this role... perhaps the United Nations ? what legal right do they have to impose legal actions and fines on those that pollute?

Nicole, I think there could be more supportive regulations but they don't totally prevent alternatives. We need to support businesses to compete to be the cleaner brand. Consumers are already comparing products for toxicity on sites like GoodGuys, whose founder Dara told me the other day that health concerns are the most common reason for checking products, despite what companies or sustainability activists think the priorities are or should be. This issue is already customer driven--in the words of the new business paradigm. I am in Berkeley, i should meet your mother!

Paul, this is a really important idea. My mom is toxicology professor at UC Berkeley so I hear about this stuff ALL of the time. It's difficult because so much of it happens at the state regulatory level. I think it ultimately is going to be a matter of grassroots advocacy - educating people, and then getting stuff on the ballot. The tough part is that often times as a consumer, the option to buy the safe products isn't really there (i.e., furniture without flame retardant) or super expensive. So, I want to say, let's make more safer products, but what do you do when the regulatory environment doesn't really allow it?

how_can_we_reduce_toxicity_that_makes_us.title: How can we Reduce Toxicity that makes us sick?

_how_can_we_tackle_illiteracy_on_a_globa.description:
There have been many great concepts mentioned involving improving
educational resources, encouraging independence and fostering youth
empowerment on a global scale.

Focusing on digital learning opportunities like the Hole-in-the-Wall kiosks
and the Khan academy seem to be a great way to give children across the
world access to  education. However, what about taking it one step
further and addressing digital education for non English speakers.
Often, when children who have limited access to educational resources finally do get
their hands on reading material, it is not in their native language.  This
can be extremely frustrating and may slow their learning process or deter
them altogether. Enabling children to access digital learning tools in their
mother tongue will motivate early learners to gain literacy skills by making
them more relevant, and fostering the capacity to enrich their cultural
identity and strengthen their community.
_how_can_we_tackle_illiteracy_on_a_globa.creator: e8a544dfeb23db4961af3949cb3eb143

comments.text: I like the idea of promoting education and literacy in a child's native language for a couple of reasons. First, and obviously, it gives kids more immediate access to learning through reading in a language they already know. But it also, I would guess, help ensure the protection and promotion of global cultures, many of which are being lost through globalization. It makes me think of the work the Pachamama Alliance is doing in Ecuador (pachamama.org) to help advance the standard of living of the Achuar people while also ensuring that their culture and traditions don't literally get lost in translation...Great concept!
I totally agree with Ashley's point of view!
Congratulations on making it to the final 9 on the agenda! Well done!http://reasonedprogression.wordpress.com

Making initial connections between sounds and letters works best in the mother tongue. Once that connection is made, it becomes easier to introduce words from other languages for children to compare and contrast. It's fun and mind expanding to find out how many different ways there are of naming one animal. Even if a child does not have the opportunity to become fluent in other languages, learning about how people speak differently in other places is valuable in building bridges of tolerance and understanding. These children's children may have more opportunity to interact with the wider world. How are we preparing this generation to accept and nurture their poly-cultured children?

When I was in Kenya last week, I had the opportunity discuss his issue with a teacher, she explain to me that she often has to go back to the child tribe language to get them to click on the relationship between letter and sound, she has covered the walls with drawing and underneath the name in Kiswahili or Tribe language, because they have no access to written material.
Speaking several languages is an invaluable wealth, which unable us to understand other and accept our differences.

I totally agree that it's important to establish language as a global common language (charity foundation comment), but learning how to read using visual tools (modern method) only works in your mother tongue, how can you make a child understand "D" like in "Dog" if for he sees a "Chien". It's easier to build on what the child knows, and then move on to english.

When we encourage people to become literate in their mother tongue we support and value their culture. When we encourage people to become literate in English, we invite them to join our conversation. Both together will work. Kids can learn to write stories about their lives in their first language and translate them into English. So can adults if they want to and have time.

Isabelle  so great to see you here after meeting you in Kenya this week! I agree with you on enabling children in their mother tongue. (obviously English could be added later if desired) 
Adam (Charity-Foundation Global-Firm) I'm surprised that you prioritise English given your earlier post about Identity. Doesn't one's mother tongue provide the cornerstone of identity?
I think that it is especially important to support the education of the english language, which turned out to be the, though regrettably unofficial, established global language.

_how_can_we_tackle_illiteracy_on_a_globa.title: How can we tackle illiteracy on a global scale?

how_can_we_create_an_environment_in_whic.description: Social enterprises, and the more socially active regular companies, are at the forefront of change in societies, and even across borders. In recent years they have proven to be more efficient in improving lives than governments have. I believe that the power of social enterprises can be better leveraged if governments on all levels create the right circumstances for change to happen, in stead of acting in it themselves. By right circumstances I mean a fair and level playing field for both social enterprises and individuals; fair and accurate regulation and enforcement thereof; and a (social) safety net for issues that are not (yet) tackled by social enterprises.
how_can_we_create_an_environment_in_whic.creator: 6fed0e6f1ba44f0520bc14fceee3663d

comments.text:
Thanks for putting this up.  It aligns nicely with many of my own thoughts and ideas.  I really appreciate your list of resources.
I did a major project with Urban American Indians to create what we called "The Urban American Indian Tribe".  Their compelling issue was being re-located to the Santa Clara County area from over 100 different tribes in the 1950's.  
They wanted help in conceptualizing and actually creating a new paradigm for integrating traditions, projects and ways for the entire community and traditions to survive living in an urban environment.  It was a totally amazing project, with many stories.  I was lucky to be able to facilitate, as a non-Indian, the development of the American Indian Alliance of Santa Clara County which continues to this day.
I add this because it was holistic, very compelling, hard, challenging and totally unusual.  We were able to develop a methodology together which helped them secure congruent ways to continually meet American Indian challenges, mixing traditions, away from their reservations.
I really love the idea of whole systems thinking and believe we need to be thinking strategically along these lines.

I love your work. I made a sustainable whole-system framework called Globalfirm. http://openideo.com/open/what-is-the-global-challenge-that-most-concerns-you-right-now-and-that-global-innovation-leaders-could-begin-to-solve/agenda-concepts/is-the-economic-system-a-design-what-value-do-you-see-in-my-designed-system/ Do you like the chart? / How do you feel about it? Thanks for your book-hints.

seed_cathedral_better_city_better_life.description:
The World Expo 2010 in Shanghai saw British designer Tom Heatherwick's latest creation steal the show with it's beautiful simplicity and elegance. The project was a collaboration between Kew Gardens in London and the Millennium Seedbank project, whose mission is to collect the seeds of 25% of the world's plant species by 2020. 

"The holes in the 1 metre thick wood diaphram structure forming the visitor space inside the Seed Cathedral were drilled with great geometric accuracy to ensure precise placement of the aluminium sleeves through which the optic fibre filaments are inserted. This was achieved using 3D computer modelling data, fed into a computer controlled milling machine."

"After the Expo, just as dandelion seeds are blown away and disperse on the breeze, the Seed Cathedral's 60,000 optic hairs, each one containing the huge potential of life, will be distributed across China and the UK to hundreds of schools as a special legacy of the UK Pavilion at the 2010 Shanghai Expo."
seed_cathedral_better_city_better_life.creator: 9af96c4abe78b8a4ff4841ab1c9d1104

prioritize_solutions_not_problems.description: Bjorn Lomborg argues that the global challenges we should work on solving are the ones that have known solutions that will have a big impact.
prioritize_solutions_not_problems.creator: faddcd3050d0b666958d7f73f81ff81d

comments.text: This talk is really good. I got quite a bit from it, yet I don't really agree that solving problems in isolation works as the best way to prioritize. The best solutions work to solve multiple problems at once in a synergistic way. An example so you don't think I'm just being fluffy: http://www.sulabhinternational.org/ works to provide hygienic toilet facilities for the urban poor. Their facilities serve over 10 million people in India every day. These facilities work on disease prevention directly through sanitation services and generate biogas for clean air cooking fuel and generating electricity. The residue from methane generation is water and clean compost. Most of the carbon and micronutrients are returned to the soil where they belong. So, this one solution works on disease prevention, malnutrition, poverty from lack of employment and climate change.
Great Nefaur! And that's exactly why we are starting my creating a library of innovative *solutions* from around the world in our Inspiration Phase.

prioritize_solutions_not_problems.title: Prioritize solutions, not problems

open_up_communication_with_parliament.description: Gudras Galvas is a site where members of parliament have a profile, and can communicate openly with the public about topics that are being discussed in parliament, or should be.
open_up_communication_with_parliament.creator: 6fed0e6f1ba44f0520bc14fceee3663d

comments.text: Appreciation for this goes to Providus in Latvia. This organisation, linked to the Open Society Institute, is doing a lot to improve the democracy here in Latvia.

Nice one, Arjun! I know some officials in the U.S. are starting to become more "social media savvy", and they've created and are managing their own Twitter accounts (yes, they're tweeting!) in an attempt to be more open...I don't think I've ever come across anything like a website such as the one in this inspiration.

Great stuff Arjan! Looks like a well-devised site (though our Latvian is a bit rough to appreciate the content ; ) We also note WebCitizen from Brazil in this space: http://www.webcitizen.com.br/en/ What other examples do folks know of? Has anyone participated on a local site of this kind? And what about examples of actionable success on the ground? Are best practices starting to emerge? Do politicians need e-training? Do some platforms work better in some countries and not in others? So much to think about on this one.

I think that in the UK there is a website that allows you to report infrastructure issues (road damages etcetera). This helps the local government monitor road quality, and prioritize repair activity. A win-win situation, that is very direct and actionable.

Nice example! Looks like we've hit on some ways to make both the executive/administrative and legislative functions more open and innovative. What other areas of government could benefit from such an approach (probably wouldn't want the judicial system overun by trial by mob though!)?

open_up_communication_with_parliament.title: Open communication with government: Gudras Galvas (Latvia)

equip_the_poor_to_educate_their_communit.description:
In 1997, at 16 years old, Peñaflorida started a youth group in his high school aimed at diverting students attention away from street gangs, and towards community activism and personal development. Joined by other classmates, they named the group "Dynamic Teen Company".
Dynamic Teen Company started as a friendship club of around 20 members, with an aim of providing youth awareness projects, talent and self-development activities, and community services. They partnered with Club 8586, another community service organization operating in the area.
They eventually pioneered the idea of the "pushcart classroom", wherein pushcarts were stocked with school materials such as books, pens, tables, and chairs, and then used on Saturdays to recreate school settings in unconventional locations such as the cemetery or trash dump.
equip_the_poor_to_educate_their_communit.creator: 96f79338ea6b1a2b9da850e94922a102

comments.text: Great inspiration. I like the idea of a movement that starts from such a basic idea and then grows to have such an impact.
Wonderful inspiration and the empowering of community from within.
I think this is a fantastic idea. I love the idea of a pushcart classroom. An incredibly inspirational inspiration!

And this can be a message to teenagers beyond the Filipino community. Society needs to know that teenagers just want to feel like they belong.  So we should keep them out of gangs and encourage them to build friendship clubs with their peers that will allow them to help out with community service.

This is great! Folks can also check out more at: http://dynamicteencompany.org/ And how brilliant that it started as a friendship club  imagine if more of us took our Facebook interaction to such heights!
Here are the CNN Heroes clips put together of Efren and his team's efforts: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zZEqPCT9jBQ

equip_the_poor_to_educate_their_communit.title: Equip the poor to educate their community (Philippines)

comments.text: Johan, great point!  Hopefully other companies have noticed Walmart's move, even from a budget perspective, and are following suit.  And hopefully enough people are talking about it that other companies notice that too.  That consumers care about these environmental and energy consumption decisions.  The irony for me is that, even though I respect Walmart's decision from an energy usage standpoint, I would still rather shop at Target.  How's that for shooting myself in the foot?!:)  Putting aside for the moment what that says about me and how shallow I may or may not be.... I think the lesson here is that brands must consider their entire identity.  But maybe that is a discussion for another challenge!Thanks again for your comment!

Nicole, thanks for the comment!  And thanks for the link.  The work Architecture for Humanity is doing looks very interesting.  And good work that should be done as well!  Should Architecture for Humanity get its own inspiration?  Maybe you should post it!Thanks again!

Eric, Thanks for the comment!  With a little success there always comes the danger of falling into complacency and maintaining the status quo.  Much easier than seeking new innovation!  It is the rare company or individual that continually challenges it's own thinking and beliefs to test if they could be done better.  The Walmart example is a testament that even purely market driven influences, not just a noble desire to do the right thing, can lead to innovation and greater energy efficiency.Thanks again for your comment!

Yes! Lovely!And great results from some company must become made more available to other industries, so that anyone can see that turning more green is profitable. and making it easy for them to make comparisons to see that it will not be expensive investment!And that we consumers are interested and really cares about such initiatives, so that we can with our collective consumer-influence make them all compete and fight amongst themselves to change and get most efficient and hopefully carbon-neutral.

On a similar note, Architecture for Humanity has been doing some interesting work in this area around building safety and best practices (http://architectureforhumanity.org/). They have also been doing work around sustainable building practices, especially in post-disaster areas like Haiti. Super cool organization to keep an eye on.

Sometimes, as individuals or societies, we take for granted how things are made and how they are designed to better our lives. The buck stops there where no new enriching ideas come across that can even make that design better; but your inspiration reminds us we can move forward. Great post and examples!

involve_and_fund_universities_in_problem.description: Universities and young people around the world are great sources of inspiration.   Including practical problem solving in university education is a great way to educate our next generation of leaders as well as solve problems along the way.    Let's not just teach social business as a separate subject in our universities but make it an integral part of many other existing courses putting engineering, innovation and technology to practical use.
involve_and_fund_universities_in_problem.creator: e3cf33cebe2e6c3e1f8d52015a33936b

comments.text: A great example in Bangladesh is CellBazaar www.cellbazaar.com/web/ .   Started by the very talented Kamal Quader and bourne out of an MIT competition.   Whilst you can see it online through the link, its real power is that it is equally easy to use by mobile phone via SMS.   It serves c2c, b2b, and c2b equally well.   The final transaction is not online:  the system stops with a transfer of mobile numbers. Whilst the customer offers generally get the headlines, if you wanted to start a chicken farm in Bangladesh then this would be the place to find 1000  one day old layers!    It has been perfectly designed for the market it intended to serve has been running for about 6 years now, is hugely successful and has changed the lives of many.What's important about this example is that it was financed with venture capital and there was a connection via the academic institute to this.   Not only do we need to encourage creative and practical thinking in our engineering and technology students but we need to link this with adventurous forms of financing.

What I like here, is the idea to make it a integrated part of different courses and work areas - the future challanges need integrated teams and ideas to solve them - so start as early as possible to train that mind set and experiences. And like Anne wrote in her comment, having the chance to work and to try out the concepts and ideas in real world helps go get a feeling about the needs and effects it can have in reality. And, lets unleash the minds of our youth:-)

In a "Design-Business Link" class at the University of Baltimore, a design professor teamed up with a professor from the Business school. During the second half of the semester we were divided into groups and teamed up with a local non-profit. Not only did it feel more meaningful, but it was a good reality check to what working with clients in the "real world" is like (that you don't necessarily learn in the classroom).

Fab Samantha! Stanford are also doing great things with their Entrepreneurial Design for Extreme Affordability programme http://bit.ly/bPIixe and MIT Wondering what similar programs folks on OpenIDEO know about?

involve_and_fund_universities_in_problem.title: Involve and fund universities in problem solving

innovation_in_organizational_design.description:
The focus on innovation in different sectors, such as technology, government, philanthropy, business and non-profits is exciting.  As we explore the reach of technology, in our world-wide life, we are missing an important ingredient for success. 

As we look at generating new ideas, we have to be equally interested in the organizational systems charged with implementing these changes.  Our current organizational systems were not designed to support innovation.  So even if an idea is remarkable, the delivery system may not be capable of doing the job.  

A focus on systems design from conception to implementation needs to go hand in hand with new ideas.  In many cases we already have the capacity, resources, knowledge and skills needed, they just need to be deployed and leveraged in new ways.

We have examples every day of redundancy, duplication of effort and spending the same dollar over and over again. Organizational re-design is part of innovation.
innovation_in_organizational_design.creator: e024f9589c1e9d64b34cb1257d9c9dfc

comments.text:
Thanks to everyone who has read, commented and evaluated this concept.  As I drill down more specifically, I have focused on a developing an "Open Government Grant System", which would integrate all the principles of the Open Government Directive (OGD), regardless of the grant focus.  From conception through implementation the entire system would be congruent, capacity building, collaborative and citizen/community participation.  It will promote transparency,  meaningful evaluation and best practices, which could be cataloged and shared.
I am in the process of writing it up, as simply as possible, and sending it along to some federal gatekeepers for consideration.  I think it would work just as well in philanthropy. It is innovative and I'd love to share it with the OpenIDEO community for feedback and ideas. 
I am taking on the federal grant making system, because I know the grant system well, we have the Obama OGD, a bulk of Congressional allocations go through the grant system (separate from contracts), and the system is old, worn out, and inefficient.
Writing this up will demonstrate one, concrete example of Innovation in Organizational Design.

I evaluated and applauded this concept because we share a lot of the same aspirations.  While you have the right idea to ask these things, we can go deeper into the question ourselves and form creative ways to solving the issue.  
You said,"..we already have the capacity, resources, knowledge and skills needed, they just need to be deployed and leveraged in new ways. We have examples every day of redundancy, duplication of effort and spending the same dollar over and over again. Organizational re-design is part of innovation."
While I agree with you on having the capacity, resources, knowledge and skills we need to make life easier for all of us, I feel that the answer is very simple.  We must coordinate advanced technology and existing resources with a humane global systems approach.  If I could have built on this concept, I would have.

Andrea, I think this is an important issue that affects many of the other ideas posted in this challenge.  No new idea with any impact can be executed without the help of some organization (or government).  These ideas need the right kind of support and execution to be more than just drawings and words.

Thanks Ashley for your thoughts on this idea. I like the question for the i20 to think about and act on. I would include re-design, alongside your clearly phrased solution, if an organization and process can be salvaged.  We need to evaluate organizations against what successful innovative organization's would "look like", if they were "high functioning" and  designed to include innovative thinking, culture and execution", as you suggest.
I don't think there is a shortage of solid, innovative ideas and concepts, I do think we avoid the harder issues of organizational capability to support and carry out the ideas, as well as the needed accountability for doing it. 
These constant system breakdowns stop us from reaching goals, solutions and the ability to experiment with concrete, innovative solutions. By its nature, a badly designed organizational system, easily leads to redundancy of effort and cost, terrible employee moral and lack of initiative, regardless of the merit of the innovative concept or idea.

Great conversation happening here on what I see as a fundamentally important question: how are we supposed to innovate, create change, think outside the box, etc, if most of us don't operate within organizations (and organizational cultures) set up to support these kinds of behaviors and attitudes?Since this is about posing a question for the i20 to solve, would you say the question then would be about how we can build organizations that are nimble, flexible and sophisticated enough to support innovation (and by extension, failure)? Thanks,Ashley

Hi Andrea, Thanks for posting this, my major area of research has been organizational design and I see this need. I think the problem begins with basic assumption that you identified as the difference between grading people and continuous improvement. Change agents need to focus on making explicit the problem and alternative, I might put it this way: 
One model of organization views people as the problem and the solutions are control and individual grading and incentives. This creates an organizational culture of mistrust, blame, and fear that undermines collaboration, risk taking and innovation. 
The alternative organizational design views the problem as the complexity of systems. Since systems create results, it makes no sense to grade and blame individuals entirely. The focus then is on collaboration to assess the system and improve its processes. This requires collective incentives aligned to strategic goals, like serving "customers." 
I'm just finishing an article on this new paradigm of customer focused organization: its strategy and chain reaction of social and economic benefits. The contrast is between a precise definition of bureaucracy and the  total quality organization. There is also a contrast between the shareholder and stakeholder models of firms.

Hi, 
I think this is an outstanding idea and really support it. Since the complexity of any system is fundamentally limited by its organisational paradigm, if we want to have a richer more complex world we need better organisational paradigms. Otherwise, we will drown in the complexity we create. I am developing a leadership model based on 'sustainable flourishing'; the goal is to find a way for human communities to grow vigorously and in such a way that they enhance their environments capacity to enable more life. The goal is not just to be sustainable by being carbon neutral or such, it is to actively grow in such a way that more life is enabled through one's growth. For example, a tree grows vigorously consuming resources but it also continually 'gives back' and upon its death all of its bounty is returned to the environment. A tree allows more life than it consumes and this is the model we need if we are to succeed!

Hi Ashley,
Great clarifying question and you are right on both counts.  I'm suggesting our current, primarily government and many non-profit agency infrastructure's, are not prepared or designed to support innovation and change, either structurally or professionally. 
In the public sector, there are rarely incentives and many perceived risks, to step ahead of the curve. At every turn, the 'what's in it for me" question comes into play organizationally and professionally.  Government agency personnel are skilled at surviving different election cycles and leadership changes, regardless of policy initiatives. 
We are currently experiencing this play out in the Obama Administration's Open Government Directive (OGD). OGD emphasizes collaboration, participation and transparency, which had led to game changers in technology, not necessarily systemically.  This is a big worry to me.
Innovation requires a tolerance for failure and risk, many government agencies and non-profits are fearful of failure analysis. Quantitative and qualitative evaluation is perceived as a grading system, not as part of a continuous improvement. Recently, requested government data has been described as "low hanging fruit" (Sunlight Foundation).
Many agencies were caught with their pants down over available data to support transparency.  They simply didn't have the data or much of what was called for, no one had built this capacity into the system and no one really thought it would be asked for so publicly.
Integrated into tall of this (and more), is the notion that core innovative concepts are not well understood, or even at all, by many of the people and agencies charged with implementation.  To my knowledge, there has been no capacity training on OGD, no step back to look at organizational change and infrastructure, no "think-tank" opportunities to look at current organizational design or capability to integrate core concepts into new norms, which would effect program outcomes.
This could be because of job description, as well as fear of losing power, control and influence over the current system. These behaviors are difficult to uncover and even when uncovered, not changed.  Innovation in organizational systems needs confident leaders and champions to support the fundamental culture and values of an innovative organization, definitely in government. Good ideas need to stick and people, and the organizational system, has to be designed, inherently, to support it.
I know this is a long answer to a smart shorter question.

Hi Andrea, this is very interesting. I wonder if you could explain more what you mean by "organizational re-design"? Do you mean restructuring government agencies? Rearranging organizational charts at businesses or nonprofits? This part is unclear to me.It's very true that in order to successfully implement a new innovation, you need to have an organization and a set of people with the capacity, skills and spirit to be able to follow through. Some of it perhaps is restructuring the very organization that's doing the innovating, while some of it might also be encouraging behavior and attitude changes in the people doing the implementing.

innovation_in_organizational_design.title: Innovation in Organizational Design

millennium_development_goals.description: These Millennium Development Goals (http://www.un.org/milleniumgoals) were agreed to by all members of the United Nations, as well as >20 other international organizations. As about 2/3 of the time has passed from the launch of the Millennium Development Goals in 2000 to the target achievement date of 2015, the UN recently held a summit (http://www.un.org/en/mdg/summit2010) to assess progress, share approaches, and commit to an action agenda.
millennium_development_goals.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Good call Vincent  "What success stories are out there that can inspire development?" We're starting to see some rolling in  who else has great existing examples of the MGD's being met in action?

I think the UN did a great job in identifying and highlighting the Millenium Development Goals but the UN is cumbersome and bureaucratic; it focusses on processes rather than outcomes and so is not the right organisation to make the progress happen.   It's also not just about social entrepreneurs and purpose driven business - in Bangladesh, where I live and work, any business which creates rural employment for people who are poor might loosely be called a social business.   As such facilitating and supporting business in areas where you might not at first see opportunity is the way to go.   In Bangladesh donor funding into microfinance has been huge over the past 20 years and there are positives and negatives from this but more importantly mf has been funded at the expense of SMEs and it's only just recently that we are starting to see that change.   Encouraging and facilitating local SMEs is the way to create employment in the poorest areas and as such reduce poverty.   Deal with MDG1 and the remainder will fall into place much more easily.

Thanks all for the support and great point Samantha. Business is a key and powerful part of society that needs to be involved. The UN recognizes this to a degree as evidenced here: http://www.undp.org/partners/business/ . However, more can be done to inspire and incentivize companies to get more involved. Innovation contests? Supporting the development of purpose-driven businesses? Any other ideas?

I think that the field should be opened up so that this is no longer a remit only for governments and for implementation through NGOs but rather business should be involved particularly for implementation.  Implementation needs to be much more 'outcomes' focussed rather than 'process' focussed.

Couldn't agree more. The goals exist, were universally approved, and are reaching their deadline at an alarming pace. Nothing would please me more than to have world leaders re-commit and accelerate the achievement of these goals.

YES! Great inspiration. The MDGs set a framework, and there are some successes. However, some of them are rather calculated successes, more than real life ones. Finding ways for governments to deliver on these promises is definitely something that should be on agendas.

millennium_development_goals.title: Millennium Development Goals

how_do_we_incorporate_empathy_into_our_e.description: It is not possible to infuse our work, services, products and ideas with true value unless we can put ourselves in the shoes of those we serve first, before serving our own needs. In order to create true innovation, we need to design new outcomes to life. Designing new outcomes can only come about through adding two key ingredients: an empathic approach or mindset and creativity. One without the other will be result in a deficient outcome. The way to achieve this is by creating frameworks that will focus designers from multiple points of view, but also sensitize them to the needs of their stakeholders. Practically, this means encouraging teaching more widely techniques such as six hats thinking; or simple design frameworks and showing how they can be applied to business, product design, services, relationships and any endeavor that needs a remarkable outcome.
how_do_we_incorporate_empathy_into_our_e.creator: 82682fad8048718eb7b5400271582699

comments.text: James, love your formulation (slightly restated here) of Empathy x Creativity = Positive Impact. And Sabra, agree with your insight that it's important to find a sustainable route to compassion that recognizes and addresses the needs of yourself and others in tandem. I think Andrenna begins to address this in her concept on interconnection: http://bit.ly/fM9k5n

@Sabra: first of all, thank you very much for the comment and for reaching out to explore the ideas further. I want you to know that I appreciate it. With regard to your perspective - you may be entirely accurate. The only think I feel I can offer is the following: 1. A deficiency in the method to reaching a goal does not invalidate the goal - it only exposes it as deficient. I think you do agree with the concept in general so at least we are on the same page there. 2. My hope is that we can train/mentor/guide/nuture empathy in people using many different techniques. At this point, I think I am more focused on getting everyone to just understand the goal and understand it in the same way. How we get there is the challenge. And I hope solutions on how to do this from you and other fine people on this forum will probably do more for the idea than others have done in the past.
@Thao : i did watch that too..and i loved it. You should also read or listen to Linchpin by Seth Godin - that is very telling as well.

James, I absolutely love your image and general concept. However, I have some disagreement with your argument. Paul Hess points out that many are not living what they preach in terms of empathy. This is true in my experience, and I think I might have some idea why. When people are trained that the ideal is to meet others needs before considering their own, they are left with the choice of being "selfish" or of having unrecognized needs of their own which cripple their ability to respond to the needs of others. As an example, I offer a classic: Alienated rich youth tries to act compassionately, but has no concept of his or her own need for community connection and habilitation. Youth is unable to care for themselves emotionally, and is clueless bordering on abusive to the people they try to help. The exercise in compassion is less than successful. The youth becomes bitter, blames the people who "don't want to be helped"and becomes the next reactionary, unthinking conservative.(as opposed to conservatives who do think, which there are many)If people are encouraged to accept and understand their own real needs, they are much more able to respond to the needs of others in an effective way.
What I like is Yehuda Bergs Power of Kabbalah. Pro- (- versus Re-) acting equals sharing, creates sustained light. It is the matter of how we are able to transform in our lifes.
This concept comes just in time. I just finished watching an inspiring RSA animation on TED where Jeremy Rifkin talks about "the empathic civilization". I highly recommend it - http://on.ted.com/8jcI

how_do_we_incorporate_empathy_into_our_e.title: How do we incorporate empathy into our everyday work, thoughts and outcomes ?

how_can_service_design_transform_governm.description:
Governments today are still the main arbitrators for anything to happen within a given country. Unfortunately, instead of introducing predictability, governments tend to increase the level of uncertainty for anything to happen. 

Service design's goal is to ensure that all touch points work together to provide superior customer service. Service design can help governments in understanding citizens needs, identifying root causes, and then designing effective and sustainable services. 

The issue at hand then is how? How can you really transform an institution as complex as a government (let alone international or supranational institutions)? 

There is a disjunction between governments and all other institutions, how can service design bring about collaborative change? How can technology be used so that governments from underdeveloped countries can achieve socioeconomic leapfrog? How can governments create new networks for social change?
how_can_service_design_transform_governm.creator: cc5c3a176e895dabfb815af7eb7424e1

comments.text: A question I often deal with is what if in order to change a government system or institution you have to roll back certain positions, perks and habits to create a new foundation. People are often resistant to change only because the way of doing things in the past is so ingrained (especially in government!).

Interesting point Val, privatization of certain services increases competition and a competitive landscape usually leads to increased efficiency. In addition to outsourced services there are other services, like education, that cannot be completely outsourced. Your point raises an interesting question, could a new partnership (public-private) be more effective? If so, how can service design help the new partnership in creating user centered, effective services?

Interesting question.  At least in the developed world (esp in the U.S.), so much of government service delivery is actually executed by third-party contractors, whether huge companies (like IBM), or through more specialized, smaller, often IT-focused vendors.  These vendors often assume responsibility for delivering products, and claim to do so at lower cost, and with greater innovation (because they don't have same day-to-day talent and resource constraints as governments).   People debate this trend as good or bad, but it's definitely a big presence in U.S.
Can government outsourcing work in developing world? Is there a sector of high performing, government-serving vendors?  Will these institutions be open to it?

Pablo, I totally agree with you.. it's the idea of a "Charter government".. maybe there could be a specific service within a government and treat it as a "charter govt service" to make the concept more feasible
A truly interesting and inspiring formulation...

awesome!, i wonder though if the government itself in some countries would be interested in implementing such tools if it goes against their own agenda.
heres an interesting articlehttp://blogs.worldbank.org/ic4d/design-thinking-for-government-services-what-happens-when-the-past-limits-our-vision-of-the-future
cheers
Provocative question Adriana! And perhaps there's some inspiration to be found here: http://bit.ly/gdvOdC

Nice one Adriana. And here's a bunch of service design tools used to deal with complex systems: http://bit.ly/ql11u and some more examples of service design at play in the public sector: http://bit.ly/gEsDXo + http://bit.ly/eiro7q

nurture_and_grow_the_middle_class.description: In the last 30 years, the average annual salary in the United States rose roughly 10 percent while CEO compensation grew from 39 times the pay of an average worker to 1,000 times the pay of an ordinary worker.  We think we have progressed since the beginning of the century - but are we starting to regress? And is this trend taking hold in other nations around the globe?
nurture_and_grow_the_middle_class.creator: 68c143efc7d461941d72e30c58730fd5

comments.text:
The very idea of upward mobility has been an incentive in America for a long time and is intimately connected to the "American Dream".  A belief each generation will do better than the previous one is fundamental to how we have incentivized our lives, direction, beliefs in hard work making a difference, drive towards education, our embedded values that we "can always do better and it matters".
This connection to the "social contract" by which we "play by the rules" is tied to upward mobility through legal means.  It is not improbable to think our crime rate will go up, our ability to support others collaboratively in a more competitive society, the "what's in it for me" philosophy may find a center stage at a time when we know sharing ideas will make a difference in our society.  If people don't believe their effort makes any difference to their own well-being, they are more likely to bail out on participation in society at large.
This fast/slow elimination of the middle class is dialectically opposed to stated goals encouraging new paradigms in transparency, collaboration, citizen participation, fundamental principles of democracy and accountability to something bigger than to oneself.  This is definitely an issue effecting all of us in both developed and under developed countries.  We have to believe we can make a difference in our own lives and the lives of others to make our democratic system viable.

this is very important obstacle in most regions. Wealth-concentration and wealth-accumulation to a small group of people or to a small group of multinational corporations.It is serious threats to both local and international business structure, the democracy, the innovation processes, the ethical side of life for middle-class and for working-class.
poor and working-class uses around 100% (sometimes even more, with borrowed money) of all existing money to consume the bare essentials : food and rent. And if their choices gets inhibited by multinational corporations and declining consumer options, we could get the results of 1-2% of the population owns 90% or more of the existing global resources.

nurture_and_grow_the_middle_class.title: Nurture and grow the middle class

how_do_we_broaden_our_focus_from_economi.description: Studies show that GDP growth, after passing the point where basic needs are met, produces diminishing returns for our actual life satisfaction and happiness.  Other factors, like social relations, health, meaningful work, freedom, caring for others, etc. become far more important for our overall wellbeing. However, we often continue to chase the treadmill of economic growth, at the expense of these other critical things. How do we shift from a narrow focus on economic growth (Gross Domestic Product) to a holistic pursuit of genuine wellbeing (Gross National Happiness)?
how_do_we_broaden_our_focus_from_economi.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Thought you all might be interested that Somerville in the United States, recently added wellbeing/happiness measurement to its census survey: http://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/01/us/01happiness.html

Quality of life measures as part of public finance markets' ratings of city life for all would ratchet up the accountancy and baselines globally. I have suggested an all-in composite called sustainable resiliency for regional quality of life equilibrium and gaps.  With such measures, public and private programs and activities that remove gaps in sustainable resiliency would be monetized, and thereby attract the public and private funding and social capital needed to speed raising quality of life agnostically, without politicization of every issue into pitting stakeholder groups against each other.  Let's find the math of collaboration, and let that math drive a New Wall Street calculus for public finance of our global cities.

I also like the idea of this paradigm shift.  We can look to Bhutan for guidance, though this same process would be different on a larger scale: http://www.the9billion.com/2011/02/27/like-bhutan-should-we-be-measuring-national-happiness-instead-of-gdp/ The underlying thread here is that health, both physical and mental are not weighed into our business practices and they should be.  Happiness and health should be measures of performance for how a society is doing and this is still fringe activity when it should be main stream.
Congratulations on making it to the final 9 on the agenda! Well done!http://reasonedprogression.wordpress.com

I  applauded and evaluated your concept, and I love the humanistic motives, yet I feel like the question your asking has been asked here and elsewhere many, many times before only in different ways.  My concept certainly covers the same question, however, poses a solution.  I think you'd be very much interested.
If I could have built on this, I most definitely would have.

Great post, Vincent! I agree, we should pursue accomplishment in wellbeing as we pursue accomplishment in business, politics, education, etc.I think we'd find that the pursuit of wellbeing, as a broad foundation, would exponentially elevate the value, depth and richness of business, politics, education, etc.
Thanks Thao. Yes, "Me to We" is definitely a big part of it!
Loving the Einstein quote Vincent. How about, "How do we foster a "Culture of We" instead of a "Culture of Me?"

Thanks Nicholas. Your expansion on the psychology research methodology and applying it to mobiles is a great example of what's possible in terms of measurement. In fact, here are 2 projects (from Harvard University and London School of Economics) that are doing exactly that: http://www.trackyourhappiness.org/ , http://www.mappiness.org.uk/

Excellent ideas, Vincent.  Reading your post reminded me of a psychology research methodology used to quantify happiness.  Participants are given wristwatches devices for a week.  8 times a day, at random times, the watch would ring and the participant would fill out a short paper survey asking them what they were doing, how they were feeling on a scale of 1 to 10, feelings of loneliness/belongingness, etc.  Today, something similar could be done with texting and cellphones to help get a better quantitative picture of happiness.  Being able to say whether the average American had an overall happier week would be a powerful tool.

Agreed Nicholas. I had a work background in strategy consulting and academic background in computer science, both where quantification definitely has a lot of power. Metrics is a definite challenge, but not insurmountable, as seen by the measurements that are cropping up in various corners of the world from NEF to the country of Bhutan to recent popularization of various books/research on happiness. For example, in the US, think of the resources going into the census. It would definitely be possible to piggyback some questions on wellbeing there. Now imagine other avenues where such information could be collected from the voting polling booths to say phone apps that provide personal tracking and tips for increasing happiness while providing anonymous aggregate statistics for policy makers/researchers. Of course, these measurements will be a combination of qualitative and quantitative, directionally meaningful though by no means perfect. However, just recognizing and being aware of wellbeing as the end goal, can have profound impact. As Albert Einstein so eloquently put it, "Not everything that matters can be counted. Not everything that can be counted matters.
One of the largest challenges for this concept is metrics.  GDP is used partially because it is easily quantifiable.

Thanks for the support and link Meena! I'm a fan of NEF and their work on the Happy Planet Index...definitely worth a read through. I think the big challenge is how to integrate such thoughts, feelings, and actions (I believe who we truly are and are meant to be) into all areas of our lives.
Great call Vincent! You might be interested to check out the Happy Planet Index by  NEF (a think tank which explores "economics as if people and the planet mattered")http://www.happyplanetindex.org/

comments.text: Innovation leaders really do need to seriously address this issue. If there were globally enforced Take Back responsibilities placed on the brand owners and they were accountable for decommissioning their own products, it would create an even playing field for the industry to change the wasteful corporate behaviour and still be competitive.
Yes, this is great. Our junkyards are amazing; billions of dollars of once "high tech" stuff.

I think this demonstrates the point that many of us don't really know what is going on behind the scenes - what would we do differently if we really knew where the things in our daily lives come from and the process that they had to go through to get to us?
