how_can_we_share_social_innovation_best_.creator: 677b685af5345b36ecb6d35b4852cc5c

comments.text: Appropedia now has a listing for social innovation. It's under newest on the bottom right. http://www.appropedia.org/Welcome_to_Appropedia. It only has 4 listings so far, but anyone can contribute.

I am a huge advocate of documenting best practices in all sectors.  I am particularly focused on the public sector, grants which have been funded for millions of dollars, created significant, sustainable change and ultimately end up on some final report shelf at the funding agency.
I wrote a book on best practices in community policing, which was distributed to 7,000 local U.S. law enforcement agencies, but many of the lessons learned went way beyond that one sector.  
I received a $3M HHS Community Partnership Grant, which was an applied practice research project, conducted in real communities.  We discovered new planning and evaluation methodologies and a much deeper understanding of the intermediary agency's role in community change and resource deployment.  
After 5 years of federal reports and the discovery of best practices, which would benefit other communities, I am sure nothing was ever done past the final program and fiscal report.  The project has been sustained by those touched by it, but widespread sharing never occurred.
I imagine creating the opportunity, using on the ground research and technology, finding all these gems and creating a depository of best practices.  One which could certainly involve other sectors and emerging public-private partnerships.  I would love to work on a project like this.  By building on previously funded projects we could save so much money and build on previous wins. We have a huge, undiscovered bank account, needing attention sooner than later.  Thanks for bringing this subject up.

How about a meta-search engine for existing grassroots innovation databases? I'm sure there's a lot of databases all over the globe like the Honey Bee network:http://www.sristi.org/hbnew/honeybee_database.phpand:http://www.nif.org.in/innovation_db

The best resource I have seen so far is CK Prahalad's "The Fortune at the Bottom of the Pyramid," where he discusses everything from eye care models (Aravind) to CEMEX and other BOP businesses that have scaled and been profitable. It would be awesome if this information was all accessible in a spreadsheet or some searchable database by product or service, and specific project features.

Yes, this would be tremendously valuable. A really good wiki on social enterprise/social innovation could help people train themselves in this field and connect with real world learning experiences, as well as help people find inspiration and solutions for problems.

This is really a good one. Like you and Vincent, I've been thinking about this, but specifically for the field of environmental sustainability and energy efficiency. If you browse for this type of information in the web you can only find loose directories of tech vendors/providers and private databases hosted by large corporations that charge you a monstruous fee for information bits (on where to invest or which companies to look at). Some reports from these companies may cost 1-2K $, hence are extensively exclusive. You can also find nice apps for mobile phones that help you to be more energy-efficient but their algorithms are black-boxed and I doubt that they are adaptive.
I would add to all the fantastic comments that you've got for now, that to tackle properly the issue, future entrepreneurs, initiatives or anyone wanting to aggregate knowledge about social-environmental innovative tech and practices must:
- Do it open, so experts and practitioners all over the world can collaborate and share their expertise and experiences with the use of such tech and practices, so tech developers can learn from them- Do it free, therefore eliminating any barrier to knowledge for entrepreneurs wanting to launch any initiative- Do it adaptive, allowing the 'knowledge aggregator' to learn from user experience and update in a flexible way- Do it in community, in order to create the collaboration incentives needed to share knowledge and experience among practitioners

Very glad you posted this concept Nicole, as Ive previously been musing about this in my mind for awhile. Broadly sharing best practices that are holistically described from design to business models would really accelerate the adoption and evolution of successful social enterprise ideas. Arjan, I believe the wiki concept, if implemented flexibly, can accommodate a plurality of views: an article can cover multiple perspectives through sectioning, be tagged by multiple category meta-articles, linked to various example sub-articles and external sources, allow for philosophical discussion beyond the facts in a commenting section, etc. Of course, which part of a wiki someone chooses to read, contribute to, or compile to distribute would be up to him/her.

It seems like so much of this idea of sharing best practices (in this concept and in others) is about creating compelling, accessible storytelling about successful projects in addition to the standard things that might be collected for business models or innovation plans. As was mentioned in one of the inspirations, storytelling could help bring empathy to all sorts of different successful projects.

Re Pablo / Meena's comments - Could be something like a cross between Alex Osterwald's Business Model Generation (EXCELLENT resource) http://www.businessmodelgeneration.com/ , Appropedia and IDEO's Human-Centered Design toolkit. All are open and accessible online. I like the idea of interactive digital toolkit (Like IDEO's great HCD).

All - loving this discussion! Thank you Johan for the appropedia.org suggestion + Andrea for the wiki suggestion - both great ideas. That is exactly what I envision. I think Appropedia is the right start, I like how you can search by project type and then  applicable projects pop up. Would like to see further development into the business model / financing aspects of projects. This is a great idea of a central portal - now just to figure out a way to get people to add their project & information to the site.
Agreed Pablo  though we need to acknowledge that many at the base of the economic pyramid are using the internet via mobile phones so best practice info needs to be made available there also.

Centralizing, organizing, and making information available for everyone has been made possible thanks to the internet but it has become increasingly difficult to quality control it  . my question is : how can we unify the most up to date information and best practices, without disrupting the openness of the web?would this work as a tool kit for innovators perhaps?i really like your concept and would like to see where it goes, Cheers

Adding to Adriana's post about P&G's open innovation community, Chris Thoen's twitter feed http://twitter.com/cthoen [he leds open innovation at P&G] has some interesting posts and resources on open innovation, including examples beyond P&G. Knowledge management and sharing best practices on social innovations is critical to progress in all the industry areas that Nicole mentions in her concept. In particular, I think open innovation in healthcare [including healthcare in developing countries] will be particularly interesting - what partnerships are created and solutions developed addressing patient care and access.

Hi Nicole, This is a very important idea and something i have studied. Knowledge can be developed and shared through associations that are formalized networks between organizations, such as industry associations. A model for doing this is the Japanese Union of Scientists and Engineers, JUSE, explained in Robert Cole's book, Strategies for Learning. JUSE developed methods for reinventing the Japanese economy, methods known as total quality control and now six sigma. They invented a different kind of organization. Associations are a third path between markets and the state.

There is one great old wiki that is for free and primarily for appropriate technology, sustainability, living green and much more. I just joined them and notice they are growing and connecting with other wikis and projects, so the information is growing and becoming freely available in one place:
appropedia.org
the thing about these initiated and long-lived projects is that they need to get their web adresses spread out to all. And to make the info accessible in different off-line-modes, just like Appropedia do, trying to spread CD-ROMS and so on...
The non-profit-initiatives need to grow to make themselves into a "house-hold-name" and to work hard on getting all the fragmented smaller start-ups in the exact same field join and to create cross-wiki-links between the databases to become much better. If not, people perhaps may not know that they can google and find them whenever they are interested in learning about "best practices" on farming or sustainability or similar.

What about a Wiki type of solution? Most social entrepreneurs are highly active and willing to promote their ideas, so by using the famous wiki name and existing platform it could be free and accessible for everyone.
Adriana - The P&G initiative is cool - if only if were open to all to see + take away from. Seems that could be a good fit for the public - private partnership model as well.
You might want to think about an idea similar to P&G's connect and develop: http://bit.ly/1a7s3c but for a social cause.

It's true that it's a lot of stuff to wade through, when you're searching for viable business-models, but I think it is also valuable that there are sources that operate from slightly different angles. I think the point is to find the resource(s) that best match with the circumstances you are dealing with. Some of the great collections are Ahsoka (http://www.ashoka.org/), Social Edge (http://www.socialedge.org/) and the Skoll Foundation (http://www.skollfoundation.org/), but I guess you already knew them.For me, the biggest challenge of creating and maintaining a centralized collections is that it will allow for one, maybe arbitrary, school of thinking to come out as leading, while a plurality of views has the benefit that you get more different examples suited for more different situations.(the personal CSR example was just that: an example to illustrate that different needs can be addressed in different ways)

I disagree with you. As a lawyer, I can say that sharing business models and financing models in a central location is needed. It's hard to find best practices and one would have to wade through a lot of stuff to find something of business applicability on the openIDEO platform. Rather than thinking of this as a CSR issue, think of it from the social enterprise point of view. Innovative business models and financing models are key for the sector, because there is so much less precedent than in traditional models. I would love to be able to do a search of b-models by region, industry, ex. to what worked, didn't, important factors, etc.

Having a central information source is difficult, and maybe even unnecessary. I think it is good that there are many places on the web where social innovations are collected. Or even just good examples from a bit longer ago. Not everybody takes the same view, but those who dive into it, can really find a lot. Ashoka, Acumen, TED, are just some examples of curated collections, so to speak. I currently live in Latvia, and here, for example, CSR is seen as something that costs money and is about charity and is mainly something that people from the US or Western Europe want to push on 'us'. The economic crisis has hit hard, and many are struggling for survival. I have co-founded a blog in which I write about real-life examples from Latvian/Baltic businesses, and how it has benefited their profitability. It is a very specific angle, but examples from other countries don't really sink in.Aggregating the information is very important, and I think that places like OpenIDEO bring some of the activist minds together. So this is a place where we can share examples, and collections.

how_can_we_share_social_innovation_best_.title: How can we share social innovation best practices?

comments.text:
Wow thanks Dr Greene and Luke. I appreciate your support, and I honestly do not know how to go about practically implementing this idea, all I know is I would love to be on a team to help create it. 
The links that you gave Dr Greene look really interesting, I'll have a browse at those at some point. Thanks.

James, I'm so glad you brought this up.
This is my life. I left high school last year, to get home schooled. I felt, and feel, so strongly about this, and believe I can contribute a lot to this concept.
So a little background: I picked up a passion five or more years ago. I found an extreme interest in technology. I started doing web development three or four years ago. Two years ago I found a job working with other high school kids. (I still work with them.) It wasn't a lot of work, but I became encouraged nonetheless. I taught myself everything and continue to learn-- I spent hours a day with this.
Sometime between the time I started doing web design and maybe a year ago, I found a passion in ideas. I began writing ideas-- lots of ideas. I started thinking a lot. I'd have ideas for businesses and projects. I started thinking, and writing, a lot about government and life and people and education.
I couldn't.. I cannot stand the education system. I couldn't stand the system. I can't stand this system. It was overwhelming. To persuade my mom to let me get home schooled, I wrote (found this on my computer):
"I don't want to go to school because it's taken far more from me than it's given me. It's made me angry, upset, and stressed. It's given me a false sense of reality. It's not even about the learning. It's about getting through school, to get to college, to get a job, that will most likely make me miserable. Or, I can live, learn the things that interest me, and do what actually makes me happy."
I was miserable.
Now, I'm home schooled-- my mom has supported me, but she won't let go of the standardized testing and the intensive core classes and the transcript-- I haven't escaped the path that public school set me off on.
Though, home schooling does have its advantages. I have found more time to follow my passions.
--
What I've learned from my experiences:
Compulsory education is good at what it does-- I am compelled to do my work, but I'm miserable and stressed (though, I'm not sure how effective it actually is-- how much do people retain from this system).
When I start thinking about what I'm learning, all of it seems plenty important: English and Math and Science and History. I take interest in all of these! English is important to communicate effectively. Math to understand the vastness and meagerness of things and to calculate simple things. Science to understand life and our place in existence. History to learn from past mistakes.
But as soon as each becomes a subject, they lose their attractiveness and I lose interest. This, I believe, is because, frankly, school sucks! As animals we learn to avoid bad things. School bad. Things in school become negative, and when we experience these negative things elsewhere, they keep their negative connotations-- It always sticks with us.
Also, actually how important are these subjects to us? Can we measure this? Can we see what actually does matter to society? What is the actual object of it all-- and why don't we start from an objective, and work to fulfill something clear?
We don't need a new system. It would take a lot to convince me a different system could work. Systems break easily. Human determination and passion, on the other hand, is quite stronger. We just need to learn how to take advantage of that.
I would love to discuss ideas for how this could be solved with anyone who'd be interested. Skype anyone? luke.burns
Luke (sorry for the horrifically long post!)

James, you have a professor of education standing and applauding you for this concept. Sir Ken & Dr. Gardner are two of my heroes and leaders in "my" group of the few people on the planet who I feel truly "get it" when it comes to how we've allowed economic paradigms of worth to be the primary design of our system of education and thus, devalued the individual and any focus on truly serving each student to be able to reach their potential. I'd strongly encourage you to look at people such as Dennis Littky (http://www.bigpicture.org/dennis/), Seymour Papert (http://www.papert.org/works.html), and Alfie Kohn (http://www.alfiekohn.org). Enjoyment comes from meaning and purpose. "Hard fun" is one of Papert's phrases that I share over and over with my students as I work to ensure they can go out into the public schools and effect real change by designing curriculum in a fashion that affords the kind of personal engagement that is necessary for real, actionable, usable, transferable learning. It's a massive up hill battle in our current system, but having been a k-12 teacher, I've seen how lives can truly be changed when school is about educating the individual rather than pushing groups through prescribed, scripted, standardized curriculum.
I truly hope this concept moves to the next stage and promise that if it does, I'll be on your team doing all I can to support this.
I'm in Palo Alto, CA at the moment.  Still have to grab some time. Andrea

Cool.
I'm in the UK, are you across the pond?

Hi James,I'm not sure where to post responses either, so I'm glad I saw what you wrote. I have to give your thoughts some thought. Where are you?I need to watch your videos. Sorry for this short response, I wanted you to know I saw it. Andrea

Hello Andrea,
I don't know if this is the correct place on this website to reply to what you have said, or whether it's best to type this on your profile, so I hope you see this either way.
I just found this site by accident, I was looking at TED talks and some how came across this site, and I only signed up because I saw this challenge first and Education 'transform' (not reform! haha) is something i've been thinking of for a number of months. 
I don't work in Education, yet, I had considered either becoming a teacher or researcher in here in the UK, so all I do is read around the main issues as and when. Obviously I will have more knowledge about how Education as a whole operates over here, then say in Europe and in the States, though I am passionate about finding ways that a) assists learning to the best that we can achieve, whilst b) making the process enjoyable for people of all ages (an important factor because learning is a life long process).
Your comment has given me a lot to read, digest, and consider. This goal of mine is something I hope to shape and define as my experience in the field of Education grows and when I have seen what works and what doesn't. The hardest parts are a) getting people enthused by the prospect of changing Education for the better (as you say), b) meeting everyone's learning needs and c) dispelling popular myths and conceptions about school in general and what being a learning being means.
You are right to address the application of any research we have found, and it seems that the best way would be to first design an Educational model that works and is enjoyable, then gain funding from governmental or philanthropical means to test it, (ie actually create a new form of learning institution) then come up with a way of assessing what students have learnt. After we have evidence that student learning and development has happened, that may sway others.
A book I have just finished reading by Howard Gardner mentions just that. In his book 'The Unschooled Mind' he describes how his Project Spectrum combined the school style system with a museum and apprenticeship model of learning. I have no idea of the effects of such a model in the long term, and he does indeed mention complications such as students copying work and struggling with independence, however the benefits seem to out way those factors. Students are able to learn from other students of all ages while being involved in concrete projects that are guided by the teacher, as the students act as apprentices. The projects are then discussed, critiqued, shared and displayed at the end of the alloted time. One of the ideas behind it is that it involves students seeing the purpose of the things that they are learning and the benefits it offers to society. For more info on Gardner, see the website (http://www.howardgardner.com/) and for information on Project Spectrum (http://pzweb.harvard.edu/research/Spectrum.htm). I'm sorry I cannot talk more on Gardners work as I have only recently come across it, and know very little about him. However such approaches and new designs for how school operates will lead to fruitful results.
I had never considered addressing each area in turn, ie literacy and reading, then go with the best ones. I had immediately considered revamping the WHOLE structure and model of a school, because it seems that the problems resulting from Education are not necessarily like patching or fixing certain parts, it seems that the problems are in the DNA of school, to use a genetic analogy. I could be wrong, perhaps your suggestion may work. As a race it seems we have infinite time to try both, and more ways to make Education better. If we can get people involved and concerned than more people will address the issues and help. As you say getting the wider community involved would be great, especially if we could get people to see Education in the same way that Environmental concerns have been addressed, as Sir Ken says, then so much for the better.
Innovative ideas getting 'stuck in the system' wouldn't surprise me because for the large majority of people they feel that it's best to stick with what we know and not waste time on changing things. A common complaint i've heard from people in Education is that when they are getting to grips with the way teaching practice works, then those in power come along and change it. I can see the frustration in being told that the rules I have to obide by in my job are constantly changing and becoming increasingly demanding. I do not see why Education needs to be this way, it seems we just have to eliminate the weeds growing in Education so that our students and people can grow. Schools need to become less like a military department and more like workshop or a fun fair. In the sense that the division between 'school' and 'life' does not exist, everything is connected and related to each other, and that students want to learn and be praised for their efforts, and teachers want to see that happen. At this stage raising awareness seems to be the first step. If we can get people to become involved with Education in the way that the recycling and environmental movements happened, I have no reason to doubt that the same thing cannot generate solutions and interest in Education.
Phew!

Hi James,
There is no doubt addressing our education systems, world-wide, is a fundamental game changer.  We have a tremendous amount of research and thinking about how we can make it happen and raise the bar to excellence (maybe not enough).
I am stuck on how we can take the research we have and apply it and develop an environment which encourages thinking and action along these lines. What if we created a series of demonstration projects, using innovative ideas and testing them out. What if we did this collaboratively with governments and philanthropy, so policy could evolve?
I've been playing around with re-designing the federal grant making system, to build a capacity building model, integrating best practices each step of the way, regardless of sector, field of discipline or focus area. 
As part of a much bigger idea for organizational change, I created a "fake" federal initiative called "read for america".  Why?  Risk and resiliency research tells us a lot of things, one being that if kids can't read, by at least 10 years old, they are likely to start disengaging from the social contract.  It's one of many known risk factor we can address.  
What if we created initiatives and grant programs which targeted that one variable, as a start (it could be another)?  We would surface the best ideas, fund the ones with the most promise, and evaluate every step of the way. 
We could target the entire system, making sure the implementer's had the professional and organizational capacity and support needed.  Other community stakeholder's would be built into the entire picture. Technology and social media would play a big role in connecting these initiatives, creating a community of grantees, learning and solving problems together. This does not happen very often at the moment.
The RFP process would be creative and grounded, involve introducing the ideas and knowledge we have, or need to have, about innovative education strategies.  Imagine the energy and excitement created to encourage your challenge?  
I am not an educator, however, I have worked with educational systems throughout my career.  I know innovative ideas can get stuck in the system, if the system doesn't adopt them. What if we made it too good to ignore?
I know there is a lot of complexity to your challenge and I am only skimming the surface.  Just the process of addressing your challenge is compelling, fun and engaging.  Thanks for putting it up, it is a key to our human success on this planet.

Great thoughts James. And you could pull over earlier inspirations by other OpenIDEATORS such as: http://bit.ly/fOaH8J using the Build Upon feature. You'll increase your DQ points plus help others find related posts on this topic. Try out the Update button on the right of your post here.

in_one_word_women..description: Women are running the planet, they are simply not being recognized for it. From Bangladesh to Kabul, Papua New Guinea to the Amazon, women are the backbone of culture, society and in many cases, industry. Yet...they still in many cases have to hide in the shadows, This has to stop. Empowering, educating and enabling women globally is a huge social, cultural and economic need.
in_one_word_women..creator: 415b61e765a41e8dfd771e64477f84fd

comments.text: Thanks for posting this inspiration Paul. I created an agenda concept around this idea. I mean, when we really think about what global challenge innovation leaders should think about, it is crazy there are not more posts on here about women. Women's issues get so buried in all the other events of the day (global warming, the world economy, etc) but just think about what women have had to endure the entire history of human civilization. More and more people are realizing how many problems can be solved by focusing resources on women's education. We talk about all these problems that women face. But in a lot of ways, they are the solution.

Nicole, I agree, juggling family and work is a huge problem and its universal.  Work is by and large so inflexible, and the move to more flexible working hours or remote working seems to be going very slowly.   The problem is the same regardless of whether you're in a slum in Dhaka or in the City in Central London - who takes care of the children?   We've built our business in Bangladesh around the idea that we need to remove the barriers that prevent women from being able to work and have fully flexible working and a creche in the larger centres.    Having left the City myself to have children I could never quite understand why these large companies didn't set up a creche in their buildings and have webcams on all our pcs so that women could keep an eye on their little ones, be so much more relaxed and work so much more productively.

SEWA (Self Employed Women's Association) in India http://bit.ly/96DS5f is doing some great work in this area. 
Nicole  great call. The National Platform for Women in Iraq seems like it was set up at address some of these concerns: http://bit.ly/deNuNn and for them to identify policy priorities.

Paul, I think many of the same themes resonate in the West as well. Sylvia Hewlett via the Center for Work Life Policy is doing some really interesting work on female "brain drain" - Companies are increasingly losing out on the innovations and working styles of women who can't juggle families and careers. So I think that the term "empowerment" must have a multi-cultural dimension and be sensitive to the fact that even in the West, women still are the primary caretakers. I don't think its so much a matter of changing that gender dynamic (that takes many generations), but more how we can think of ways that immediately accommodate the different collaboration, work styles and lifestyles of women - while underscoring the fact that there is a strong business imperative to do so.

in_one_word_women..title: IN ONE WORD: WOMEN.

boston_s_innovation_district_creating_an.creator: 77d75e58964ecffdc2d803496cac7d8f

microcredit_financing.creator: 711c99771f3ceed49f77ac8c7c89ac2d

comments.text: Thanks Meena that's a great article there. I very much enjoyed the quote only some poor people will benefit from the chance to borrow, but almost all will benefit from the chance to save. This and people's mentions of the issues with microcrediting are why I believe the services provided with the microcredit financing are key to it's success. Some simple schemes, such as a savings plan, or simple lessons and support can go a long way to the success of the loan and the person's venture.
Thanks Arjan for update on Grameen Bank and link to issues with micro finance: there are positive outcomes but unfortunately, there are also negative consequences when things go wrong.

@WL: yes, Grameen was not only one of the earliest, but maybe the most important one in making micro financing into what it is today, and they've been firmly at the cradle of social entrepreneurship as well. Muhammad Yunus, founder of Grameen, has deservedly received the Nobel Peace Prize for this a couple of years ago.
In general, what worries me a bit about micro finance at the moment is that some institutions divert from the 'banking for the poor' path, and do not respect the lines set out by Grameen and Yunus. There seem to be some examples of bad behaviour that need to be adressed. See this Economist article: http://3bl.me/9mhdws
Is Grameen Bank http://www.grameen-info.org/ one of the earliest schemes? like their tagline - "banking for the poor".
Nice one! Check the work these guys are doing as well : http://www.kiva.org/

Good inspiration Adam! Providing financial mechanisms for the unbanked is a huge global issue and I'm glad you've raised it here. And here's an innovative, large-scale, bottom-up *micro-savings* initiative I was researching last year in Mumbai: http://bit.ly/9BmSjM Actually I'm back here now and am heading out later this week to accompany one of their staff on her rounds of households in the extensive Dharavi slums.

can_we_use_a_new_form_of_social_network_.description: As Jonathan Haidt has so compellingly explained, the problem confounding our ability to make progress on so many of our shared challenges is the balkanization of society, and the resulting inability to even hear each other, no less understand, learn and collaborate. Might it be possible to implement a social network system that helps people on opposite sides of (political, social, economic...) issues to have a more constructive dialogue? I think so.
can_we_use_a_new_form_of_social_network_.creator: 98db3fa4d45560f8046ed523c9a5a81a

comments.text: While not a social network, Opposing Views is a resource closely related to this concept. Opposing View is a website debate forum for experts:http://www.opposingviews.com/about Users can rate, comment, and vote on issues.

I think this might work, even across some really big cultural/political divides if a mediation component was added to this concept. Skilled mediation/communication trainers could work with each side to give them the tools and skills to communicate clearly and non-violently.This would influence all their future interactions around issues and daily life. Imagine a generation of community leaders who have the communication skills to work out problems peacefully with diverse neighbors.
That's a good point, Sidi--audience and user base is very important for this concept as well.  It's all about finding that sweet spot between too different and too similar.

Your idea is original Richard and it could be uselful I think, but only for cultures that are somewhat simillar and have similar means of communication and not complete utterly different believes, goals or interests. I`d worry about conflict or even disinterest should we wage sensitive issues or questions. I`d combine it with my ides or collecting information anonymously (or not, don`t really know yet) to teach rather than debate. Our personalities are powerful in a sense that most of us will not accept "defeat" publically and our minds are so powerful that they always find more knowledge to prove a point. It certainly is a complex matter I shall say ...

This is definitely more complex than like/dislike.  I think an important aspect to consider is the topic selection.  Would these topics be problems that have already been discussed widely?  If so, I'm afraid that a system like this may only lead to further division and the failure of the community as a whole.  Discussing gay marriage between people who have already chosen sides is not likely to suddenly have them switch sides.  But, if topics were mostly things that most people did not have great knowledge about, then there would be more room for persuasion and more education to be had by all.
As a college debater, I think this is a really cool idea.

can_we_use_a_new_form_of_social_network_.title: Can we use a new form of Social Network to bridge Cultural Divides?

innovative_public_private_partnerships.description: Companies that have realized profit AND the value of positive social trust / goodwill at the bottom of the pyramid are society's business and social innovators.
innovative_public_private_partnerships.creator: 677b685af5345b36ecb6d35b4852cc5c

comments.text:
Johan  I hear you, though for me the key innovation here is around the business model. The model could also be applied to sustainable solutions  and that's a great challenge you've raised around public-private partnerships.
My earlier inspiration from India http://bit.ly/97LjA3 is an example of sustainable solutions delivery which also employs a micro-finance model and supports local solar power entrepreneurs. It speaks to Nicole's question of 'how do we create skill / knowledge transfer within an economically sustainable model.'

This is indeed a great example. In Latvia, where CEMEX also operates, they invest a lot in the town where their factory is located. Mainly in education and community projects. I am convinced that public-private partnerships are very powerful means of solving some of the issues we face. Often, multinationals are better positioned than national governments to really make a difference. And in many cases already, companies are investing time and skills of their employees in real community development, where the business benefit is not necessarily in creating a new market segment, but a different way of developing the skill set of employees, where the business case is in lower training costs and higher retention (meaning lower recruitment costs).

Johan, you bring up really important points. All I can say, is it's a balance. Poor people deserve energy efficient homes, for sure, but first and foremost they need homes. I go back and forth with projects that promote renewable building materials, fuel sources etc., for low income countries. They are generally more expensive to build and maintain, and there is something bothersome about the fact that we are telling the poor that they must use renewable/sustainable building materials at a higher price after (and while) we in the west pillage the environment. 
The CEMEX model is great because it was beneficial for the company and for the poor consumer. I mentioned it in my last question, but it is absolutely important that a skill transfer occurs in these partnerships so that communities can become self-sufficient and like you said, start creating/selling their own products. The partnership (rather than CSR) model is a possible way to begin the "decoupling" idea you suggest. It's a matter of best practices and success stories becoming mainstream & then evolving with better knowledge and experience.

But how can we influence the companies that contribute?I agree with the humanitarian benefit the CEMEX are attempting, but concrete is not at all a good sustainable building material. What if one person in that scheme wanted a house built with timber? Poor people deserves also energy efficient homes with insulation and such.So when the donation is clearly connected with a desire to sell more of their own products and to make profit,How can we decouple this connection?but still get companies involved with corporate social responsible programs?

innovative_public_private_partnerships.title: Innovative Public / Private Partnerships - CEMEX (Mexico)

are_governments_being_overlooked_in_deve.description: Governments in developing countries are often seen as corrupt, inefficient and difficult to work with. But clearly there is great potential in harnessing the human capacity and systems inherent therein.      ---Innovation + Capacity Building = Better Governments
are_governments_being_overlooked_in_deve.creator: 94f8ef29957040e42b74843c902d2eea

comments.text: I evaluated your concept, and I got to say.. I really like where you're going.  As long as small countries have small purchasing power, it will remain to be a big fish eat little fish kind of story when it comes to them and their people.  'Tis the nature of a profit-based economy.  I like where your hearts at, friend, but I think you'd be interested to know where my head is.  Check out my concept and tell me what you think.

What an excellent project. Real, measurable results is what all education should produce. I wish all the best to those involved in this project, and I know it will have great impact on people's lives - those who need it most.

David, I would also like to support this initiative. I think this important not just because it's a way of mobilizing government staff to make more effective contributions towards poverty reduction efforts, but its also demonstrates the motivational power of education. Unfortunately, more often than not grass roots development workers are in workplace environments that are far from motivational. They are often poorly paid and receive little recognition for doing good work or coping with the difficulties of working in remote rural areas. In addition despite multi-million dollar investments by international donors, they often have very small budgets to work with and are "not trusted" to manage these budgets. It's often a very hard job, but simply by listening to these people and providing some simple incentives (such as professional recognition though an education program) can have a significant impact on their effectiveness. Professor Yunus (noble prize winner) says that "we must not leave the problem of poverty to the next generation". I agree. We have the technologies, the resources and the collective will power to change this terrible shame of the modern world. The fist place to start is to mobilize and make better what already exists. I believe we can quickly make a significant impact on global poverty if we spend less time looking for the "silver bullet" of the new "technology" that will solve all our problems, and focus more on making better use of what we already have. There are many thousands of community development workers already in a position to make Professor Yunus's dream come true. Some critical motivation and support can easily be provided to these people using existing resources and structures if we are prepared to rethink the way we approach education. Nick

David - Love the IDEO HCD. Yes, I think something absolutely can and SHOULD exist like this for government, especially in the aid context. Bill Easterly writes a lot about this topic, distinguishing between "searchers" and "planners." It's just a matter of mindsets. We need to start teaching policy makers and bureaucrats to listen rather than jumping to prescriptive solutions. I think the social entrepreneurship movement is forcing governments to do that, which is a great thing.

Arjan, you are absolutely right. Many of those social businesses ARE better and more efficient than governments in developing countries. However, the fact remains that these governments already have systems in place that are not being utilized to their fullest extent. Should they just be done away with? What a shame to discount a source of great potential just because it is currently inefficient. The reality is that these systems will be around for a long time, whether they become effective or not.
For example, in southern Laos alone there are 5000 government agricultural extension officers at the district level. These guys are working the closest to the poor. They are government workers who have a high school education, average age of 40 years, and they have been charged by the government to bring agricultural technology and services to the poorest of the poor. They are the front-line. These guys are not going to go away no matter how many social businesses are doing their job better. 
I am a huge proponent of private sector development and the power of the right business model to create change. But I posted this design challenge about governments for a good reason. Billions of dollars have been spent and will continue to be spent on government capacity building (much of this government-to-government). The point I am making is this: Can we not harness the creativity and innovation currently being applied to social entrepreneurship and ALSO apply it to how we think about working with governments?
Again, check out the PRAM project in Laos. We need more examples of this IN ADDITION to more social business solutions.
http://pramlaos.wordpress.com/about-poverty-reduction-and-agricultural-management-pram/

David, interesting and important question. In my opinion, see also my concept on social enterprises, governments are best equipped to create the circumstances in which individuals can make a change. I think the many social businesses that are coming up in the world are the most sustainable way to bring in change. Maybe even better and more efficient than governments and aid organisations can ever be. I think the biggest challenge for governments is not a lack of capacity, or too much influence of corruption, but more a matter of power struggle. For dictatorial regimes, benign or not, that seems obvious, but in democratic countries policy is often made and executed with the results of the next election in mind. And I think there is a growing disconnect between what political parties in that system think the people want, and what people really want. That is why I think that individuals with the right business model can create more efficient and sustainable solutions.
Adriana  would be great if you add your question as a stand alone post under Agenda Concepts. We think it' worthy of it's own discussion thread!

Thanks for your comments Nicole and Adriana. I like Adriana's 'design challenge' statement. However, the point I am making is: How can we get aid organization's all over the world to ask that question themselves? Nicole said it best in her other comment: "for a sustainable long term functioning societies, governments have to work." Working with these governments to implement solutions where they take a leading role is very difficult, and time consuming. Often, the end result is not nearly as effective or efficient as it could have been if the aid organization had done it themselves. But that is not the point.
I think we need more creative thought and innovative ideas in how aid organization's can better understand the needs of these governments and build their capacity at the same time as helping the citizens within the country. You may be familiar with IDEO's Human Centered Design Toolkit. This is an awesome resource for any organization wishing to design solutions according to the real needs of a community. Can a Human Centered Design Toolkit be created for the government context? Something that could act as a innovation guide for organization's that wish to interact with the government? That would be awesome.

Great comment. Governments certainly need to be involved in the process through greater partnership, collaboration and ultimately institution building. See some of my comments in the public-private partnership concept. I try to expand on this idea a bit. Adriana, valid comment, but I think that transforming governments takes a long, long time, and often times, isolated projects that showcase a dynamic partnership that then scale are the way systemic changes happen.
I would rephrase the issue as : How can service design transform governments into transparent, user centric, strategic problem solvers?

are_governments_being_overlooked_in_deve.title: Are Governments Being Overlooked in Development Work?

combatting_violence_through_the_transpar.description:
One of the greatest challenges facing the world today is violence due to gangs, drug trafficking, terrorist organizations, mafias and such. With the proliferation of such crimes and forms of violence, we are beginning to believe that it is normal to be surrounded by shootings, kidnappings, home robberies, etc.

A big part in the quelling of such violence is having a justice system that guarantees transparency and the processing of criminals swiftly and efficiently. The sense of justice is essentially non-existent in most developing countries where people do not press charges towards criminals fearing retaliation and being victims of corruption. This violence costs millions of dollars to economies and can become an important reason for people to consider migrating from their countries.

There must be greater collaboration between countries and the input of great minds; legal and from the innovation community, to use technology and collective thought in achieving real solutions.
combatting_violence_through_the_transpar.creator: 83dce9acdbcf645b6557e5e0dc25c59c
combatting_violence_through_the_transpar.title: Combatting violence through the transparent and efficient delivery of justice

competitive_innovation_x_prize_foundatio.description: Offering big cash prizes to the winner, the X Prize Foundation has spurred innovation in many different fields by sponsoring competitions in which teams race to design a solution that best achieves the goal of the challenge.
competitive_innovation_x_prize_foundatio.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: Sabra, Thanks for the follow-up comment!  Maybe prize money could be accumulated by people contributing to challenge categories... such as 'third world education', 'alternative fuels', etc. and then specific challenges within those categories could be proposed and voted on.  I like it I like it.The main point of my inspiration though, regardless of how it gets funded, is that compensation driven competition with an eye toward new business models (Virgin Galactic as an example) is a great way to catalyze innovation.Thanks again Sabra!

I've seen problems up for solution (with payment offered) on crowdsourcing sites that came from NGOs needing an appropriate tech solution. What if NGOs could pool their resources to fund crowdsource design competitions for the solutions they need? That would also help make the challenges and prizes big enough (and inspiring enough) to bring out people's creativity in a really good way.  People, orgs and businesses could also create and sponsor challenges like people contribute to projects on Kickstarter and IndieGogo.

Sabra, Thanks for the comment!  That is a very interesting idea!  Very provocative!  I see two issues to this: the downside is that crowdfunding prizes might not generate a prize amount big enough to produce interest in submitting a solution proposal to the competition.  I might find the proposed challenge interesting but is there enough incentive for me to help in the funding of the prize for it also?  I'm just thinking out loud... maybe there is an incentive equation in there somewhere that works that I am just not seeing yet....The upside to your idea is that it greatly increases the potential for challenges to be proposed that might be much more innovative and interesting in and of themselves and never otherwise would have been thought of by an isolated 'board of directors' or sponsoring company or whoever currently picks the challenges.  Which could be a good thing.  Uncovering challenges we didn't know we had but are in need of addressing.Great stuff to think about..  Thanks again for your comment!

I'd like to see design contests like this that are crowdfunded and crowdsourced. What I mean is: people propose challenges/solutions they need. People vote on which are most vital/they need that solution too. Prizes are crowdfunded like kickstarter. Democratize research for the most needed solutions.

competitive_innovation_x_prize_foundatio.title: Competitive Innovation: X Prize Foundation

how_can_we_make_integration_questions_le.description: In Scandinavia (and many other places in the world) the support for the xenophobic parties is rising. At the same time you are not allowed to question or point out errors in the current foreign policy without being called a racist. If we can't talk about it, how can we make it better?!  We need to come up with new, innovative ways to handle the discussion of integration in order to improve incentives that creates value for individuals and society as a whole.
how_can_we_make_integration_questions_le.creator: bb0fbfced25c57b6b37e526c14bd36f6

comments.text: Intercultural relations is indeed very important as the world becomes increasingly globalized. As someone who has experienced being in category 1 and 2 (as defined by Arjan), I think its important to distinguish between varying levels of cultural accommodation such as integration (equal opportunity, rights, etc.) and assimilation (merging into mainstream culture), and recognize that different groups will see different levels as ideal.

Your thoughts are very recognizable, although I think that it is mainly an issue in several progressive European countries, like the Scandinavian countries and the Netherlands. There has indeed been a political correctness that blocked us from discussing the real issues and finding real solutions. Now you see that parties that lay blame somewhere else (islam, outsourcing, foreigners in general), and are feeding off this us-versus-them thinking are getting more votes in elections. Without offering real solutions, by the way.If you look at the recent history in the Netherlands for example (I'm Dutch, so that's what I know a bit about) is that every time there is an influx of immigration from a certain region for a specific region, it takes at least 3 generations to integrate. The first generations often does not assimilate. Often because their reasoning is that migration is a temporary solution (refugees from conflict, economical drivers). The second generation falls between the cultures of the homeland and the residence country, which leads to tension and problems, and in the third generation you see that people feel Dutch, have a higher average education, get jobs etcetera. It's not a scientifically researched subject, as far as I know, but growing up, every decade or so there was a new group that was to blame for everything.The issue is, rightly as you said, that we need to start identifying problems where the problems are, and discuss them in an open way, aimed at finding solutions.

how_can_we_make_integration_questions_le.title: How can we make integration less black and white?

comments.text: This is a beautiful video.  During the ensuing hour, post view, i've been relatively seamlessly propelled toward the ideals expressed within by related videos and the host website "globaloneness".  It seems humanity as a whole needs to find a balance.  I want to ask, on what time line might we project this balance to occur?  in order to create this time line we may start by asking, what are the immediate threats to our living world?  and then, have we created these threats?  if yes then, for what beneficial side effects were these threats created?  and then, how can we extinguish this threat while meeting, or at least providing for, whatever demand provoked it?  If we can succeed in extinguishing these threats we may then begin to project ahead of ourselves toward a desired planetary evolution.  what then is this desired evolution?  a world that functions as a healthy organism, one that progresses creatively, one sensitive to natural laws which maintain balance?  what shall we do with the collective power in humanity that remains.  the power to interpret our natural world (science) and then the power to manipulate it (industry).  what shall we do with this understanding, with this ability to create?  perhaps the question is.  What really enriches life?  perhaps the acknowledgment of life itself is what enriches life.  how can we ensure that we do not forget this?  how can we teach this?

oursness.title: Oursness

reduce_poverty_by_creating_employment.description: The most pressing need is the reduction of poverty in the developing world.  This can only be done sustainably through the creation of employment.   We need to increase labour in the developing world without increasing consumerism in the West.   We need a revolution in hand made.    Hand manufacture holds huge opportunity for poverty reduction by taking much needed work to remote and rural locations, increasing the rural economies and reducing economic migration to cities.   It’s not necessarily something for scale but rather can be many small businesses that celebrate diversity.      Paul Bennett created the equation ‘ SMALL x MANY = BIG’ and it’s spot on.
reduce_poverty_by_creating_employment.creator: e3cf33cebe2e6c3e1f8d52015a33936b

comments.text: And another that has reached mainstream sales with hand made greetings cards  http://www.guardian.co.uk/money/video/2010/nov/11/sreepur-christmas-cards-bangladesh
Here's another great example    http://www.bholu.com/     making home decor items in Gujarat with the profits going back into local schools and the products available in the mainstream worldwide.

I wanted to add a little extra note to this on the hand-made element.   I'm a great fan of technology and moving forward, but sometimes I think that we mechanise without really thinking about whether it brings benefits.   True, in many cases mechanisation brings increased productivity and increased profits, but there are case where the cost of hand made is very similar to the cost of machine made and then we still go ahead with mechanisation despite the clear social benefits of hand made.   I give you an example.  Every year 4 million babies are born in the US and not one of them comes with a hat!   The cost of making a knitting hat by machine is very similar to that of making it by hand in the developing world.   It's small and takes little time to make by hand, whereas its a little tricky and time-consuming by machine.   So why don't we make all knitted baby hats by hand and create employment.    A much bigger example of this in action is in the sweater industry in Bangladesh.   The whole industry still use the hand operated 'handloom' knitting machines, where every line of knitting is made by a man (usually) pushing a carriage across the work.   I was astonished when I first saw it that all this hadn't been replaced by snazzy computer operated machines.  In fact the cost of investment in this machines did not make economic sense when considering the cost of labour in Bangladesh and so the old method remained and the industry creates work for millions.

Imagine, one inspired lady getting 5000 women a fair and basic income, whilst working on all those different communities, spread all over the country. And getting commitment from the community members. Terrific! Love it

What a great story from Nairobi.   We need a whole new revolution in hand made and vintage.    I'm sure that there must be lots more examples and certainly there is lots of scope for many more.   Hand made and vintage - sounds like the start of a movement to me....

Hi Samantha. "It's not a project  it's a business"  love that and am a big fan of entrepreneurial approaches to poverty reduction. Here's a bottom-up example from a savvy woman in Nairobi who sells her repurposed clothing locally: http://bit.ly/9Ls4lR (It's a great read!)

reduce_poverty_by_creating_employment.title: Reduce poverty by creating employment

start_with_why.description: Instead of focusing first on the product solution (the what) or the process of the solution (the how), start with vision that is rooted in something deep (the why). Leaders and organizations that start with why, inspire and often are distinguished by a higher purpose (whether for or non-for profit). Here is a link of the TED talk that summarizes it. http://www.ted.com/talks/simon_sinek_how_great_leaders_inspire_action.html

We must address the why rather thanthe how or what.

comments.text:
Thanks for posting the link to Novica, Sabra. I have heard of that site and am hoping to suggest that there could be growth in the innovation level/product and service options beyond what is typically "artisan" work. Having met others who are interested in developing offerings in other sectors, it would be great to equip them to find their own tools/channels as well. 
And thanks for your links too, Meena. I concur - business training is part of it. I'm guessing it will be important to note country-specific distinctions that would need to be considered in the process.

A great question Kara! One of the humble, yet scaled, initiatives I've noted in India is the Mahila Milan micro-*savings* initiative which doesn't rely on external funding: http://bit.ly/9BmSjM But what is often missing from micro-finance ventures is accompanying business training. I remember hearing about a scheme in Kerala which requires business training as part of the loan process  seems like a good start over a purely transactional approach. Companies like Fab India http://bit.ly/gdupE1 are making strides in India is providing distribution channels for artisans who also become shareholders in the enterprise.
There are many, many avenues which an Agenda Concept such as this could explore  a well devised line of enquiry.
http://www.novica.com/ facilitates direct access to global markets for artisans in the developing world.

how_can_we_encourage_business_developmen.title: How can we encourage business development and distribution channels for rural/marginalized communities?

(We're sure there are many) In the Inspiration Phase we hope to create a library of existing initiatives to inform the Agenda Concepts Phase. the_early_development_of_the_social_poli.description: This issue stems from my own inspiration. In most of the projects I´ve worked in I´ve observed that the interface for the communication and information sharing between the civil society, the main socioeconomic sectors and the policy makers (including expert panels) was not developed up front. This complex step often constitutes a major constraint in the decision making processes within the projects, as its absence makes such processes top-down, hierarchical and to lack the necessary representation of the local, socioeconomic sectors and neighbourhoods. This fact ultimately erodes democracy, leads to socioeconomic inefficiencies and to (too) many competitive (often conflictive) interests.
the_early_development_of_the_social_poli.creator: 9f926880e84ea0eb301decf03d398f55

comments.text: Nicole, thanks for the reference, I will try to get hold of it. And thanks for thinking Im a writer, I take it as a compliment. Im still a researcher, on my way to write something useful. Though all that I've post here is original, is based on academic, already published knowledge (some of my own, of course: http://bit.ly/d8dLU6).

Pablo, I highly suggest you read "The Future and Its Enemies" by Virginia Postrel if you haven't. She is a self-titled dynamist and has devoted an entire book to exactly what you are talking about (although in a number of different contexts in addition to policy/gov regulation). 
On a personal note, I would be interested to read some of your writing (if you are a writer, which is sounds like you are).

the_early_development_of_the_social_poli.title: The early development of the social-policy interface

designing_a_clean_system.description: How can we use design to reduce an age-old problem of corruption across different countries and cultures? Corruption breeds in both developed and developing countries although their forms may differ. In developing countries, it may be in the form of a physical bribe; in developed countries, it may be in the form of undue influence by large corporations on political leaders. Both forms cause complex societal problems, such as inequity, poverty, etc. The problem of corruption must first be tackled without which many other problems will remain.
designing_a_clean_system.creator: af12d67c887430203dd3edf958d321aa

comments.text:
Thank you everyone for your comments. 
Vincent's zero rupee note is interesting that it allows the people to be part of the solution but i wonder about some of the repercussions that comes with using the note. 
Nicole's statement about making uninteresting problems interesting was very insightful because the big problems of the world has hardly changed and it's not as interesting or exciting as some of the things that are more current. It's still the same old problems even though we seems to have better ways to solve problems now. Corruption is one of them and i was also thinking of other areas like poverty, hunger, prostitution, etc
Thanks Pedro for the tip on the book. I will definitely read that one. 
Arjan's statement of difficulty in doing business is very true. In fact, it's in many areas and not just business. For developing and developed countries, it would both be livelihood although one would be about finding work or getting things done while the other would be how you went about with your work. 
It's a really complex problem cos it corrupts any system.

Finding ways to lower corruption around the world is surely one of the best ways I can think of to improve the development of countries all around the world. The impact of corruption on poor countries in particular was very well explored in the book "The Undercover Economist", by Tim Harford. It's a very good book which talks about elaborate economic concepts in a fluid manner, placing them inside interesting stories and thus offering an engaging narrative. It made me keenly aware of the many problems corruption brings about, and so I'd recommended it for anyone else who is interested in this subject.

I believe that this inspiration is crucial for the future improvement of the world. Furthermore, it should be taken at global level if we want to have real effects. Some steps in that direction have already been taken by Transparency International and they should be supported by further efforts by public authorities in the major countries.

>1 million 0 rupee notes are in circulation in India to combat corruption: when asked for a bribe, the note is handed over. Learn more at http://india.5thpillar.org/ZRN and view success stories at http://5thpillar.org/~pillar/india/category/content-type/success-story

You hit on two of my favorite topics: transparency and infographics. There are two really important elements here. 
One is that corruption is a major impediment to development and it doesn't just happen in poor countries. 
The second is that interactive maps and infographics are such an interesting way to make un-sexy problems like corruption engaging and accessible for a number of users. Transparency International has been doing an amazing job with this - straddling the world of policy and design.
Make sure to check out TI founder Peter Eigen's TED talk: http://www.ted.com/talks/peter_eigen_how_to_expose_the_corrupt.html

Corruption is indeed something that blocks economic development. Not only does a lot of money go to waste, it also paralyses business. An interesting study, done over 10 years ago, showed that corruption actually did not make business go smoother (that was once the perception). See: http://3bl.me/fds2x4. Interestingly, one of the authors later added that eradicating corruption would also be helped by a properly working legal system (investigate, prosecute and convict) and increasing the reputational damages. Finding ways to help countries do this, would be a good thing for the ILSI to work on.

designing_a_clean_system.title: DESIGNING A CLEAN SYSTEM

how_to_control_the_earth_s_climate.description: I think that the real issue we face is not global warming itself, but that our species is vulnerable to changes in our climate in general. Even if we became carbon neutral, our climate will change 'naturally' as there is no fixed state for the Earth's climate. We will still be vulnerable to rapid, natural shifts in the climate. Therefore, the real issue for global leaders responsible for 9 billion people in the 21st Century will be it to find a way to achieve a level of control over our climate that allows Humanity to mitigate the worst climatic disasters and maximise beneficial climatic effects.
how_to_control_the_earth_s_climate.creator: faf74828f7a33e800312e47653832f00
how_to_control_the_earth_s_climate.title: How to control the Earth's climate?

comments.text: The point made is that innovation reaches the hands of the rich first. I believe we need to start fostering a sense of social understanding in our design programs to focus this amazing brain power on social issues. If the minds that went into to creating products like the Kindle and Blue Tooth and all these iPhone Apps were able to focus on water treatment systems, access to education, and zero-waste business practices imagine what shape our world would be in!

should_innovation_follow_a_framework_whe.title: Should innovation follow a framework where the human welfare predominantly drives the process ?

creating_physical_not_just_online_commun.description: The last decade or so has seen massive innovation in online, or distance, community building. Facebook. MySpace. Foursquare. But what about creating meaningful physical communities? Are these online social media tools just a way to remind us how much it means to us to be members in different communities?
creating_physical_not_just_online_commun.creator: 68c143efc7d461941d72e30c58730fd5

comments.text:
I evaluated your concept, and from what I can understand you are aiming to bring people closer together.  The internet does this fantastically by giving us all a common form of communication and instantly!  Now I agree, face to face interaction is much more heart to heart in it's essence, but it isn't necessarily required. 
While I think people should work on becoming more inviting and accepting of others, I don't think your concept validly pursues that.  The best way to bring people together is through unconditional love and morals, something that can not be built tangibly, but rather consciencely.

Also interesting to remember that apartment buildings and tower blocks in their current design don't facilitate local interaction that easily. A corridor is a not a nice place to meet and I believe buildings need to include these common spaces.

I did a project recently at school with a similar question in mind. It proposed creating large floor to ceiling digital touch screens in every metro station in Paris, named 'Public Wall: Learning from Graffiti Artists' where everyone could leave messages, create news, draw pictures in their local physical communities. The best ranked work and news and updates would be shown throughout their train line, (their network one size larger) and if amazing, shown in the central station and then projected out into the city through large high quality projectors.

A really exciting way to do this would be to leverage location-based social media more powerfully to make these physical locations important in already existing or growing online communities.  Leveraging the enthusiasm for online communities to rejuvenate physical ones seems like a smart (and poetic) strategy.

What I like about online communities, is that it enables me to exchange thoughts with people I would never meet in person. However, I also like to connect with real people around me. Having moved from my home country to another one, and now the second one, it's important to me to connect with the place I am in. A very good way is to connect with the local community. You are absolutely right that this is important.

Nice one Sachpreet! And you can increase your DQ points by adding some of the relevant posts from the Inspiration Phase with the Build Upon feature. (Start by using the Update button on the left of your post)

Really good point. This is so important for communities to thrive culturally and economically. People are going to be more invested in their communities if they feel a connection to the people around them.

creating_physical_not_just_online_commun.title: Creating physical - not just online - communities

comments.text: Two organizations that have been dedicated to this question for many years are:1. U.S. Peace Corps (www.peacecorps.gov)2. Inter-American Foundation (www.iaf.gov)While they don't have it figured out they have certainly learned a lot of practical lessons about working "with" vs "for" communities around the world.

In my work with Native American tribes in CA, I make sure i avoid the issue of going out and designing for or telling the tribes what to do by following the co-design methodology.In my work, the tribal members are co-researchers: they collect the energy data, crunch the numbers, install the wind turbines and make the reports with us in tandem.  It has been very effective and I think you should check out my paper on this: Co-Design Methodology for the Development of Sustainable and Renewable Energy Systems for Underserved Communities: A Case Study with the Pinoleville Pomo Nation  DETC2011-47748

I think this is a great concept.  It reminds me of this quote from Paolo Freires Pedagogy of the Oppressed: Educationthe practice of freedom, the means by which men and women deal critically and creatively with reality and discover how to participate in the transformation of their world.  In addition to innovating WITH communities, I think we can push this idea further by also thinking about innovation FROM communities.

Have you heard of the work of a Brazilian architect, urbanist, and inspired social entrepreneur named Edgard Gouveia? He co-founded a community leadership initiative in Brazil called Instituto Elos (http://elosbrasil.org/en/teste/). They have developed an great social methodology to ignite meaningful action with communities, called the Oasis Game. Their idea is to approach a community-development project as a game, and invite a diversity people to participate, from street children to regional officials and business owners. This inclusiveness attracts more people to join the game and once involved, each person is invited to bring their most unique and valuable talents to the table. Communities can better help themselves if they are inspired by an empowering entrepreneurial spirit and work collectively for the common good. This is a great tool for engaging local communities anywhere in the world and the methodology could also be used in the corporate world.
Wow Hurbertine  that sounds really cool. Those savvy Brazilians, huh?!
Congratulations on making it to the final 9 on the agenda! Well done!http://reasonedprogression.wordpress.com

Great concept.  I evaluated your work and I think the best way to solve the issue is through the pure application of resource based economics as well as the philosophy associated with it.  In an RBE society, the community would be global and much more personal than ever before.

Very relevant concept. Top-down initiatives from the stewards fail because they propose blueprint solutions, most of which do not take into account local stakeholders in the development of the initiative itself. This normally increase distrust and aversion among the locals. Moreover, the blueprints do not take into account social uncertainty and do not develope mechanisms for dealing with change and surprise. More participatory, inclusive and flexible processes are needed. Of course you always have troublemakers but then you can design for diversity and cancel non-constructive people...and many many more things...you all know.

Hi Meena,Very relevant suggestion!I only just saw your post now and I believe it relates to mine in many ways - Design as cultural imperialism, homogenization and biased intellectual capital? http://bit.ly/gYIvMJWould like to hear your views on this too.I hope your question will be picked for the i20 summit.Cheerio,Chris
Just noticed a relevant article from this week's NYT about technology and citizen engagement: http://nyti.ms/hbd0AU

Appreciative Inquiry is a process I can recommend: Discover, dream, design, and deliver. It is another version of the open ideo process. Their common denominator is facilitated conversations to reach solutions that matter.
@Adriana  a challenge indeed. And that will give i20 global innovation leaders something to talk about ; )

Great question, the challenge, however, is scalability. Community programs involving co-creation and co-implementation are critical but then you face the "Glocal" challenge. How can you create local globalized programs?

Indeed  in line with participatory budgeting (I built on your inspiration for this) and great to check out another example in that vein. There's also something along the participatory budgeting line in the Us Now film  really worth a watch when you have time: http://bit.ly/gdvOdC

Hey, in line with participatory budgeting, here is a really cool initiative I found in Chicago: In in 2009, residents of Chicagos diverse 49th Ward began deciding how to spend the $1.3 million capital budget of Alderman Joe Moore in an innovative experiment in direct democracy. The 49th Ward is the first political jurisdiction in the nation to implement a permanent participatory budgeting process. See what the ballot looked like: http://participatorybudgeting49.files.wordpress.com/2010/04/pb-ballot-english-sample4.pdf

@Reinhard: I love the Serious Play approach!  another brilliant one for community engagement. You might also be interested in this blog post which outlines a recent community co-production initiative in the UK: http://bit.ly/fbxcZt

Great questino, Meena! Actually this very question is what I try to answer using the LEGO SERIOUS PLAY approach ... involving not only so called stakeholders who often neither have a stake in nor care about the results but enganging employees who have the knowledge and experience and let them share it using kind of new language - which is LEGO. I really hope that this question will make it to the i20!

This is very relevant also with emergency aid! Sometimes nations in the west can send useless or unwanted objects as part of catastrophic help packages to a country that suffered a natural disaster. (out of ignorance, lack of knowledge, or simply egoistic reasons when they try to promote a special companies products or services)
This is so relevant, great question Meena. I can imagine the i20 really getting excited about this one.

play_with_integration.description:
Last year I participated in Gam3 In Copenhagen, an urban sports and culture organization that aims to improve integration of young people from minority cultures in Denmark, empower young boys and girls and tech them about teamwork, leadership and conflict solutions. All this is done through street games - basket and street dance, were children 12-18 get trained and coached by young volunteers and professional basket players and dancers.

With Gam3, color, religion or language doesn't matter - what matters is your game!

comments.text: I firmly believe that social entrepreneurs are changing the world. I've had the opportunity to work side by side with many Ashoka fellows (Ahsoka is the biggest network of social entrepreneurs and I'm proudly part of their local staff in Mexico city) and  I have witnessed with my own eyes how their projects are changing the most pressing problems in society. From a serial entrepreneur that has changed the eye-care in India, by radically lowering the cost of eye-surgery, returning their sight to more than 800,000 patients a year; to an incredible woman that has created a virtual reality simulator that works as a table game for schools to educate children on empathy, compassion and other universal values, and is being implemented in over 80 schools wordlwide. Ashoka supports the leading social entrepreneurs that are proposing innovative ideas with a systemic change focus and that can eventually replicate their solution in other contexts. I feel the world leaders should get to know he work of this social enterpreneurs that will radicately inspire them to action.
Great inspiration. Corporations should be more involved than ever, but it's really important they keep it sustainable at all times.

Love it. Given how many people are employed by businesses, and how much people consume is produced by businesses, business can be a powerful force for change, and there is much about business that could be changed. A topic near and dear to my heart, and which I'm currently working on.
