awaken_creativity_in_schools_with_empath.description: Understanding others and our ability to feel awakens us.  Although everybody in the world has some shape of creativity as a human resource, not all of us are equipped to tap into it.  What if we awaken the creative process in school curriculums across the world with empathy?
awaken_creativity_in_schools_with_empath.creator: 8757541db3a21588d7952dbb8fb5fe29

comments.text: Great themes here...  I like the idea of building dialog between children.

I am currently an elementary school teacher in Marinilla, Colombia, and one of my coworkers shared a quote with me (don't know who it's from) that sums up the essence of what I believe to be the goal in mind with this "inspiration":
If you teach me, I'll forget.If you tell me, I'll remember.If you involve me, I'll learn. 
That is exactly what we need to do with students...INVOLVE them. The best exercise we can do when reflecting on this is to think about the most impactful experiences we had in grade school and analyze WHY it was so impressive. I have done this exercise, and what I have realized is that the most important factor determining if kids learn or not lies within the PROCESS of involvement, not necessarily the end-goal of what we want them to learn. In the end students do not learn what we teach them, but rather they learn what they experience, and the experience is given through the process, not the end-goal assessment.
And to WL Wong: I like the idea of partner schools. I'm actually in the process of connecting my school in Colombia with a Montessori school in Brooklyn :)
http://danielgoleman.info/topics/social-emotional-learning/ for current work in helping children learn empathy and teamwork.

Some Australian schools have partner schools (or sometimes classed based) in different countries. There's a bit of communication happening and sharing of experiences. Some schools also try fund raising for resources to help partner schools but perhaps more can be done, and with mutual benefit. The learning of languages and cultures would definitely be enhanced through greater communication and collaboration across the globe.

awaken_creativity_in_schools_with_empath.title: Awaken creativity in schools with empathy

trade_my_brain_interdisciplinary_barter_.description: How can artists, business people, builders, programmers (etc. etc.) learn from (and have fun with) each other through barter systems?
trade_my_brain_interdisciplinary_barter_.creator: 677b685af5345b36ecb6d35b4852cc5c

comments.text:
Here is a story I came across about a festival where uninsured artists and musicians exchange work for medical attention. http://www.businessweek.com/smallbiz/content/nov2010/sb20101117_585960.htm 
The event is called the O+ Festival: http://www.opositivefestival.org/ I wonder if the festival will eventually open it's door to more talents and skills. I would really like to see that happen.

shifting knowledge trade from a profit based system to a more open community based exchange sounds like a great idea; i just wonder if this approach requires the entire monetary system to be ignored in order to be widely accepted as a viable solution( meaning = people still need to make money); or could it be that we are increasingly finding this kind of trading more fare as things and services become more and more expensive;, good inspiration!
Yes, I have heard about the couch-surfing project. Trust = key. Can someone please create this? (I have no time, or I would...)

Interesting concept. Unfortunately I do not live in Brookly (or anywhere near it), because I could use your legal advice probably. And may even have some skills in return.I think that the trust issue is very important, and for that you need an active community that has a stake. I like the example of couch surfing (http://www.couchsurfing.org/) where both hosts and 'surfers' are 'rated', so that people can see whether you're dealing with a trustworthy person. To be honest, I have that notion based only on hearsay, haven't tried it myself.

This seems like it would have so many applicable uses on different scales  person to person but also serving broader projects. You could barter skills as a group to support a neighborhood initiative in a more effective way than already happens...for example to build a school playground, a group of residents may already get together with specific skills or talents (including legal!) to get the project started, but they could then leverage their commitments to get funding, supplies, support, etc from the government/organization.
Haha, I definitely do not trust Craigslist. I think you should start something similar in Brooklyn. You could use Meetup.com to create a local group with a similar concept or goal.

Thao, I was actually on a mission a couple of months ago to barter my legal skills. 
I tried Craigslist but it was kind of sketchy (no built in trust or quality control) and so I wound up not taking up the 2 offers that I got (that were for sub-par web design) 
I emailed the trade my brain web admin and he never got back to me! Wasn't sure if it was just a lack of funding/support thing or if my legal offering wasn't weird and quirky enough. But what silkscreeners - potters - dance teachers don't ever need a lawyer right?! 
I would LOVE to have a brooklyn barter platform. Local enough so that you (probably) won't be murdered or scammed but artsy and creative enough that you could experience of variety of trades / skills.

I'm sold. If you could learn something new every single day of your life, why not do it? Maximize life's return. This platform would be a really good start, and I am definitely intrigued by the give and take concept.I see it's in beta mode. Have you given this a try? Just wondering about the overall experience...

trade_my_brain_interdisciplinary_barter_.title: Trade my Brain!

can_governments_create_social_credits_to.description:
Governments have created "emission credits" as an economic incentive to cut back on carbon emissions. What if  "social credits" were created to incentivize social impact. Many businesses have excess capacity that is wasted, yet increased complexity for other usages deter businesses from actually using that capacity. For example, freight companies moving products from China to the US oftentimes take empty containers back given the differences in volume. What if those containers were used to send aid/food/etc to underprivileged communities in China or elsewhere in Asia? LIkewise, most supply chain systems deal with uneven supply vs demand capacities. 
Excess capacity can be infrastructure but it can also be talent, services, etc.
can_governments_create_social_credits_to.creator: cc5c3a176e895dabfb815af7eb7424e1

comments.text: It's a great idea but, as you say, moneraty incentives are a powerful tool, perhaps (and sadly) the unique incentive for large corporations. Empty containers mean less fuel used in transport ergo less transportation costs. In that case I would say that it is not a matter of monetary incentives but of legal enforcement and social awareness on the excess capacity of many companies or supply chains. In the environmental/energy case, social pressure is proving to be a very powerful pressure for many companies that are adopting more-clean tech and practices. Also, if there was higher social concern about the opportunity that you are posing, governments could apply a "tobin-liked" tax to corporations that do not efficiently use their excess capacity, i.e. that do not transport something back :). After all, medicines and food do not weigh that much and we are each time becoming more energy-efficient.

can_governments_create_social_credits_to.title: Can governments create "social credits" to incentivize businesses to use excess capacity for social causes?

Your idea of "working centers" reminded me of a Fast Company article I read a few months ago. [http://www.fastcodesign.com/1662188/coffee-shop-office-hybrids-the-workplace-of-the-future] I think it's a great concept! While many of the causes and solutions to the crisis are beyond the reach of consumers, it has nonetheless highlighted the need for increased financial literacy of everyday citizens.

comments.text: Hi All,Thank you for your thoughtfull comments.  Ashley -- I took a look at your challenge inspiration.  Entreprenuership among school age children would be a great way to address this issue.  I'm going to try a figure out ways to merge the too as well.

Hi Joy, I completely agree. In terms of financial literacy and entrepreneurship for the next generation of business leaders, I'd like to point you towards my challenge Inspiration: http://openideo.com/open/what-is-the-global-challenge-that-most-concerns-you-right-now-and-that-global-innovation-leaders-could-begin-to-solve/inspiration/nurturing-entrepreneurs-worldwide-global/Maybe there's a way we could combine these into a concept of what this kind of training would look like, for both kids and adults? Great point here.  As a soon to graduate college student, I would personally appreciate to have well-defined forums for credible financial information.  Some of my friends and I have talked about this before, and I think that changing public education curricula to include financial literacy is an avenue worth considering.

And here's an example of starting young, with popular culture, from the Reserve Bank of India via a comic book series: http://bit.ly/ghr11t which covers concepts of banking, interest, loans, currency, etc. Helping folks understand the collapse of financial markets more clearly is useful too  as in this animation on The Crisis of Credit Visualised: http://bit.ly/hGQNrZ

could_we_adjust_our_perception_of_money_.description:
1. There is a great debate going on around the definition of development. For instance, Hans Rosling in Gapminder presents strong arguments; overall, he states that money doesn't exactly mean developed.
2. Economics are a measuring system, a science studying the distribution of limited resources to cover up unlimited needs.
3. Some efforts start to link the Economics with the environment (measuring carbon emisions in a monetary way)

Could we forget the money for a while and build different kinds of systems? Rural comunities are usually poorer, yet greener. If a city didn't have the space to plant as many trees as needed, could a rural comunity do it and have some social aid in return (a school, or a hospital financed by that city)?
could_we_adjust_our_perception_of_money_.creator: 52bb2e4d9c5becd14f01c5e87c2b4c71

comments.text: We need to create a new system for valuing "assets" that are not based on our current perception of assets. If a new system can be defined by the people then we can begin to value the things the people value and develop that way instead of developing the way that "advanced economies" have told us we need to develop.

could_we_adjust_our_perception_of_money_.title: Could we adjust our perception of money and economics?

look_for_a_method_to_improve_car_owners_.description:
Always we see big cities' avenues and streets with giant lines of vehicles on rush hours  (almost of developing countries has this problem). People talk a lot about this. But, however, never there's an effective solution to make it better.

The best way I see is improve public transportation, instead of self ones. But almost all of car owners don't want to stop using their facilities, because our buses and trains are not so good as we can see in Europe, Japan and US, for example.

How can we make it works? Just make public transportation better? What about a new self device that does not pollute and is cheaper than hybrid/eletric models we have today? Another way could be a service or campaign that make people think about giving a ride... What do you guys think about?
look_for_a_method_to_improve_car_owners_.creator: fb17ea3d285648336422ccbdc89a4877

comments.text: Invent more ways to encourage carpool not just work days, but everyday, and energy saving electric vehicles... So far, in the Bay Area, we do this by creating special lanes for them.  But there's got to be other ways.

Have strict punishment for public transport drivers (ie. bus drivers, taxi drivers) who break the law. You could have a public ticketing system whereby citizens can take photos or videos of them breaking the law and email/send them to the police.
Manila has horrendous traffic issues. One solution that helps a tad is to close down certain intersections and create strategic u-turn areas available.

This makes me think about the future traffic straddling bus in China: http://forum2.mobile-review.com/showthread.php?p=881706   People can still drive their own cars, and yet there is common public transportation.
Transportation is such a key basic need, as well as a huge cost (both environmentally and monetarily).  Definitely an area ripe for discussion!

look_for_a_method_to_improve_car_owners_.title: Look for a method to improve car owners uses public transportation

how_might_we_design_a_system_in_the_busi.description:
I just had a conversation with someone who is in a marketing department. he has been complaining about the high cost of marketing in supermarkets. He said, a supermaket is charging them a lot of money in an aisle space where more people will see their product quickly and easily. And continued to say, because we fed the greed of that supermarket owners by offering a higher price by out bidding our competitors for the sake of just getting that spot for our products.  

And so it happens, in a pharma company, a group of salesman who has been manipulating sales for the sake of reaching the sales goal for a year to get the tour package as a reward instead of focusing on the process of how it will be done with honesty and integrity and yet reaching the goal.
how_might_we_design_a_system_in_the_busi.creator: fde2fdb1dbf604aede0ffee76d26e4ce
how_might_we_design_a_system_in_the_busi.title: How might we design a system in the business organization that will inspire values with our employees?

national_button_day.description:
We should launch a national button movement where everyone in the United States wears a button at least 3 to 4 inches in diameter.   Building on the inspiration where senior citzens wear buttons of themselves as young kids, adults should wear buttons of themselves as teenagers. Teenagers should wear buttons of themselves as seniors. Kids should wear buttons of themselves as adults.

Kids can just draw what they aspire to be when they grow up as working adults. Teenagers can just photoshop themselves as happy, healthy, retired seniors.  Adults in a midlife crisis can just re-live their teenage years.  And senior citizens can instantly feel young again.
national_button_day.creator: 8757541db3a21588d7952dbb8fb5fe29
national_button_day.title: National Button Day

can_legislative_decisions_be_separated_f.description: The rule of thumb in the U.S. is that any newly elected president has about one year to get anything worth-while accomplished.  After that every subsequent decision will be made with an eye toward the upcoming congressional elections.  Is there any way to redesign the democratic process so that getting elected and staying elected is not the most influential motivating factor?
can_legislative_decisions_be_separated_f.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: Nicholas, thanks for the comment!  I do not have any relevant data pertaining to countries other than the U.S. off the top of my head.  But I do get the sense that this issue is not just relegated to the U.S. but in fact is more about general human nature.  Power wants to stay in power.  Money wants to continue to have money.  These (and other things I am sure) tend to cloud the pure ideal of the democratic process.  I could see that monarchies or dictatorships might not suffer from these faults as much.  Of course there would be a whole other set of problems that those forms of government would have to overcome.  But I digress.  Do you not also get the sense that member countries of the EU also tend to allow their legislative process to be bogged down in efforts to get or remain elected?  The Italian government might be a good case study in broken process...Anyway, thanks again for your comment!  It is an issue worth expansion of reference!
This is definitely an important issue for America, but do we have any information about how this applies to other countries?

Thanks for the comment Pablo!  Very interesting idea to use rolling budgets to separate the grasp for money from the grasp for power.  It seems that money has trumped the just, moral or human right as the prime decision-maker in policy and legislation.  But even with rolling budgets I wonder if it only stretches the current situation rather than change it.  For example a U.S. senator of a certain political party is still going to push for funding for projects that funnel money to people within their state.  The more people that are kept in jobs and happy, the more likely they are to vote for that senator again or for someone else within their political party.  Even if those jobs are for questionable practices such as heavily subsidized, environmentally damaging, unregulated drilling on protected land for fossil fuels (hypothetically speaking).  Regardless of when a budget is voted on it still remains a game of self (or political party) preservation fueled by money.  So to me the question is can a political system be designed so that the policy makers will have incentive to vote for the just, noble or right thing instead of the popular thing?  A tough one to be sure.Thanks again Pablo!

The legislative structure largely relies on budgeting to make practical the enforcement and monitoring of regulations. For me, a complementary question could be what are the incentives for politicians to make policies and decisions without thinking in the next term of office? Do rolling budgets work (e.g., on a 4+2yr basis so the next government is continuist rather than breaking)? Must civilians participate in the vote of budgets?

Thanks for the comment Arjan!  I agree that democracy is a faulty system.  Politicians make promises to get elected and then, once in office, make decisions based only on what popularity polls predict will get them or their party the most votes at the next election.  And it is a universal problem, not just one party.  You mentioned McCain.  Well, if I remember correctly,, Obama pledged (is that the same as a promise?) to close Guantanamo prison.  As far as I know it is still operating two years after he took office.  I think this is a tough problem.  But one, as you mentioned, that should be discussed.  Maybe there is a way to hold politicians accountable for pre-election promises.  If they, as a candidate, make a pledge to do something which brings them popularity and votes, then if elected they must follow through and do it within a certain amount of time or else their party forfeits a seat in the legislature or something.  Of course this would not solve the problem of doing the right thing or tough decisions that have to be made on issues that come up while in office.  But it's a start.Thanks again Arjan!

Great concept. In my opinion this is something that many long-standing democracies suffer from. Many governing periods of elected presidents or governments are too much influenced by the next elections. This makes that long term programmes are more and more ignored, in favor of short tem, populist solutions. What struck me for example in the American mid-terms was the stance of former maverick and presidential candidate John McCain, who went against what he had said before, to enlarge his chance to get reelected in Arizona. But also other examples in other countries point to the same challenge. Hanging on to power seems to become more important than delivering change you believe in. It would be great if a new version of the democratic model can be discussed.

can_legislative_decisions_be_separated_f.title: Can Legislative Decisions be Separated From the Election Cycle?

climate_change_agenda.description: While nations debate and negotiate the climate change protocol, can business contribute towards the climate change agenda?
climate_change_agenda.creator: e7d68a74121c4bc315364113f8043d15

comments.text: Hi WL! You raised an important point here. I believe businesses can and should engage in climate adaptation agenda since the climate change impacts, for example, on food security, are well associated with business bottom line. For instance, in regions that businesses are operated, food security is the basis of sustainable human resources. In addition, cooperating with smallholder farmers helps agribusinesses increase the diversity of their supply chain, and thus sustainability of their businesses. Businesses can also find profits from developing new crop varieties, diversifying supply chain by bringing poor small-scale farmers (who are most likely to be affected by climate change) into their procurement system, developing new technologies to monitor climate change impacts, etc.

I'm confident you're on to something here, WL. The important thing is that we need to find ways to make climate change a profitable business, and then more companies will follow the lead of BHP Biliton. Apparently they have found some profits in it.

climate_change_agenda.title: Climate Change Agenda

don_t_treat_the_elderly_as_victims_but_a.description: In South London, England, Southwark Circle members get together to enjoy a variety of interests and activities, and to learn new things through the Member Calendar. They can also buy tokens to get help from local, reliable Neighbourhood Helpers. Some members also help out fellow members and can earn tokens for doing so.
don_t_treat_the_elderly_as_victims_but_a.creator: d7d03fc4ed767b64ad78b2fdbcd6324c

comments.text: In the Asian context, the elderly was respected. By this the modern society, this concept is largely ignored by the younger generations - thus they think the elderly is more of an liability, a burden to "get rid of". Although we acknowledge that the modern society is a "greying one" [the younger couple not producing enough babies], I think we must realise that we ourselves are not getting any younger and we ourselves are in fact aging and one day (20 years later) will be like the man in the photo (wearing a button to "give ourselves an identity and having to fit in the "modern society" 20 years then". Give ourselves and our children a thought.
Nice one Avi  I like how it furthers Nathan's notion of *enabling.*

Thanks Meena! I've mocked up the idea here:http://www.flickr.com/photos/47222633@N05/5166810349/Maybe Kodak could sponsor this? All the tech stuff to help the elderly is fine but sometimes all they need is a smile of understanding.
Avi  that's such a great idea for a conversation starter!!
What if the elderly wore a button photo of themselves as young kids? This might break the ice and remind the currently young of how they would like to be treated in THEIR old age:)
This is really nice! We've got the same problem in Sweden with elderly people just feeling as a hinder in society. We are all people and we need to feel needed!

Nice one! I love so many of the things that Participle are doing in the social innovation space. While their tag line is "addressing the big social issues of our time"  their solutions are tailored to make a real difference to everyday lives.

Great thought Nathan!  As the world's population of senior citizens grows it is a great idea to figure out ways to capitalize on the power of this 'resource' instead of thinking of them as a liability and drain on the economy.  Good stuff!  Thx!

don_t_treat_the_elderly_as_victims_but_a.title: Don't treat the elderly as victims, but as enablers: Southwark Circle

design_as_education.description: Studio H is a different kind of classroom. Over the course of one calendar year, students earn high school and college credit, and are paid a summer wage to build the community project they have spent the year designing and prototyping.
design_as_education.creator: e64164abfe9be327a5be6b001bdbfdd8

comments.text: What I really like about this idea is that it's not just inspiring kids to think creatively through design, but it might also be sparking a student's interest in entrepreneurship. When kids see they can help solve community issues through coursework like Studio H, perhaps their eyes will open to other problems that need solving and other business opportunities that can be seized?

Emily Pilloton makes a great pitch for thinking about design teaching as an active improvement of one's surroundings, rather than some abstract chart-drawing process. Research skills, material skills, manual skills,  and empowerment all at once. It's similar in some ways to the Fab Lab Concept item:
http://openideo.com/open/what-is-the-global-challenge-that-most-concerns-you-right-now-and-that-global-innovation-leaders-could-begin-to-solve/agenda-concepts/how-can-we-spread-innovation-teach-valuable-skills-and-create-independence-to-developing-countries/
Maybe blend them together...

No amount of virtual social networking  can replace in-person, face to face work. Social networking begins the connection; face to face networking completes the connection and the actual project. School can be the place to integrate the virtual and real world.
Fab example JJ! Creative capital, critical thinking and community driven participation are all brilliantly illustrated in this inspiration.

design_as_education.title: Design as Education

comments.text: Very interesting Nicole. Perhaps participatory budgeting deserves its own Inspiration post?

There are actually some international agencies that have used a similar process in their budgeting and large scale project design - its called participatory budgeting. (Wikipedia: Participatory budgeting is usually characterized by several basic design features: identification of spending priorities by community members, election of budget delegates to represent different communities, facilitation and technical assistance by public employees, local and higher level assemblies to deliberate and vote on spending priorities, and the implementation of local direct-impact community projects.) Porto Allegre, Brazil is one place that adopted a participatory budgeting model for a few innovative reform programs to overcome severe inequality in living standards amongst city residents. The World Bank estimates that the participatory budgeting process directly led to facility improvements. See http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTEMPOWERMENT/Resources/14657_Partic-Budg-Brazil-web.pdf

stand_up_get_up_do_something.description: I want to bring this to the attention of everyone who watches the computer all day: don't just watch your life go by! Stand up. Get up. Do something.  I think the biggest global challenge we face is to slow everybody down, including myself, in this new age of internet technology. Social networkers can communicate and get information very quickly and easily. We hear people talk about helping the environment, which remains in crisis. In specific areas of the world, people talk about corruption and inequality, while many internet users, from where I live, are concerned about Mafia Wars and updating their Facebook and Twitter status. So I say this: why don’t we begin to design things that activate leaders and encourage global participation, rather than having us depend on things that make life quicker and easier, which in turn makes us all passive and lazy?
stand_up_get_up_do_something.creator: 8757541db3a21588d7952dbb8fb5fe29

comments.text:
Check out this article:  http://www.usatoday.com/tech/news/2009-09-22-social-networking-real-time-web_N.htm
I wonder if we lose brain cells from going on Facebook?  Currently the human race is so connected in cyberspace that it's about time we use internet technology to mobilize ourselves and activate leaders.

Very good point about utilizing social media/gaming for social good. One example of this (though of course, there is still so much more that can be done, and to encourage more active participation) is Facebook Causes (http://www.facebooks.com/causes) with almost 25 million monthly active users.
Side Note: nice video clip. Now have "Network" in my Netflix movie queue =P

stand_up_get_up_do_something.title: STAND UP! GET UP! DO SOMETHING!

charter_for_compassion_innovation_meanin.description: How we treat ourselves and others, particularly those with looks, ways, and thinking which are unfamiliar to us, really matters.  If we teach compassion and PRACTICE compassion, we become actively committed to improving all living things.  So regardless of the global issue which is most pressing - providing food and water, improving our environment, encouraging peace, etc. - innovation informed by compassion results in meaningful, holistic solutions for ALL.
charter_for_compassion_innovation_meanin.creator: eb5ba7c977d21014520ad3ee0432d10f

comments.text: Yes! And again: YES! Beautiful inspiration.Don't forget to visit the site and add your name to the charter. I just did :)http://charterforcompassion.org/
Yes, compassion brings meaning and motivation for innovation and action.

charter_for_compassion_innovation_meanin.title: Charter for Compassion + Innovation = Meaningful Action

remake_the_way_we_make_things.description:
It's important to have a clear long term objective.  In my opinion, the following (in the words of William McDonough) is the only acceptable overarching objective for international innovation leadership:   "Create a delightfully diverse, safe, healthy and just world, with clean air, water, soil and power - economically, equitably, ecologically and elegantly enjoyed. Where children of all species are honored." -William McDonough.  We should start moving towards this preferred situation one system at a time (system = product, service, building, factory, city, country, planet).  The principles behind the Cradle to Cradle Design Framework enable us to do so in a holistic way.   Let's start with 1000 C2C certified products in the short term. (See http://www.C2CInnovation.org .)
Products that are characterized by the following: 1. Non-Toxic    2. Managed Nutrient Flows   3. 100% Renewable Energy   4. Pure Water   5. Socially Responsible
remake_the_way_we_make_things.creator: ae4277446e55b6d2d65860ff7e1407b3

comments.text: Yeah, it's great. From what he says in this talk, there's still quite a lot of R&D and construction of new material production technologies to get the tree-house going. Architecture that sequesters carbon is a great idea... edible architecture?

I really like this extract from the talk: "Imagine this design assignment: Design something that makes oxygen, sequesters carbon, fixes nitrogen, distills water, accrues solar energy as fuel, makes complex sugars and food, creates microclimates, changes colors with the seasons and self-replicates. Well, why don't we knock that down and write on it?", William McDonough (talking about trees)

This is related to another entry of mine on another challenge:
http://www.openplanetideas.com/how-can-sony-technology-be-used-to-address-environmental-challenges/concepting/soft-design-an-organic-approach-to-consumer-electronics/
It is an important concept.

remake_the_way_we_make_things.title: Remake the Way we Make Things

matching_the_elderly_with_young_people.description: The elderly population is growing in developed countries and often they tend to live on their own/alone. On the other hand, there are young people starting out in universities/work that need a place to stay. By having an exchange centre to match a young person with an elderly person, this could work for mutual benefit.
matching_the_elderly_with_young_people.creator: e7d68a74121c4bc315364113f8043d15

comments.text: Justin, the elderly should not be forgotten and pushed aside - they still have must to contribute in terms of what they know. My friend's father of 80 is a very experienced carpenter (not his profession) and he still takes time to teach his grand kids. From what I saw of the program on TV, there are sufficient checks in place to ensure that it can run smoothly.
Thanks Vincent. When I watched this on TV, I did think that this was such a brilliant idea. It would certainly be great to see how else this can be extended to other groups for mutual benefit.

This can be utilized for teaching as well.  Forget universities, simply bring young people and older people together because the elderly have all the gained knowledge.  They can then trade/barter their knowledge for the physical things their body can no longer do.  However, a young person could learn needed job skills, etc. from their elders in exchange.  I'd worry about having a young person care for my grandma though, because most young people have not gained the skills in home care to care for themselves, let alone someone else.  However these skills must be learned and there are ways to exchange knowledge

Wow WL, that's a great inspiration for building intergenerational relationships. Thanks for sharing! I wonder what other groups that currently have limited interaction could be matched up in a mutually beneficial way (with the additional benefit of increasing exposure to different perspectives, one of the roots of innovation).

matching_the_elderly_with_young_people.title: Matching the Elderly with Young People

the_creativity_crisis.description: We need to realize that creativity is a human resource.  And whenever society breaks down our creativity, it contributes to a global crisis.
the_creativity_crisis.creator: 8757541db3a21588d7952dbb8fb5fe29

comments.text: Kristine  feel free to post OpenIDEO as a stand alone Inspiration post  describing what needs/issues it is meeting : )

I think this is a great topic. Schools need not necessary to the one that "kills" creativity. It is the modern society that "kills" creativity. We in our chase to do our best and be our best, will not allow our children to sit there quietly to think to "mess around" with their hands and "get dirty". in major cities, there are hardly any trees left to climb, no tall grasses to run in, it is no empty fields to lie down and stare at the clouds! We should engage ourselves in this area before the next generation takes over our governments and our future lives.
Here's an interesting rendition of one of Sir Ken's talks: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zDZFcDGpL4U

Hi Eric Its inspiring to know other parts of the world value the creative process into the school curriculum, especially in impoverished countries and cities like Manila.  :)
Emily  I definitely agree that creativity is an essential human quality unlike linear ways of thinking or anything that restricts our behavior.  This goes back to the arguement that society shouldnt break us down for our creativity.  When society breaks down our creativity, it breaks us down as humans.  ;)
And Amy  I always thought that creativity and destruction go hand and hand together, but couldnt really explain it to other people as well as how you articulate consumerism and output.  :D
And finally for all of the Open IDEO community to know  In addressing the most innovative thing going on, I am surprised none of us have mentioned Open IDEO yet. Designers from all over the world are coming together here, at this spot, which gives us a chance to contribute independently, while we also get to collaborate as a creative community.  
According to experts like Ken Robinson, the creative process is all about 3 components: imagining, creating, and innovating.  We definitely need to enable creativity in our society.
So kudos not only to Open IDEO, but to you guys!

Great inspiration, Kristine. VCIS, an international school based here in Manila has taken a proactive stance in supporting Ken Robinson's advice by creating a curriculum with mind mapping, multiple intelligences and assessing the student properly to utilize their unique giftings. A very encouraging and hopeful approach to education and highly inspirational. I wish I went to this school!

Ken Robinson is an amazing man. I think the time and space to allow creativity to evolve from it's very embryonic stages to fruition is impoverished in an over hurried world. We need to carve out opportunity for creativity. It is after all the crucial characteristic that makes us human.

This is so true; the only solution to the consumer mindset is a creative one. That is not to say that consumerism is a bad thing - it provides its benefits, but it needs to be alongside creativity/creative output, otherwise there is little to consume in the first place.

the_creativity_crisis.title: The Creativity Crisis

see_what_our_challenges_are.creator: da0cc2802d6ef48e9a64ff4fc5cf25f2

comments.text: Yes agreed this is an essential consideration and one we should all be considering during the conception phase. Various patterns are emerging from the inspirations that have been submitted. Too often it is only those who shout the loudest that are pushed to the top of the agenda. This means those least equipped to have their voices heard, the very people who are often most vulnerable are least likely to have their needs met.At least in part I would hope that we will tackle how we should include those most hard to reach in thinking about how we set global agendas.
www.gapminder.org   :) I just wanted to add that lovely project here next to your inspiration.

see_what_our_challenges_are.title: See what our challenges are

how_can_we_improve_local_food_production.description: Improving local food production and distribution models is key for environmental sustainability, community heath and a thriving, local agricultural industry. How do we build a system of positive behavioral incentives that encourage local, healthy eating habits?
how_can_we_improve_local_food_production.creator: 677b685af5345b36ecb6d35b4852cc5c

comments.text: Check out VIACOOP a mexican network that links producers with consumers. http://www.via.coop/
And Paul, yes. Damn the FDA. The most un-progressive federal agency. We need policy support for small farmers more than anything else. That starts by educating consumers.

That is an awesome observation, Meena! I think that creating a sense of pride in local agriculture is really important. I was also thinking that design could play an important role. Like, what if you went into a grocery store and there was a visualization of where your food came from, its carbon footprint, how much it ACTUALLY cost (taking into account subsidies and externalities). Of course no chain grocery store would support this, but maybe a whole food would or something. That might have to be something like a cell phone app for now, but I just thing that the audience is necessarily limited to people who are already thinking about these things. Even an art exhibit or something would be really fascinating. 
Arjan, good points, though I would argue that food aid and cheap subsidized imports do more to harm to developing countries' agriculture base than a growth of local farming would cause in the US / Europe. Wonder what the economic impact would be on local economies if there were less imports going INTO Africa. 
SO much of this is about education. It's a hidden problem in a lot of ways. As westerners, we have the luxury of walking into a store, and picking up a piece of fruit without being told to think twice about where our food comes from. This is where creativity comes in. Showing people in a visual way, how their food choices impact the rest of the world (and their communities).
Speaking of local food sources  I was totally impressed with observations in Nairobi slums earlier this month: http://bit.ly/mathare_thrive

I like your idea. Food from local sources is important. On the other hand, wasteful subsidies and practices also limit the competition from other countries. The upside of food produced in Africa for the European market is that it brings economic value to poorer regions. But I believe there is a good balance. Over at OpenPlanetIdeas, there have been some nice concepts, such as the Sustainable Shopper, where information of production methods and production location are made available through a barcode-reading app on a mobile phone. This could help, maybe?

We can begin by oppose the Food Safety Act--if it is not too late-- which would impose fees on small farmers that are too much. It also has misguided theories about the problems, going too far with germophobia and ignoring the problems with gmo and toxicity in food. The problems of small farmers include FDA raids on raw milk producers and consumer coops with confiscation of their food, computers, and equipment in both cases. Raw dairy is one of the most healing foods and does not have the risks they say it has. Pasteurized dairy is the dangerous one that spoils when old, unlike raw milk that turns into yogurt and cream into sour cream. Pasteurization also is the main cause of dairy allergies.

how_can_we_improve_local_food_production.title: Incentivizing local food production and consumption

comments.text: Great post, James!  This concept is so true and it empowers individuals to understand one another and show appreciation in simple ways...even a smile, at the right time, can be a very valuable gift.
Love this pay it forward thinking is something we can ALL participate in

teaching_people_how_to_give_gifts_throug.title: Teaching people how to give gifts through their work

schools_can_teach_mind_mapping_to_innova.description: A mind map is a powerful method to radially document your thinking, in solving problems, planning, organizing and brainstorming.
schools_can_teach_mind_mapping_to_innova.creator: 96f79338ea6b1a2b9da850e94922a102

comments.text: Completely agree. It took me until grad school to discover how powerful mind maps are.

I agree. As someone who has never been strong on standardized tests, but was a top student in school, I fear that the [US] education system is too quick to jump on standardized tests as a form of evaluation, when people clearly learn in different ways. Furthermore, where is the creativity in teaching to the test? And how can we ever innovate if we're just trying to pass a test?

YES. I am trained as a lawyer and one of my biggest gripes is that lawyers are rarely taught systems thinking. How does this policy affect an outcome in another State? How do policies actually affect people's lives? (Just two). The ability to map out processes and causal chains and actually SEE system would be so important to thinking more holistically about the world we live in. Not only is it important to instill this in the brains of young people, but also professional - lawyers, business grads, etc. who get caught in linear patterns for all of their problem solving needs.

schools_can_teach_mind_mapping_to_innova.title: Schools Can Teach Mind Mapping to Innovate (Philippines)

available_water_for_all.description:
AVAILABLE WATER FOR ALL.  How to allow provision of this raw material for the whole of humanity? Each knows  ( for it no need of  statistics ) that water rarefies itself , that water is unevenly distributed on the globe surface and that water ( not for packaging but  for detection, production and  preservation ) becomes object of eager speculations.
Besides this , the more an entity is rare, the better is its value, indeed its preciousness character fully come out.

There is many perceptions of its preciousness  some people want to guarantee its regular supply without additional constraints, others aim to treat it like any commodity or product under  rough or oppressive trade conditions
available_water_for_all.creator: c846ad488745538ea805daa7dd2b5349

comments.text:
I agree with your stance entirely regarding the notion of water being of intrinsic value to all life, and also feel that individual or familial water generation may be one of the best ways to ensure water is available world wide, however it can't be the only answer.  If water supplies were at least augmented with individual de-humidifying technology, surely our limited yet cyclical supplies would indeed last a bit longer, but not enough to combat the steady pace of population advancement.  It may be on the right path for a longer term solution, provided the technology and innovation were to make strides in the right direction.  I believe additional effort should be placed on desalinization innovation, to expedite the process and provide relief for areas of the world that are much too dry to make much use out of de-humidifying air tech to gather water to augment their supplies, such as near deserts, where water is needed the most.  
Without a doubt though, water will become one of the most valuable resources in times of severe pollution or conflict between nations.  If there is a way to prevent inevitable war, and to make the world healthier (maybe not 8 glasses a day healthy, but close), then I'm all for it.  Perhaps it simply requires more funding and innovation..

available_water_for_all.title: How to allow provision of water for the whole of humanity?

create_a_can_mentality_for_those_with_co.description: We are facing an epidemic withhigh numbers of people  born with congenital defects/disabilities yet we haven't  adapted to include these people.  Unless we can begin finding unique ways to include them in productive ways they will become a drain to our resources not a benefit.   If we continue to see them as needy and helpless then we will begin euthenizing and destroying this class of citizens in mass because of financial drains.  Innovative products can assist all physical and neurological handicaped people in becoming contributors. There exists the potential to create virtual rehabilitation programs.  Utilize virtual reality technology to aid in the improvement of disabled people.  Think of the movie Avatar.  This can be utilized in all therapy they can virtually exist in a more pleasing environment to improve the mental part of getting healthy.
create_a_can_mentality_for_those_with_co.creator: 3162a04a0b81bc677801cdecb83df486
create_a_can_mentality_for_those_with_co.title: Create a Can mentality for those with congenital birth defects.

how_do_we_accomodate_a_sustainable_power.description: Throughout the western world a contemporary debate surrounding sustainable energy production is starting to take form. The developing world is still very much a wild west for power companies, where they grab the chance to build irresponsible and dangerous power plants in the middle of cities and sensitive nature areas.
how_do_we_accomodate_a_sustainable_power.creator: 807f60c58a227daba50d747acf74001b

comments.text: Tank you for the comment Ren. Good stuff and definitely one (good) way of doing it. However, I think what is important is to be aware of the problems and opportunities, and present an opening for a fruitful discussion between different sides and stakeholders, not necessarily provide the answers.There is problems with bottling solutions like those, I think that every situation needs to be handled with care and insight in the specific context.

The rich countries make an investment for their own future, by investing in transfer of clean technology to underdeveloped countries and developing countries. Because the poor countries will otherwise copy the unsustainble development and use of raw materials depleting the earth of its resources at a faster rate,  the developed countries will have difficulty in finding raw materials and most of all finding clean sources of water, good quality soils for plantation in the future. The underdeveloped contries must take the leap to a sustainable development path and diminish the use of oil, old wasteful and energy consuming means of production.  One way to achieve this is to give long term finance and create the means to finance join pilot cleantech projects to produce renewable energy and also to transfer clean technology where its needed to purify water, reduce waste, increase energy efficiency in industry by introducing lean management techniques and so on. All this cost a lot but it will pay off. Finding the right partners is dificult NGOs can facilitate the task, BSDH Bolivian Sustainable Development Hub www.bsdhub.org  is an example of hybrid NGO and tech transfer partner betwen the Nordic countries and Bolivia, an alliances of this type are needed to accelerate the rate  of  clean technology transfer to undeveloped countries.

how_do_we_accomodate_a_sustainable_power.title: How do we support sustainable power alternatives for the developing world?

comments.text:
My friend Ardyn Halter suggests: "I really like the idea Avi and think that you could initiate it by working with a municipality - perhaps one on each of the five continents on the same day. Call it "Generations Day" - which should take place once a year (but could continue on other days too). It should be launched by  engaging with the social welfare department of municipalities on five continents.
And on that day as many people as possible would commute to work, the very young wearing the badge of one of their grandparents' image on it, the elderly with photos of themselves when they were young."
Maybe companies like Kodak or Sony could sponsor the actual photo buttons and publicize the "Generations Day"?

finding_innovation_in_every_corner.creator: 0ebfe65ca16ea82675e4294e27747639

comments.text: Nice one Eric! That cycle washing machine could solve the obesity problem as well ;^)

Great! Check out these grassroots innovations, both washing machines that also keep you in shape:
http://www.worldchanging.com/archives/006333.html (scroll to the bottom)andhttp://www.mygreenphilippines.com/wordpress/?p=68 or http://il.youtube.com/watch?v=ogZX5hGOFNA

Hey Vincent  the main thrust of Honey Bee dissemination is via their printed newsletter as most of their innovators are not online. I guess that's an issue in terms of sharing info in this realm. Besides Honey Bee's regular national scouting, they do this great thing called Shodh Yatra bi-annually where they go on a two week rural search for innovations as a group of students and other interested parties (PopTech joined them one time) They distribute the newsletter along the way and get a lot of interest that way. They got a huge boost when 3 of their grassroots innovations got featured in a Bollywood blockbuster last year!
Am also keen to know what else the OpenIDEO community can point to in regards to initiatives that are enhancing grassroots innnovation. Maker Faire Africa is doing a good job of bringing folks together at that end  though is mainly focused on their annual event: http://bit.ly/emeka_o

Nice one Meena! The Honey Bee database (http://www.sristi.org/hbnew/honeybee_database.php) is quite impressive, as are the true partnerships with the local, material resource poor, but knowledge/innovation rich people.  Anyone know of any related efforts out there? Off the top, I know of Appropedia ( http://www.appropredia.org ), which is an open source wiki for sustainability, poverty reduction, and international development through appropriate technology and collaboration. Also curious about what are the different ways that are being used to collaboratively gather, develop, disseminate, and fairly compensate innovative solutions locally.

finding_innovation_in_every_corner.title: Cross-pollination: Honey Bee Network (India)

Very nice. Rory Sutherland from Ogilvy says "... many flashy, expensive fixes are just obscuring better, simpler answers..." in this TED Talk (http://bit.ly/c3XmKG). Your idea might just qualify.

can_we_turn_cities_into_rainforests.description: What can nature teach us about the way complex systems work? Rainforests are essential to the stability of the planet's environment. They are the home to millions of species and involve huge ecosystems where organisms are interconnected and interdependent.
can_we_turn_cities_into_rainforests.creator: ca701b75a86614da4ee800558fc6954f

comments.text: Rainforests should be studied a bit more to truly understand the interdependency and social relationships that create the homeostasis within the system. With this information we can try and create biomimicry social models that could allow for sustainable city life, both environmentally and socially.

I think this is a great idea, learning from complex natural ecosystems, like the rain forest, and see how we can use that knowledge to improve cities. With urbanization projected to grow in the foreseeable future, it is important to improve the sustainability and 'liveability' of cities.

Hi Kale, I do not mean literally turn cities into rainforests, but rather look at the way rainforest ecosystems work as a model for urban innovation. For example, let's make buildings run on sunlight, clean air and become interconnected with the surrounding environment and people. Turning cities into rainforests is purely symbolic of the potential positive impact cities can have on the world.

I evaluated your concept and had this to say about it.  Now when you say 'turn cities into rain forests', do you mean to knock down existing ones and replacing them with native species of trees to stimulate the tree and wildlife population?  If so, I thought it would be better to expand on the idea and, instead of removing cities, work to preserve the land around them.  There are plenty of stretches of unpopulated land that can be used to harbor arbor life.  :)
I like the idea of bringing more trees, but I think that there are bigger problems that ought to be faced right now.  Especially considering with the current state of the world.

Hi Jan,completely agree, we should always take a systems approach and be careful not to focus purely on what we think of cities. I see cities as the sum of everything that it connects to, which will inevitably include rural areas etc etc. A systems map could potentially be very revealing but also almost inexhaustible. 
The way I see it, is that there is beautiful complexity, in say the rainforest ecosystem which produces something incredible, and ugly complexity which can usually be found in that of the city and often produces a negative impact on our environment. How can we make cities beautifully complex?

Hi, 
I like this idea a lot though I suggest that what needs to be clarified is what the city actually is. In terms of impact on the world, cities are much more efficient per capita  then rural communities. An urban citizen requires comparatively fewer resources in a city than a rural citizen though of course there are many more in cities. My point is that these cities are sustained by vast complex supply systems, particularly food, water and power systems. As such, I think the discussions would have to include elements of the supply and waste processing chains that enable cities to exist in first place. So, to sum up, an interesting sub-discussion could be 'how do we define the boundaries of a modern city to understand its impact?' It seems that the answer would have to be much more than just the particular circle that has been drawn around the city by an orbital motorway or urban planners.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Living_machines explains "Living Machines" artificially constructed living marshes which use biological action to clean waste water and sewage.

can_we_turn_cities_into_rainforests.title: Can we turn cities into rainforests?

py/tuple: Does this concept deserve a place on the i20 agenda?
Yes – it's definitely a significant global issue requiring innovation
Maybe – it's important but there are other issues which deserve more attention
No – it's interesting but not of global significance
Does this concept point to innovation opportunities that i20 leaders can discuss?
It points to a range of opportunities
It points to a single opportunity
It's indeed a challenge but doesn't point to opportunities
Is this concept well framed?
Yes – it relevantly covers the issue to promote onwards discussion
Somewhat – though the scope is either too narrow or too wide
Not really – interesting issue but this concept doesn't really invite conversation

how_can_the_growth_of_the_obesity_epidem.description: The rate of obesity in America has been steadily increasing.  Today more than 26.6% of American adults are obese.  And the number continues to rise.  How do we stop this unhealthy and costly trend from affecting not only the United States but also the rest of the world?
how_can_the_growth_of_the_obesity_epidem.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: Sabra, thanks for the slew of interesting ideas!  I agree that simple but effective methods such as the thermal cooking you mentioned need to be promoted more.  Even 'no cooking' -a hearty salad- can be great:)You also have a good point about the transportation issues faced by many people.  But maybe this issue is coupled with your last point about education.  Where there is demand, in a healthy economy, that demand will be met.  So if people in lower income areas under-served by good healthy food options, demonstrate that they want to spend their money buying seasonal vegetables rather than cheap cheese burgers, I bet that the vegetables will find their way to them somehow.  I like your comment about urban gardening.  I had a similar concept for the Jamie Oliver challenge http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-give-children-the-knowledge-to-eat-better/concepting/student-city-lot-farming-project/ Maybe a hybrid solution would be to not only facilitate urban farming and education projects but to also subsidize the operation of a fleet of fruits and vegetables trucks to travel to the marginalized neighborhoods and sell healthy food where there are no good quality grocery stores within reasonable reach.  Some great opportunities there.Thanks again Sabra!

I think linking weight loss to solving hunger issues as you suggest is a really good idea. I wonder what other ways that could be done?Most people I know don't know how to cook well. I'm a big fan of time and energy efficient cooking.
"thermal cooking" , where the food is heated on a stove to boiling then placed in an insulated container to continue cooking for several hours and stay hot for hours more, has great potential for making easy inexpensive, healthy food portable. Portable thermal cookers are all over Asia, relatively available in most of the rest of the world, but strangely are not readily available in the U.S. except among the DIY crowd on the Web.The last time they were at all popular here was during the "Great Depression" of the 1930s. Social groups and churches held training meetings to teach women how to make and use the cookers. This is ancient technology that reduces energy used in cooking by 50-80%, and makes a family meal portable if desired.They are becoming quite popular in some parts of Africa as well because of the reduction in fuel gathering necessary for cooking.Thermal cooking is great for beans, grains and stews,(anything cooked in a closed pot) and thus fits well in most traditional cooking worldwide.
Fast food eaten by the poor is picked up on the way to or home from work at whatever cheap place is on the way. If households lack adequate affordable public transportation, then choices are limited to walking distance Whether they are taking the bus or using a carpool type arrangement, simply getting to a real grocery store, where you have to stop, go in and look for what you need can be a challenge to add to the time budget. Many areas have no grocery store within walking or easy bus distance. All the food available is fast food or convenience store bottom of the barrel (not very good). 
The idea of teaching that many people to cook after being trained out of it for almost 2 generations now is pretty daunting, but I agree it is completely necessary. Urban gardening has more potential to feed people well than trying to get real grocery stores into places where they won't immediately prosper.

Sabra, thanks for the thoughts!  I totally understand your point about less privileged people not having the time, energy (or money) to work out or afford a gym membership, etc.  But I think that the idea that making healthy meals at home takes a lot longer than picking up fast food is a myth.  Yes, availability in poor neighborhoods of good, healthy food can be an issue.  But the time it takes to prepare it does not have to be an issue at all.  I think with a little education and the right mindset and everyone can make cheap but healthy food at home in very little time.  Jamie Oliver's 'Food Revolution' series and his OpenIDEO challenge http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-give-children-the-knowledge-to-eat-better/brief.html were very much focused on this.Maybe one of the actual hindrances to this is that our culture has largely forgotten how to cook.  Since it seems as though all adults in a family usually have to work to pay the bills, very rarely is there a person that stays home and prepares meals.  So the importance of this skill has been put aside because of work economics.  And today people solve this problem by buying more pre-prepared foods, whether from the grocery store or fast food.  This practice tends to skew calorie intake and fat intake. higher because of portion size and ingredients used.Your charity idea is interesting for it's educational aspect.  Maybe an organization could be developed that would assist poor families with money for food if they agreed to go to educational cooking courses.  Or something like that....Interesting stuff to think about.  Thanks again!

The fitness trainers at one of the places I work are really good at helping people improve their diets. People are motivated to do so because folks (especially women) can't really lose weight with exercise alone. 
People who have a hard time making ends meet usually work really long hours to keep their families fed, clothed and housed. They have little time or energy for food prep, poor availability of convenient healthy food, little opportunity for pleasant exercise and little money to work with. The solutions to these problems are much more complex.
I wonder if a charity model such as I mentioned in my previous comment could be used to help the relatively affluent to fund helping the much less affluent to learn how and be able to eat healthy and exercise appropriately?

Sabra,Thanks for the comment!Exercise, and more of it, is always a good thing.  And any way we can be incentivized to do it is a stairmaster step in the right direction.  Unfortunately, though, all the exercise in the world is not going to be able to keep up with the damaging effects of a societal diet heavy on low-quality, super-processed, high-sugar, high-bad-fat foods.  And it seems like the major driving factor in the development of our collective diet is price.  We use price to decide what we eat.  And the fast food restaurant chains are in a perpetual battle to own the bottom of the pricing gauge.  And then they derivate from there.  Combo meals, Happy Meals, Dollar menus, Buy One Get One For Free, etc. are all working to make the eater feel like they are getting the most food for the money.  Ironic that in reality the cheapest way to eat is to make it yourself.  Not to mention that home made food has the potential to be much more healthy.  And doubly ironic that all of this eating of unhealthy but cheap fast food ends up costing us dearly, both in the billions and billions of dollars spent treating the effects of obese lifestyles and in our shortened lifespans.  If we were smart we would be spending all of that money trying to change the source of our perception that a diet heavy on fast food is a viable lifestyle than spending it on the obesity and poor health that is the product of this vast and damaging way of life.Thanks again Sabra!

I recently heard about a program where people can participate in charity fundraisers by exercising at gyms and fitness centers. For example: the gym or fitness center verifies "distance" of exercise biking by an individual rider. The rider gets sponsored by individuals, the charity they support and even sometimes by the fitness center. The person exercising to lose weight gets the additional motivation of helping others as they help themselves, and the help of fitness trainers to make sure they do it in a healthy safe way.With cell phone apps and exercise equipment with digital reporting capability, people could get their exercise outside of the gym counted too.Quality, quiet under desk exercisers could really help to provide better exercise opportunities for office workers and students. Some are already on the market, but they haven't achieved much market penetration yet. The charity angle could help with that too.

Nicole, thanks for the comment!  Your frequent shopper card idea is great!  I think we underestimate how much people respond to positive incentives such as this.  Even seemingly small incentives.  Let people feel like they are earning points toward either receiving something for free or in competition with others and their behavior will be influenced.  This idea may not work enough to create a whole-sale reversal in obesity rates but I think it could definitely be part of the puzzle of a solution.Thanks again!

I honestly think its about creating positive incentives instead of punishments. I.e., there are a few stores that now have cards you can scan at checkout to receive health information. What if like frequent shopper cards, consumers were rewarded with points for healthy purchases and then got a coupon or some other reward? 
I am not sure if taxes change behaviors permanently, it seems more often the case that people just spend more or find other ways to get their fix.

Ashley, Thanks for your comment! I agree with you in that price perception is a major factor.  My guess, though, is that government subsidies for big agro-business have helped to skew pricing and keep certain things artificially low while at the same time leaving other products to suffer normal market forces. I might also suggest that our culture's zombie-like brand awareness plays a role too but maybe that conversation can be saved for another time:)  I also agree with you in that education and access are key in turning people to more healthy eating options.  This was one of the main focal points of the Jamie Oliver challenge that OpenIDEO recently completed.  You've probably already seen it but just in case check it out here: http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-give-children-the-knowledge-to-eat-better/brief.htmlEducating the public about healthy food is important to think about.  Jamie Oliver has been doing some great work in this space.  But much more is needed!  What strikes me is that I think this is a modern problem.  The mechanization and industrialization of food brought on by post World War Two manufacturing advances have caused our culture to quickly collectively forget the food traditions that our grandparents and their parents passed down.  If we look to absolutely any culture just 100 years ago we might see that they were all just as (if not more) price sensitive as we are.  Yet they were able to eat both cheaply and relatively healthfully.  I'm sure it was also helpful that everything they ate was not super-refined and super-processed.  I think some valuable lessons have been lost since then.  But they are out there!  We just have to get them back!Thanks again for your comment!

Johan, Thanks for the comment!  As usual, great thoughts.  Yes, the high fat, high sodium, high sugar foods developed by fast food restaurants and snack companies are supremely engineered to produce in us immediate gratification, fixation and future craving.  And, yes, the health problems in us and our children that develop from a diet heavy in these highly processed calories are real and dangerous.I agree that banning fast food or making it illegal might be a bit of an overreaction.  But then the question remains - how do we address this grave and growing problem?Thanks again for your comment!

Hi Demian,Obesity is definitely a big issue in the US, and as fast food spreads to other parts of the world, I'm sure we'll start seeing obesity rates rising elsewhere (and in fact they may be already!). The challenge, that I'm sure you're aware of, is price. Americans are especially price sensitive - we want our food (and everything else) fast and cheap. Increasing quality most often means increasing price, and when you're trying to provide for your family, it's hard to argue with a 99c hamburger. The issue then becomes how we can increase access to affordable, quality food while also providing the education and training families need to understand 1) the health benefits of eating better foods and 2) how to actually cook it!Thanks for your great questions and ideas,Ashley

Demian, keep up the great thinking!
I was going to say something else appreciative to you in the comment below,
but i have not exactly the best focus or concentration today.
I think I must be still severely hungover from the sugarrush i took on sunday?:):D;-p

Hi. As usual you have great and provocatively solid thoughts.The extreme way you mention of making "fast food" illegal is a bit too much, even for me.But If it was made illegal for companies to serve you more sugar than a set daily dose? Or if it was made a law that companies must show you the sideeffects of each meal you purchase? Or if it was illegal to subsidies growing sugar and was put a tax on it in the restaurants, that should go to the expensive health care that needs to take care of the obese individuals.-----What I have learned about fast food is that the ingredients is combined so cleverly by the restaurant chains that it is containing the perfect contents of it, and in perfect amounts to make you addicted to it.Yes! Sugar is in extreme dose in the soda.Carbohydrates is packed in the fries/chips.and Protein and transfats in the meat.There can be 44 teaspoons of sugar in one regular serving of soda!!!The artificial sweeteners have strange effects on peoples organs, and can be the sole reason to diabetic diseases!
Yes! sugar is addictive! it is medically examined and proven!
The amounts of sugar that kids consume these days is hitting the physical and emotional central nervous system and makes them happy, exhilarated and doped up. It will make them crave more! yes, the hormones in kids makes them crazy.It is already commonly known as sugar rush!it is the biggest reason to concentrational issues in school and with falling results of their education as the biggest result. The reason to "new disorders" like ADHD, ADD, dyslexia, obesity is right under parents nose. And they keep stuffing their own kids full of the drugs.
And still people would b relatively free to eat whatever they feel like. Some of them already know the side-effects, but many keep on, like heroin-junkies, they drink soda in huge-mega-gulp-containers. and they cannot stop.
This is dangerous vicious negative spiral. And in worst case scenario it is what makes difference between healthy people (getting good jobs and good salaries) and unhealthy people (unemployed, poor, not being able to buy and eat healthy food)This obesity problem used to be a problem only in U.S.A, but as the notion of living the american dream is spreading to all continents, I guess it is only matter of months or weeks before this problem arises in Chinese cities too.-----Technology must be put to use to educate people, educational system must bring in the parents to show difference in how their children performs on a standard test before and after a fast-food-diet/sugar rush.Political systems must be changed to inflict massive attitude and behavioral change for many people. Tax must be applied on companies and products that cause huge negative effects in society. Tax incentives must be put to good use in order to improve society! Subsidies on practices that is bad should be stopped!Make subsidies transparent and mandatory to show each customer in the fast food restaurant, to make them see who is behind the profit in their lunch. and to make customers understand why there is some very creepy clown standing behind them making sure they eat it all up! How do the food chains make profit and why!----Oh, by the way, it is only in the advertising that says fast food is fast, cheap and tastes good!I was at one of those places on sunday. It took long time, the staff was confused undereducated school kids (working for slave wage), My dinner cost enourmously much  (at least 4 times more as for what it would have cost for me to cook my normal healthy dinner at home!)And it was not really tasty, fries was rancid with bad cooking oil and the soda watered out and tasted only sugar and water.And i was hungry again after just two hours. (it was probably the f***ing sugar and empty carbohydrates?)

I heard about this but really doubt it becomes a reality unless the consumers start pushing for that change, it is clear for me that corporations, in other words, the people with Real power don't have this in their agenda and I don't think policy makers have the freedom to take this decision. It is up to us "consumers" to generate and promote a whole new set of standards in every product we buy. i wonder what would happen to every industry if they were forced to take their products back after being used, it would definitely push society towards a more sustainable future i believe but how many people would find this transition very inconvenient and how can we support those industries to get ready?
Great comments guys! cheers

Another idea Annie Leonard promotes is "Take back" laws for more and more products to be returned to producers.

how_can_we_use_technology_to_make_open_d.description: A large portion of our population is ignorant about the important issues of our government. And, the sources by which we gain information about the government are increasingly biased and unreliable. Social media technology is able to connect large numbers of people, communicate large amounts of information quickly, and eliminate hierarchical structures. The question is, how can we connect these resources to solve the problem of closed and apathetic democracy?
how_can_we_use_technology_to_make_open_d.creator: 7f9d326151b299e1e2fbcd951317ee68

comments.text: I agree that this has got to be one of the most important questions of our time. While a great number of challenges face America and the world we live in, we risk following the same paths if we do not find a way to be more inclusive, in order to find new solutions.

The one way I can see America adopting a technologically driven open government system in the future is if the idea gets big in the younger generations-- and sticks around for a while, until all the old guys retire and the new guys move in with newer thinking.
Countries that I believe would be more open to this:
Iceland is having ordinary citizens draw up a new constitution. They're willing to make a big shift when the time calls for it. Much of America is too proud to even consider rewriting the holy constitution. I think for technology to make an impact in government, it should be at the core-- acknowledge at the very least.
Portugal is adopting new technology-- they're building a completely sustainable city!
Countries like these. They'd probably be more willing to adopt a technological government.

Meena, thanks for the resources.  I'm very interested in Brazil's wiki-legislation, though it clearly needs more development.  The mashable article you posted also had a good point in regards to Luke's comment.  It pointed out that most of America's congresspeople were sworn in before the digital revolution.  So, we can expect some increased acceptance technology (and less shortsightendess :-)) in the coming years, as more techies take office.
Like the voter video too.  Nice retrospective that shows this kind of enhanced community we can create with social tech.

Luke, I am afraid you might be correct, though I wish it weren't true.  The entire country can't be like San Francisco, I guess.  Addressing this globally will at least get the process started that will eventually get America to change its approach.  I think that America could get onboard this movement if we saw it work in those smaller countries.
I'm curious which countries you think would be more open to this approach?

I can't agree more, Nicholas! I've had the same thoughts and probably have some notes on my thoughts about an open cultured government / society somewhere. Realistically though, America is too shortsighted. I don't see this happening here.
Where I see potential is with smaller, more innovative countries, or through bringing up failing countries-- sidestepping the mistakes the rest of the world took.
For larger countries to entertain the idea would require it's been experimented and proven highly successful elsewhere.
I think some aspects of a technologically-driven open democratic country might be possible in America, but I'm not sure how effective it would be.

Nice one, Nick. Brazil is doing some interesting things in this space: http://on.mash.to/hHB06N I also like this initiative which harnessed citizen journalism in the last US general election: http://bit.ly/c5OxEZ It encompasses innovation, engagement and democracy.

Great thoughts Nicholas. You might like to pull over more related posts from the Inspiration phase, like http://bit.ly/gdvOdC, to increase your DQ points : ) To do this you can use the Update button on the right of this post. And we're sure other OpenIDEATORS would be interested if you added a link for the Sunlight Foundation.

Andrea, while I agree that technology isn't the only piece of open democracy, it is critical to open democracy's success.  The connective power of the internet makes social media one of the most powerful ways to connect citizens to governments.  Nothing else in our society has the power to make the activities of the government as transparent and as accessible.  Technology is so exciting because of this potential.  And, that excitement can be leveraged into civil engagement if Gov 2.0 is executed properly.

The effective use of technology and social media is one part of creating open government. Many call the use of technology in government Gov 2.0. While the economy use of technology is a game changer, it is only one part of open government, under the Obama Administration it's the Open Government Directive, which includes collaboration, participation and transparency/accountability. Much of our drive towards open gov. includes using technology, but is by no means the whole story. This can get lost with all the excitement around technology. I posit the idea that true open gov is much more complex and includes, among other things innovation in organizational design and strong capacity building models if we want citizen involvement.

how_can_we_use_technology_to_make_open_d.title: How can we use technology to create open democracy?
