nurturing_entrepreneurs_worldwide_global.description: When I think about global challenges that require innovative thinking and solutions, I immediately turn to the need for entrepreneurship education for children. In the United States, there are a couple of great nonprofits teaching kids the basics of business, entrepreneurship and financial literacy (Junior Achievement, NFTE, and The BizWorld Foundation to name a few). Interestingly, what you see outside of the US (especially in developing countries like Brazil, for instance), are instances of young people who are essentially forced to be innovative and entrepreneurial in order to support their families, go to school, etc (as an example, check out this TechCrunch article about entrepreneurs in the slums of Brazil http://techcrunch.com/2010/05/12/coming-up-from-the-favelas-brazils-slumdog-entrepreneurs/).
nurturing_entrepreneurs_worldwide_global.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31

comments.text: Jaime, glad you like this idea! And your friend is on the right track!

Wow! great insight ashley! I have a friend who is teaching her daughter with addition, subtraction, multiplication and division by giving her goods to sell to her friends and classmates. At the end of the day, they sit down do the math and her daughter is so happy that she found out she earned.

Grass roots innovation tends to be mostly passive and innovators and people around them usually do not appreciate the magnitude of their solutions. Any  platform that links people together and increased information/knowledge velocity will help.

Avi, your concept is terrific! Thanks so much for pointing it out - I am still new to OpenIDEO so I'm not always aware of what ideas were previously submitted. What I like about your concept is that it builds on toolkits and programs that already exist, like IDEO's HCD kit. I also love the idea of a TEDx for kids - in fact I think I heard that one took place recently? I'll have to check. Thanks to you, Christine, and Meena for your thoughts. Now I need to think through how to move this into the concept phase!

You might find this concept helpful:http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-increase-the-availability-of-affordable-learning-tools-educational-for-children-in-the-developing-world/concepting/an-innovation-academy-for-kid-entrepreneurs/

Love this. What about creating a match-making platform geared to kids that enables entrepreneurship and concept-creation cross cultures? Similar to peer-to-peer learning but from an generative and entrepreneurial angle.
Relevant questions indeed. Aflatoun is one of the organisations working in this area in India: http://bit.ly/9OJVeh
Provoking thoughts Ashley! Now that the Agenda Concepts phase is open  we hope you might use this post to devise a specific question for global innovation leaders to address at the i20 summit.

nurturing_entrepreneurs_worldwide_global.title: Nurturing Entrepreneurs Worldwide (Global)

redesign_the_ideas_of_the_city..description: Cities today are the opportunity  to many of the worlds problems. In cities, people are connected, education is better, finding a doctor is easier, finding a job is easier, life is better for most. But is the concept of the city today still worth rethinking?
redesign_the_ideas_of_the_city..creator: d1aacd22b4aa8bdc73b7b0053eb8a201

comments.text: Agreed  a great focal point and insightful video!Redesigning the city throws up many issues, as you mention. Can we start to post examples of ways these are being met in innovative ways from around the globe currently? That way we can form a collection of inspirations before we move on to the Agenda Concepts stage. Here's an example that speaks the notion of re-imagining cities: http://bit.ly/cpDjQK) Keep those great ideas flowing guys...

very interesting point about pairing cities experiencing rapid population growth with those experiencing decline.
I agree Auto-industry cities should think about the future of infrastructure that may or may not include the technology of the present day.

In contrast, you have a city like Detroit, which has become less connected, less social etc as people moved out after the slow and painful demise of the auto industry.   That said, it is trying hard to re-define itself with things like urban farming and artistic communities.    What if somehow a city like Detroit, that is now more vacant than ever be paired with the likes of Mexico City and be the provider of mass transit solutions (not in the form of the car) but be the center for culminating the best of all the mass transit systems in the world and create jobs to make all the necessary parts so that Mexico City spend their time and energy on people traveling together versus in cars?  Could these kind of pairings translate between cities across the world?
indeed, Steward brand would say that we will be 75% Urban by mid century. Today, about half of the world's population live in cities.
Good focal point, as the majority of the world's population is now living in cities.

redesign_the_ideas_of_the_city..title: Redesign the ideas of the city.

empower_local_activism_through_storytell.description: Catalytic Communications is working in the Rio favelas to empower residents through media capture and social media trainings.
empower_local_activism_through_storytell.creator: 677b685af5345b36ecb6d35b4852cc5c

comments.text: Making a difference sometimes doesn't necessarily mean making policy changes, but finding new ways to navigate bad policy. I think the most important thing is giving people the tools and skill to come up with ways of change making. Organisations like Ashoka - http://www.ashoka.org/ - are doing so.
I think the idea of developing localised networks to enable people to contribute their stories and shape policy is a fantastic one.

empower_local_activism_through_storytell.title: Empower Local Activism Through Storytelling

how_can_we_inspire_kids_to_get_excited_a.description: I've seen many ideas about education come up on this challenge, and a common theme is using design and other creative approaches to education as a way to inspire kids to be innovative and entrepreneurial. Whether building on ideas like the ones I've cited below, or looking at models championed by organizations like Citizen Schools (see the video), I have found examples of classroom education that's relevant, engaging, and gives kids a "big picture view" of where their education can take them. Another common theme is bringing professionals into the classroom to show kids what life looks like as an architect, a doctor, a carpenter, or a business person. I really think the key is helping connect the dots between what kids are learning in school now and where these learnings will take them in their careers.
how_can_we_inspire_kids_to_get_excited_a.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31
how_can_we_inspire_kids_to_get_excited_a.title: How can we inspire kids to get excited about and feel invested in their education?

connectivity.creator: 006fe0f8f73c108fad5cb289ceac4bd1

comments.text: Good example Sergio! While some might think that this doesn't speak to a pressing global need  your summary of the mission to 'simplify the way people and organizations interact, communicate and collaborate' could be applied to many big picture issues. These kinds of examples will help us build a library of inspirations before we get onto exploring the Agenda Concepts in the next phase.

biking_taken_seriously.description: The city of Vancouver is responding to an increase in bicycle commuters by developing bigger and safer bike lanes in main streets and avenues.
biking_taken_seriously.creator: 95ec567e1dd393fd45927d9d9e204b2b

comments.text: Many European cities  notably the Netherlands and Scandanavia  make priorities for cyclists. Even cities like Peru are catching on: http://bit.ly/95mnRF London has made progress this year too: http://bit.ly/bZ2C8V I also like bottom-up initiatives such as Bike Pool: http://bit.ly/96g7RA which uses social media to connect cyclists. The Yoxi platform also profiled a great idea: http://bit.ly/bTTvAo You've raised a great point here Pablo  and more attention should be paid to the many innovations taking place globally in this space by cities that are struggling to adjust to urban congestion and vehicle poluution.

biking_taken_seriously.title: Biking Taken Seriously (Vancouver)

online_democracy_and_decision_making.description: Technology has revolutionized the way we publish and access information.  We have information, loads of it, freely available, almost a commodity now.  What we need now is a revolution in making and taking optimal decisions and actions together.....
online_democracy_and_decision_making.creator: 5c5011157b10ce049d0021c1cc4d14fe

comments.text: How far do we go with the concept of online democracy? Do you imagine the 2012 elections taking place online? Should we be able to manage our government accounts and political decisions as we do our bank accounts?

Oh, I also agree that we're behind in upgrading our cultural and political notions, but America is a huge country-- a massive country. With more mass, it is more difficult to change direction. So I don't expect to see much budge in larger countries anytime soon, particularly when they struggle just to make decisions on something as threatening as climate change!

We are in the era of distraction and unengagement indeed. But there's also a growing movement of open culture and community-- which also falls appropriately between the technology world and the climate change movement. This is going to be the future! We're on the right path; now, we just need to further catalyze this movement, and help it grow, and continue doing what we're doing.
See: http://openideo.com/open/what-is-the-global-challenge-that-most-concerns-you-right-now-and-that-global-innovation-leaders-could-begin-to-solve/agenda-concepts/how-can-we-use-technology-to-make-open-democracy-a-reality/

online_democracy_and_decision_making.title: Online democracy and decision making

implementing_design_thinking_by_redesign.description: Design thinking aims to discover the real needs of customers and this means that an organization’s strategy should be customer focused. A customer focus, however, can run into barriers when parts of the organization have different objectives like pushing products or ROI. There is still a need for clearer models of how to align the whole organization and all the functions to customer metrics: sales, marketing, product development, operations, management, accounting, finance, and human resources. For example, how does marketing represent customer needs in meetings in a way that meshes with the criteria of finance? If design thinking is inserted into traditional organizations that are incompatible, then designs are not as likely to be supported and faithfully produced and delivered. How can we create models of organizations to implement design thinking to serve customers and stakeholders?
implementing_design_thinking_by_redesign.creator: fcb1dc6f540886cd1905b62c0a723c4e
implementing_design_thinking_by_redesign.title: How can we Redesign Organizations to Implement Design Thinking?

comments.text: we used P2P funding also for the Future of Money Project www.emergence.cc

GrameenBank and Kiva.org : microcredits, mostly to farmers, startups and small trades in developing countries.
CrowdCulture : a swedish version that is for non-profit-cultural and creative small-scale businessprojects, the cultural department is trying to help this to update their own old-style-thinking on funding, scholarships, stipends (government matches the sums of all the privately donated sums): http://bit.ly/aQ5r4X
http://www.indiegogo.com/ works with all sorts of projects including those beyond the creative sector
Great! What other novel funding methods do folks know of from around the globe? Could the Kickstarter model be applied to endeavors beyond the creative sector?

development_of_the_social_policy_interfa.description: To develop the social-policy interface previously to the most relevant decision-making processes of our time.
development_of_the_social_policy_interfa.creator: 9f926880e84ea0eb301decf03d398f55

comments.text: Thanks for adding those Pablo  they are brilliant examples! We're fans of bottom-up approaches as well as top-down and side-to-side ; ) If we continue to collect a wide span of inspirations in this space we're likely to do a better job together of devising an Agenda Concept in this realm. Great to see a number of examples flowing in around the intersection of social and policy innovation.

Thank you for these three comments.
Nicole, reading your comment I noticed that I didn't consider as an example the inclusion of human rights as one of the most relevant issues of nowadays. Watch what's going on in many countries (e.g. Western Sahara). Global leaders should include it.The idea is to prepare these intefaces a priori, with the top supporting and enhancing innovative stakeholders from the bottom. With enough time, most issues should be tackle participatively preventing them to became a contingency or something too urgent that requires a top-down intervention rather than a bottom up, emergent and systemic solutions.
OpenIDEO, thanks for reminding me about Arjan's inspiration, it looks good. However, I must say that what Im proposing is the difficult task, which means going (most of the times) from the bottom to the top. GudrasGalvas seems to propose a traditional (and great) mechanism of top-down communication and consultation to the civil population, being that instrumental for transparency (a fantastic goal otherwise). Yes, I have some examples but based more on the results on case studies than on closed projects. However I can mention two, within which we are making a lot of effort though action research trying to build specific interfaces prior to decision-making (added to my inspiration).
Arjan, thank you for your link, it looks pretty good and I will go through it very carefully. It seems really in alignment with my proposal.
An interesting website to keep an eye on in this space is Social Brite: http://www.socialbrite.org/. They are posting a lot on how NGOs can use social media tools.

Good call Pablo. Arjan has posted a great example of this kind of thing here: http://bit.ly/a5w0yt Can we collect further examples of existing intitiaves in this space during our Inspiration phase?
Nicole  technology + media capability + collaboration are indeed big issues and we're glad you and others have been posting examples of how this is being addressed in various locations. This diversity of approaches will help us when we move on to the next phase of fine-tuning Agenda Concepts.

This is SO important. It's not only about government, its equally about civil society engaging new interfaces and ways of communicating. I am trained as a human rights lawyer, and it is always astounding to me that so many traditional NGOs are completely technologically inept. This not only impacts their ability to get funding, but also to communicate / share ideas / collaborate. It also affects their ability reach stakeholders and people on the ground who are actually affected. NGOs then wind up making duplicative efforts and actually being competitive rather than collaborative. Bridging the grassroots - local NGO - National / Int'l NGO - Gov divide would be enormous.

development_of_the_social_policy_interfa.title: Development of the social-policy interface

open_government_at_all_levels.description: Following up on Shana's inspiration about local government engagement in San Francisco, there is an opportunity at all levels of government (from individual towns to international organizations like the United Nations) to increase public participation in a collaborative innovation process. This increases the chance of creating solutions that truly meet the needs of and are actively supported by citizens, while also building public trust through a transparent process. One large-scale example in the United States is the current National Open Government Initiative.
open_government_at_all_levels.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: For sure, that's a way to make corruption lower. When citizens are involved on the public administration (looking at all governors actions), it can works.

Lowering the threshold for citizens to engage with governments is important for innovation in a country. Deploying platforms like these not only enables that, but also drives a change in attitude on the 'governing' side. It urges public services to listen better.
Because different citizens will engage with civic issues on different levels, we should definitely explore opening government at different levels!

open_government_at_all_levels.title: Open Government  At All Levels

bees_mans_best_friend_providor_and_prote.description:
Dr. Reese Halter's report on bees:

For the past few years, the news has been filled with a drumbeat of doom over the fate of the honey bee. Thanks largely to a mysterious phenomenon known as Colony Collapse Disorder (CCD), the number of hives has been falling, with catastrophic implications for the species, and for our agricultural system. England's hives have been vanishing faster than anywhere else in Europe, with more than half dying out over the past 20 years.

The humble honey bee must be saved at all costs – for what other creature can foil terrorists and drug lords, save us from horrid diseases, and still contribute towards a delicious and nutritious breakfast?

Read the full report here: http://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/8104213/Bees-mans-best-friend-provider-and-protector.html

Dr Reese Halter is a conservation biologist at California Lutheran University and author of 'The Incomparable Honey Bee and the Economics of Pollination' (Rocky Mountain Books)
bees_mans_best_friend_providor_and_prote.creator: 9af96c4abe78b8a4ff4841ab1c9d1104
bees_mans_best_friend_providor_and_prote.title: Bees: mans best friend, providor and protector

natural_high.description:
I decided to upload my own research project. Happy to share with OpenIDEO.





Natural high studies  methods of employing recent advances in digital fabrication (3D Printing) with low-cost ubiquitous construction materials (mud). Investigation tests strategies of changing the form of the brick from the cuboid to a differentiated honeycomb lattice of masonry units. The project studies how changing the shape and cost of a brick could lead to an entirely new design of the city.
natural_high.creator: d1aacd22b4aa8bdc73b7b0053eb8a201

comments.text: Interesting project, thanks for sharing!

how_can_we_get_more_people_to_contribute.description: Clay Shirky spoke about "Cognitive Surplus" - that people were finally employing their spare time to cogitate and act in ways that was worthwhile. There have always been a lot of people providing money to causes, but not as many providing time and effort to volunteer at charities, planting trees, cleaning rivers, teaching, helping the underprivileged and the like. How do we make it fun, 'cool', and worthwhile for more and more people to spend a minor fraction of their time in little ways: writing a free textbook Wikipedia-style, pulling out weeds in the neighbourhood park, helping traffic cops man weekend traffic, educating people from littering and so on. How do we enable people be, for perhaps an hour a week, be the change they wish to see in the world around them?
how_can_we_get_more_people_to_contribute.creator: bdb17a3044a511d1a2a6f540615c48c7
how_can_we_get_more_people_to_contribute.title: How can we get more people to contribute time/effort to the world around them?

teach_positive_failure.description: One of the big inhibitors that I see in our governmental work right now is inertia bred through fear of failure. Innovation is a series of learnings that only come from experimentation and failure needs to be embraced as such: part of a learning journey.
teach_positive_failure.creator: 415b61e765a41e8dfd771e64477f84fd

comments.text: I really like this post.  I think it can be applied to anything in life... and I feel that all postgraduate students can benefit from this lesson in developing any project.
If a teacher can teach positive failure, the teacher will not necessarily fail the student.

Just to add, there's a bit of research in the learning sciences field on "productive failure" for eg Productive failure in mathematical problem solving http://mathedresearch.blogspot.com/2009/04/productive-failure-in-mathematical.html - will be interesting to see if some aspects of productive failure can be applied here.
Failing in a project can be a great inspiration for many new ideas and perhaps solutions and innovations to prevent failing in the future.

Absolutely right. The fear of ending a political career, the fear of the wrath of the voter in next elections, I think that all helps to sustain this fear of failing. Also, public services generally speaking do not have dynamic 'corporate' cultures. It would be good to strengthen the idea that every failure is also an opportunity to learn and just do it better next time.

In business, isn't it true that about 33% of businesses fail in the first 6 months and only 44% are still running after 4 years?   Aren't there many venture capitalists out there who will only invest in entrepreneurs who have already have one failure under their belt?   There's a lesson here and I agree it's one that governments and particularly government donor agencies need to learn.

teach_positive_failure.title: Teach Positive Failure

how_to_provide_equal_opportunities_by_ch.description:
In the last years companies started to outsource manufacturing to poorer countries in order to reduce costs.

And a lot of people in those poorer countries tried the opposite: they migrate to richer countries looking for better opportunities.
 
But the rules are the opposite for them: richer countries closes the frontiers to foreign people, while poor countries opens them to companies –sometimes by relaxing taxes or laws to favor the installations of new factories.

Governments have to think in the promotion of a better approach to globalization. 
Not to reduce production costs, but to share knowledge and allow underdeveloped countries to grow.
how_to_provide_equal_opportunities_by_ch.creator: 9bd6da4e89c3fd7fccfaf9888519a060
how_to_provide_equal_opportunities_by_ch.title: How to provide equal opportunities by changing the way that companies do outsourcing?

designing_the_city_for_the_earth_not_the.description: In response to "Redesign the ideas of the city," the real challenge is redesigning both the cityscape and the landscape.  This requires sensitivity to the earth as well as improving the quality of life with natural resources.  In Mexico City, the earth was overwhelmed with transportation and pollution.  Without smell, people could not really experience the environment.  People needed smell to detect chemicals in the air.  People have also used smell to experience the pleasures in life, such as the smell of bread baking in the oven, or freshly cut grass.  Smell is very primal.  Out of all the senses, it also triggers memory the most.  If we are to improve the quality of life, we need to not only redesign the city, but also create harmony between the environment and the quality of life for people.
designing_the_city_for_the_earth_not_the.creator: 8757541db3a21588d7952dbb8fb5fe29

comments.text: We're glad you're finding OpenIDEO addictive Kristine!

designing_the_city_for_the_earth_not_the.title: Designing the City for the Earth (Not the other way around!)

how_can_we_improve_space_in_the_developi.description: There are lots of tools to improve different aspects of space - safety, ecology, convenience of use, type and purpose of use. The developing countries are far behind the developped ones in making their spaces and architectural design efficient. Especially now, when architecture is really far ahead in some countries leaving the poorest ones with the medieval solutions. Using the exactly same tools, though, will kill the diversity of space, which is essential for the global inspiration and for the development of different paths rather than locking ourselves in one solution. I think it is important to equalize the efficiency of space without making everything the same.
how_can_we_improve_space_in_the_developi.creator: f663744062e5876058493e584f1dbd3e

comments.text: Thanks Arjan! I must say that I heard once or twice that Poland was famous for the renewals of old buildings and old-towns restorations. The same thing is going on in my city - Wroclaw/ former Breslau/. Making old cities look great is one aspect, but building new parts of towns using one's own imagination and local point of view is the other, I think.

Lukasz, I visited Elblag recently (for a stopover), and I have to say that I was impressed by the old town. I really admired the way that in this Polish city they adjusted the new architecture to fit the look and feel of the old city. It might have looked a bit German, but I think that in cities like this, that has a lot to do with the historic significance of the Hanseatic League and therefore also Poland's history. Just to let you know it's not all bad :).

Thanks a lot Adriana!I have not heard about the series before - it looks very interesting. The diversity of issues and insights from around the world is very inspiring, also for architects, to do something deeper than modern aesthetics.
Interesting proposal Lukasz, this reminded me of the "Learning From..." series at the CCA http://www.cca.qc.ca/en/education-events/530-learning-from-series

how_can_we_improve_space_in_the_developi.title: How can we improve space in the developing countries without killing the global diversity?

can_the_metric_system_finally_be_globall.description:
Please??
This may sound like a silly question but the stubborn refusal of the United States to officially adopt the Metric System as it's standard for weights and measures is the cause of huge amounts of global inefficiency.  The time is long overdue for the U.S. (and Burma and Liberia) to follow the lead of the rest of the world's 203 countries and use the Metric System.
can_the_metric_system_finally_be_globall.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: Thanks for the comment Larry!I agree that in some parts of the U.S. both systems are in use to some degree.  But I think that it still needs to become ingrained in our culture to the point that we unconsciously think about measurement in terms of metric. Right now there is still a mental conversion that has to happen. A lot more needs to be done for it to become the default system for everyday usage for everyone.  This is why I think that it is important for our leaders to move us in that direction with legislation, advertising, by example, etc.Thanks again for your comment!

I like Sabra's idea of teaching the metric system as the default, with the idea of the English system as part of the culture.  Especially in areas of the US that are already very international, I hear both systems in use in daily conversation.

Sabra, Thanks for the comment! Interesting distinction!  Yes, I might agree... it is important to learn where we came from - gaining a thorough understanding of our history, global and local, even down to what might be considered the mundane - so that we are secure in our knowledge of the decision process that got us to where we are.  And of course so that we don't repeat past mistakes.  And equally important is to cultivate a culture comfortable with continual self-examination.  If we get stuck on something and resist well-considered change or development, we risk being left behind  by the rest of society and becoming obsolete and irrelevant.  This, I think, is the corner the U.S. has painted itself into by holding on to the 'U.S. Customary' system for so long.  The world is leaving us behind.Thanks again for your contributions!
I think metric should be first in education for global citizenship, and customary systems should be taught as part of history and cultural education.

Thanks for the comment Sabra!  You are right that some people can easily handle mastery of both systems.  I have worked with both in the field of design and fabrication and it is manageable.  Though I will admit that I think metric is the much smarter system.  Conversion between units and scaling up or down is a piece of cake.  There are just so many problems inherent in the U.S. Customary system. For example, doubling 6 5/8" can either be 13 1/4" or 1' - 1 1/4".  And this assumes everyone understands the " and ' marks.  Another example would be that 'one and a half pounds' should really not be written as 1.5lbs but rather 1lb 8oz.  The reason being that not all of the decimal divided pound measures are as easily convertible to ounces.  1.6lbs for instance.  Then there's also the confusion between ounces of weight and ounces of volume, remembering how many tablespoons are in a cup, etc.  But, you are correct in that some people get along fine with it all.  I think the big problems, as was mentioned, come into play when conversion error happens in commercial industry or when lives are at stake such as accidentally overloading a plane or using fractions of an inch to build a spaceship.  And on that last point I have to endorse the metric system - fabricating something down to the millimeter is much more exact and straightforward than when fabricating using sixteenths or thirty-seconds of an inch.Anyway, i think the main point is that if we were all using the same system of measure that things would be that much more efficient.  A unified system would save time, precious energy and money, not to mention possibly a life or two every once in a while.  The metric system, adopted by almost everyone - except the U.S. and two other countries - seems to be the most viable candidate.  And a good system at that.Thanks again for your comment!

Johan, thanks for the comment!  Yes, it would make life so much simpler for all involved. There would be no more need for hard to remember conversion multipliers from one system to the other (not to mention that the conversions even within the U.S. system are arcane).  And where there are conversions there is opportunity for error!Thanks again!(yes, I think pint in the UK is only for beer... that's why it can't be touched! I was joking a little :) )

Most people I know in the U.S. use both measuring systems to some degree. I don't see why we have to give up one to have the other." Customary" measure is better for some things like cooking, and tools to repair old machines. It's not so good for NASA apparently:(

Yes. It is just such a small change, and will remove all confusion with international trade and commerce.
(it is just as silly when the U.S. national championships in some sports are called World series...)
(regarding pint in U.K, isn't it just used for beer these days???)

Matthew, Thanks for the comment!  Yes, I think you are right in that normally, the U.S. attitude is that we are the cultural leaders and that all other nations should conform to our way of doing things.  Well, the metric system is one of those places where the U.S. has been left way behind and needs to just get over itself and do whatever it takes to catch up as quickly as possible.  The time to act is way past due!  Thanks again!
I'm American and I think this is a great idea.  But the way we are and think it would be more like, can the rest of the world use the US customary system?

Thanks for the comment Globalfirm!  I find it so strange that the U.S. has not switched to the metric system after all of these years.  And even stranger that it seems as though no one is talking about it in the public space!  What an amazing opportunity this could be for a public figure or leader to get people talking and inspired to take action and make the change!  Thanks again!
Great idea!

can_the_metric_system_finally_be_globall.title: Can the Metric System Finally Be Globally Adopted?

cradle_to_cradle_design_plan_to_use_wast.description: Achieving greater Sustainability requires much more recycling. Retailers and manufacturers of short use, high value objects should come with some guarantee of buy-back, or at least purposeful return policies, to maximise recycling opportunities.
cradle_to_cradle_design_plan_to_use_wast.creator: d9d013d2b14cc2be9a75b1eaca89f5c8

comments.text: Thanks for all your comments. Demian, your comment about single-use non-decomposable plastics is a real long term concern, and many consumers don't want (or will happily do without) them.

The mushroom packaging idea is pretty brilliant.  I remember going to the Tokyo fish market, seeing the mountain of empty styrofoam boxes and thinking 'does this much styro trash get generated here every day? And that's just at one of the world's many fish markets.  As with my 'Plastic Problem' concept, http://preview.tinyurl.com/249v9ko the proliferation of high-energy-consumption, single-use, non-decomposable plastic products is a huge problem.  We need to make big changes in how we think about and use our resources.  Thanks Simon!

What a great material!
This style of organic material manufacturing addresses several global challenges: finite non-renewable resources; high energy demand to create materials; and landfill of products after use. Innovation leaders should share technologies like this with each other. Organic materials would however be restricted in some export markets as they pose a threat to native eco-systems (and economies).

Wow, I really enjoyed the video! I would like to see a greater effort in designing for these new material technolgies. We're learning more and more about echo-friendly materials and production methods with great product potential. I hope videos like this inspire designers to develop products around these new technologies. Corner blocks are great, but there is so much untapped potential. I'm aware that steamed/expanded cork is a very popular and sustainable thermal insulation in Europe, but products like these could be doing much more.
I wholeheartedly agree. Thank you for posting that video, very insightful information.

cradle_to_cradle_design_plan_to_use_wast.title: Cradle to Cradle Design - Plan to Use Waste

how_can_we_rethink_money_and_economic_sy.description: With flaws in our current economic systems, how can we harness other techniques for banking and financing to benefit people and communities, providing greater opportunities and stability against global economic shifts?
how_can_we_rethink_money_and_economic_sy.creator: 81446bf6aa4c90e4a5700e7e6ac2b0a3

comments.text:
I can't help but feel we should include developing poor places in our own country as well.  The more we can set an example, alongside others, the more powerful collaborative solutions will become.I think of the Skoll Foundation as a key stakeholder in this issue, as well as others like maybe Ashoka Fellows.  This is not my area of great knowledge. There is a rather new group in Denver called WISDOM worth looking at.  They are hooking up venture folks with good ideas and causes using business practices. 
The more attention and "status" we can bring to these efforts the more likely they are to create positive buzz and hopefully replication.  I like the idea of compiling a resource list, alongside best practices, to build on the best examples big and small.
Alongside this, I am a huge believer in capacity building and making sure whoever touches another person, community or country always leaves more capability behind than before.  
Integrating  key qualities and principles consistently, into the design, implementation and action phases of innovative ideas needs more attention in every area of our innovative approaches.

Good questions. Which other institutions are willing to participate in localized financing? IMF, central banks? Are there any opportunities for Business Angels or Micro-VCs for engaging in these financial dynamics?

how_can_we_rethink_money_and_economic_sy.title: How can we rethink money and economic systems to benefit people where they are?

No – it's interesting but not of global significance
Does this concept point to innovation opportunities that i20 leaders can discuss?
It points to a range of opportunities
It points to a single opportunity
It's indeed a challenge but doesn't point to opportunities
Is this concept well framed?
Yes – it relevantly covers the issue to promote onwards discussion
Somewhat – though the scope is either too narrow or too wide
Not really – interesting issue but this concept doesn't really invite conversation

empowering_the_disempowered_with_open_da.description: The open data movements of the US government, EU and some development partners (e.x. World Bank) tend to empower the empowered. How do we engage the disempowered to help contribute, shape and open data to change behaviors to improve social and economic development?
empowering_the_disempowered_with_open_da.creator: 5ba729c9820f854187114f7e0e8d3eba

comments.text: This is great  making data available to everyone, not just statisticians and researchers, provides so many opportunities for continued improvement and new solutions. In Chicago, CMAP, the Metropolitan Agency for Planning, recently released a website called MetroPulse (http://www.metropulsechicago.org/), which has accessible and usable data for the region available to everyone to use. Most of this data is available somewhere in a pdf or a published booklet, but putting it to graphs and charts with interactive features allows for way more options on who can interact with it. This could be great at a number of different scales!
Let's not forget wikileaks, which is aggressively open with its data, though its process and motivations is opaque

There is a lot going on in this subject via the Open Government Directive under the transparency part of the initiative.  There are a couple of big questions and challenges surfacing.Even if the data is available, it is not often in any useful form. Agencies themselves were never set up to collect or organize much of the requested information, and even when there is data towards transparency, how to make it relevant and useful is 'the big question".  It's the "so what" part of the bigger question?  Who is going to use it and how do we make it useful to real communities and citizens?  This was a major focus at a conference I spoke at, hosted by the National Institute on State Politics and Money, this past June.  This meeting was invitation only and was primarily a mix of investigative journalists and those in the transparency "movement" and/or Gov 2.0. I was invited because of my applied experience in communities.
David is quite accurate in his comments that the open data movement is empowering the already empowered.  They have hopes and ambitions to involve local communities, but don't know how.  "So what or who cares" if you have the data and nobody uses it?  This is a struggle going on now.
The Sunlight Foundation (http://sunlightfoundation.com) is very involved with transparency and data.  They are not the only newer non-profit with their eye on this ball.  How effective they will be in translating all this, in a way it's useful to local communities, is a good question.  Another group working on this, in a more applied way, is Code for America (http://Code for America.com).  It's modeled after Teach for America.
I get somewhat concerned when so many doing this data work are great at technology, but don't have experience in community or applied setting work, or any of the other parts of the whole picture.  This may be where the breakdown is, or will occur, even if great data is available. I am very in favor of multi-disciplinary teams, involving various professionals and age groups is important.  We need the wisdom of many to pull any of this off successfully.

Interesting post David. Can you add some links to the kind of open data movements you are referring to? Is Ushahidi a positive development in this space? http://bit.ly/bT3U3O and Frontline SMS? http://www.frontlinesms.com/
Do other OpenIDEATORS know of further empowering initiatives in this space? It may be useful contrast these to what David mentions above so that global innovation leaders can get a sense of the gap.

empowering_the_disempowered_with_open_da.title: Empowering the Disempowered with Open Data

food_for_the_heart_and_mind_the_mid_day_.description: For some kids in India, education and meals don't always go in hand - one has to be sacrificed for the other. The mid-day meal scheme, 40 years old but still relevant, promises each student lunch each school day, thus providing a massive incentive to  keeping kids in school
food_for_the_heart_and_mind_the_mid_day_.creator: bdb17a3044a511d1a2a6f540615c48c7
food_for_the_heart_and_mind_the_mid_day_.title: Food for the heart and mind : The mid-day meal school scheme (India)
